number of helpful: 240 of 287 people (84%) found this review helpful12 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												Homefront is an FPS which tells the story of a resistance movement fighting back against a near future Korean occupation of the USA.The game play is a very generic FPS. Pretty much identical to Call of Duty and Medal of Honor; you can only carry two weapons,  and four grenades. You will have to swap to different weapons from dead enemies throughout each level as finding ammo is more difficult than you would imagine. None of the enemies use the same weapon...Graphics wise, it looks nice, but you can tell the game was released in 2011, it looks better than most games released, however it shows it's age when comparing it to more recent titles. The graphical options are wide and you can probably play this game on a potato if you really wanted.All the maps in the single player are very well designed, sadly you can't really explore because you are constantly reminded to keep following your squad leader. You fight through various different environments such as the streets of suburbs, department stores, and baseball fields, all of which show a disturbing outcome of the quite scary "what if?" scenario from a Korean invasion.The single player of Homefront will take about five hours to complete; this is pretty short in my opinion, and the game ends on a massive cliff hanger, I would of liked to have seen another two or three more missions to tire up the loose ends in the story.  Multiplayer is still very much alive in Homefront, I have only played in a couple of games but I had no problem finding a map full of people to jump into. A lot of the reviews you will read on here will say multiplayer is the strongest aspect of the game, so they can't all be wrong. I would like to recommend Homefront; however I would wait till it is on sale, it has recently been on sale a few weeks ago for as low as £3,75, which would be an absolute bargain if you could get it for that again in an up coming sale.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

number of helpful: 183 of 228 people (80%) found this review helpful18 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Set in the year 2027, Homefront presents a kind of "worst case scenario" of the near future. Kim Jong-Il has died and has been succeeded by his son, Kim Jong-Un. After unifying North and South Korea, and forming the Greater Korean Republic, Kim Jong-Un begins annexing nearby countries, such as Japan and Vietnam. At the same time, America's economy lies in shambles due to their dependence on foreign oil. After a satellite-launched EMP blast, Korea finally invades America.In the single player campaign, you play as Robert Jacobs, a former helicopter pilot who is being recruited for "re-education" by the Koreans. But pilots have become scarce in occupied America, and the resistance fighters need one for an important mission. Luckily, it doesn't take them long to liberate you from your Korean captors.The gameplay is fast-paced and exhilarating throughout the campaign. The shooting feels incredibly tight and powerful, and is extremely satisfying. Honestly, I don't remember the last time it felt this good to shoot someone in the face. The AI, for both squad mates and enemies, is outstanding. Your squad mates are able to hold their own in a firefight, and even saved my life on more than one occasion. And your enemies provide a fitting challenge without it feeling like they're cheating. For instance, enemies don't automatically know where you are (like in some shooters) making for some pretty awesome ambush scenarios.As a member of the Resistance, you're almost always outmanned and outgunned, meaning that hit-and-run guerilla tactics are preferred over head-on assaults. And even though you're only a lowly member of the Resistance, you still get some neat toys to play with once and a while, such as the Goliath: a six-wheeled tank-like vehicle that destroys enemies that you mark with a targeting device. You also get to man the gun of a humvee and fly a helicopter over the course of the campaign.The only problem with the campaign is that it is over far too quickly. Consisting of seven missions, it only takes few hours to finish the campaign on normal difficulty.Once you're finished with the campaign, you can always jump into the multiplayer. The online multiplayer in Homefront is almost an exact copy of Call of Duty's online offerings. There are six different classes, such as "Assault" and "Sniper," that can be customized and renamed. As you gain experience and level up, you unlock new perks and weapons. Up to 32 players can play in a match, and most of the maps are of the suburban variety.Graphically, Homefront is solid. Environments are well-detailed, and help set the tone of an occupied America. Some textures, like the wood grain in a hardwood floor, look absolutely stunning. But shadows sometimes look a little low res, and character models can look sketchy at times. But even if Homefront had the greatest graphics in the world, they would still pale in comparison to the phenomenal sound design. The voice acting is spot-on, and the incredible soundtrack sets the mood perfectly throughout the entire campaign.If you're the kind of gamer that values quality over quantity, then you'll definitely want to check out Homefront.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Right now, this Homefront is right where it belongs. Mixed reviews, dropped price (sales up to 90% recommended)... And yet, it's not all that bad.As a straight-forward shooter with a rather short singleplayer campaign and not-so-bright multiplayer, it's not worth much. I don't like Call of Duty series, but this game generally worse at gameplay than Infinity Ward games, and somewhere on the level of Treyarch jobbing. Don't believe to those who're saying that there's only 3 hours of gameplay. That comes from people who are playing at easy difficulty. Yeah, the AI is not the brightest bulb in garland, yet the overall challenge is quite fair, weaponry is nice and overall impression from shootouts is decent enough - if we're not going into ballistics and bullet piercing effects.The controls are generally good (except vehicles). The visuals are not bad, on the level with CoD, again. Nothing too fancy, though. The overall viewing angle a bit too small, like we wear an assault helmet - but it is not so! Levels aren't really large, and even when they are - the path is usually quite narrow. Bugs... exists, but not overwhelming. I remember only one rage-producing moment, when I dropped hostile glow hawk, and then trigger moving at place where I was some Bradley or whatever, and sending me to restart point. That's bad, yeah, but not really game-breaking. The engine is quite stabile, no crushes, no any big troubles that can't be fixed with reload.Multiplayer part is not dead - servers (mostly) working, some people are running around and killing each other... usual stuff. I liked the idea that the more kills you perform, the more clear to opposite team your exact position. That's making cheaters more noticable to others - however, they're still a trouble to fairplay, admins aren't really any good at moment. Overall - multiplayer there is dull and down-sized version of Battlefield 3, so - no, not recommended for MP, without your own team especially.What I really like about the Homefront - is of amount of backstage work. Of course, it's all quite naive and, as always, made by people who are very far from real warfare business... But still, they're showing quite nasty and somewhat realistic picture of the former "United States of America", being rounded up and bended by hunger, lack of fuel, the inhumanity of the former citizens, and much more brutality on the part of the mighty Korean warriors. Basically, the story tells that just right after the USA dropped the flag of the world's №1 oppressor, due to financial problems, they got it all back. Right from 18th century ("The only good American is a dead American"), and particularly, for the US oppressive war of 1950-1953. Yeah, united Koreans, managed to best the US, using their own tactics and arsenal. It supposed to be ironical, but in fact turns out way too pathetic. The aftertaste of this story is even worse than in case of Spec Ops the Line... not so strong and bitter, however. That's just a visualized horror of "oh, God, what if the world will do to US the same thing we're doing to them now? Like in Iraq, Afgan, Libya etc..." Well, I am more believe in scenario like in the "Invasion day" 2013 movie - where Americans themselves selling all and everything out. And still - good scenario and background work. Videogames are really objects of art, and as one of them - Homefront deserves your brief look. Standard-issue FPS with good guns and story of bended US, spitting in the face of invaders... Worth 6.5 points from me (out of usual 10).

number of helpful: 45 of 58 people (78%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
This isn't Advanced Warfare (Well...it's set in 2027)This isn't Modern Warfare (Ok, it kind of is) This is Guerilla Warfare. Homefront tells a story that not many other FPS games have told. Many games like to show the U.S. as "the undefeatable force" and the "people who always save the day in the end". In this game, you get to experience the opposite. What would happen if North Korea were to occupy America? Answer: It's not pretty. CAMPAIGNNorth Korea has occupied America. You play as Robert Jabcobs, a pilot in the army. You are part of the Resistance, a small army trying to fight against the KPA (Korean People's Army). Along your journey, you will see the horrors of this alternate future and experience a different  gameplay style of a shooter game. The story to me is good, nothing amazing, but simply good. the characters are memorable and have their distinct personalities. Guerilla warfare is  something that this game introduces. Usually when you play titles like Call of Duty and  Battlefield (lets just use those titles as an example), these games usually want you to be an explosive and ammo grinding hero. This is somewhat the opposite in Homefront. Throughout the game, you will be performing hit-and-run raids and surprise attacks. Also, for each gun you pick up, you might only find one magazine and the maximum ammo you can carry for most weapons will be lower than 100. Instead of spraying like John Rambo, you gotta aim  carefully like a skilled Marksman. The campaign is about 5-6 hours long for me on Xbox 360.MULTIPLAYERI haven't spent much time playing multiplayer, but there is still a small and dedicated community playing. Multiplayer has the typical customization that most modern FPS multiplayer games have. The multiplayer feels like a hybrid of Battlefield and Call of Duty if you ask me. However, with that being said, I wouldn't recommend buying Homefront for the multiplayer since the player count is less than 200, but if you really want to play Homefront for the multiplayer then by all means go ahead.My Own OpinionI'm one of those people who have been interested in Homefront ever since it came out in 2011.The story is one that I still find amusing and I spent time playing it on Xbox 360 (when it still worked).Should you buy it?I would say wait for a sale, then pick it up. It's not the best game in the world, but it has something different to offer.- Psychii

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												STORYThe story, at least at the beginning, is promising and just about close enough to current affairs to have you interested. However, the game is far too forceful with the "oo look how terrible war is" feeling, which seems to be self-defeating: instead of being subtly led into any sort of realisation/agreement, you just feel like you're constantly being struck by a moral hammer that ends up being incredibly annoying but otherwise ineffective.The characters are also less than compelling. Perhaps having more time in the story might help (see note below on playtime).GAMEPLAYThe gameplay itself is ok but I remember the odd restrictions in movement popping up (having to take a specific path rather than being able to jump over certain things was limiting for the gamer who decides to mash every button to get round an obstacle!). For some reason, the game dynamics/enemies/tools etc. felt a bit like those in Dishonored (which isn't a bad thing): weird and also quite enjoyable.GRAPHICSNot bad at all, can't complain.PLAYTIMEI think I spent about 4 hours completing this game on the hardest setting and I'm not a super skilled gamer. A first person shooter should take at least twice this time to complete!SUMMARYGood gameplay and concept, lacking in story and playtime. Probably only buy if you're bored and the price looks favourable...

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
A decent title game a campaign that doesn't meet expectations, but with a great and unique multiplayer mode. Homefront is certainly one of the most unique shooters I’ve ever played, driven by an ingenious and surprisingly well-fleshed out plot and a dark and dreary, realistic setting. But it also controls and feels like a typical shooter, looks like a game that’s several years old, and most importantly, has an inexcusably brief campaign. Multiplayer is Homefront’s redeeming quality, and those gamers out there who are like me and swoon for alternate/future history settings should certainly look into it. However, if what you’re seeking is an upper-echelon shooter, keep looking, because Homefront isn’t what you’re searching for.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												This satisfies my patriotism fetish more than you can possibly understand. Nonetheless, it's a somewhat dissappointing game. Much of the story felt as if it could have had real, tear-jerking moments, yet the elements are never explored. I think the largest reason for this is how rushed the game feels.Don't get me wrong, it plays adequately and looks great. Nonetheless, something about the pacing of the campaign just feels...off. Too much happens too quickly. The protagonist goes from a "military grunt nobody who happens to be handy with a gun" to "lord of war who causes the earth to tremble as he breathes in one's general direction" within an in-game week. I had hope for this game. I really did. When I saw a child's parents executed in front of him, and when I hid amidst dozens of murdered corpses within a mass grave to hide from communist invaders, I thought, "Maybe this game won't just be another lifeless virtual duck-hunt." Unfortunately, I was wrong. I'd much rather the game follow a more humble storyline instead of going for huge "emotional" moments and executing them poorly. Your character is a resitance member. Why not have him act as one? Why not have him smuggle objects, firebomb cars, and raid checkpoints? I was hoping for a game that would convey how Red Dawn (1980s) felt. It very obviously tried to pander to the "MURICA" crowd, which is why I bought it. Even from a totally biased point of view, I think this game fails at what it tried to achieve. A lot of work obviously went into it, yet, the campaign feels like it was rushed out.I got it on sale for 4.99. That's all I can recommend it for.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												(I’m not a huge fan of first person shooter games in general so keep that in mind when reading this review)Okay, first off, this game is WAY too short. The campaign took me only 4 hours to complete on normal difficulty (even with me dying and re-spawning every few minutes)  If you are going to charge $20 for a game, make it a bit longer than 4 hours.	Despite having a short campaign, I had a lot of fun playing this game.  It has a wide variety of fun to use assault rifles, submachine guns, sniper rifles, and not to mention goliath-the resistances armored vehicle that you control with a targeter.	The graphics are sub-par even for a game made in 2011.  On many cases I had to lean closer to my monitor to see if it was an enemy I was aiming at or just a stray piece of garbage.	I have nothing to say about the multiplayer mode as I have not played it but I might update my review after I have played it.	Regardless of the short story and the lacking visuals, I enjoyed this game, but I wouldn’t buy it until it goes on sale or the price goes down.  However if you are looking for a fun first person shooter game that won’t kill your computer, Homefront is a very good option	I give this game a respectable 7/10.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												Story is a bit on the unbelievable side of things. While Homefront is inspired by the original Red Dawn, this is less of a "realistic" attempt at portraying an American insurgency against foreign invaders, jingoistic delight though the film may have been. I'd have preferred a more thoughtful, slow-moving, tactical campaign but Homefront's run-n-gun supersoldiering around can be fun. Despite its flaws Homefront is an entertaining game that tried to be different from the standard modern shooter story. The combat is satisfying and challenging on higher difficulties. Weapons look neat. Multiplayer is actually enjoyable, when you can find a match.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Now I see why people didn't really like Homefront. Don't get me wrong, it's NOT a bad game, but it's a disappointing one, especially when you see how much THQ advertised and promoted this game. So what's brought this game down? The singleplayer. First, it's awefully short; you can beat it in 4 hours. But the story, wow, there's such a cool background and the characters are totally relatable. And that's what annoyed me the most. It has such a good premise that you wonder why isn't it any longer. And the gameplay. It's like a typical military shooter. The problem is that it holds your hand WAY TOO MUCH. For example, you'll have to take out certain enemies, and there's an icon on it saying "SHOOT". Well, what else would I do? Blow a kiss to it? The problems of the singleplayer outweighed it's benefits. Multiplayer fares better. The PC servers are still up, and there's at least one full server on afternoons. It's like a combination of Battlefield and COD. You can use points in-game to purchase things like armor and even vehicles. Maps are quite good too. Ground Control, the main mode, has you capturing certain points, like Domination in Battlefield, only that you can move up to a certain area if one team dominates it, like in the Rush mode in Battlefield. In summary, Homefront is full-priced game with budget-game quality. Buy it when it's on sale.

												Standard Mediocre Modern Military Shooty bang-bangGo here, kill the badguys, wait for AI to open door, find a new gun, rinse and repeat.Story; eh. It's warporn. (twice in a playthrough)- Got stuck on a lot of junk. chairs, clothing lines, rubble. Rather annoying. Also annoying when you try to move back or to the side behind cover only to be blocked by one of the AI...Slightly disappointed, but still enjoyed playing.  Not a bad game, just short and repetitive.Played the game twice; First blind on normal, second on hardest difficulty. Multi-player; Yet to try.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
Home is where the game isLet's start of by saying what I need to say about Homefront. Homefront is an unbalanced and a bit rough game that feels unfinished. And that's the main problem me, and many, others had with this game. It sounds a bit silly recommending a game after starting the review with negative things. Why would I recommend this game then? Why should you buy this game then?The first thing that comes to my mind about Homefront is an abandoned puppy, left with no food, no shelter and left alone in a calm understanding of failure in it's head. You can still see the hope, the brief moment of love it got in it's eyes. If you can open your heart to the sad and helpless Homefront you are treated with a pretty mediocre yet fun FPS experience.Homefront does a lot of things wrong. But at the same time Homefront does things right. Well, mostly a thing or two. Homefront is a really really mediocre game. It doesn't have any magnificient plot. It doesn't have original, revolutionary gameplay mechanics. But it does have style. And that's enough to cover the worse things with the game behind a well designed and stylized environment.Homefront deserves a spot of some sort among the FPS genre. It's nothing great. And part of it may be in the way developers treated the game. You can see the partial laziness and the lack of trust on their product made them lose interest in the game and went with the basic idea of every FPS game nowadays; "Let's make another one of these" was their motivation to even make Homefront.Homefront is certainly worth buying if you are in need of a short yet stylized single-player FPS game. Even with it's mediocre gameplay it still manages to entertain for hours with it's challenging Achievements.For more recommendations and reviews on our favourite up and coming quality games follow Lot's O Giveaway's group curations here!

content:
Posted: May 28, 2013
												Let me first try to explain why it was that I wanted to play Homefront.  Firstly it was the first game that I could remember that brought the fight to American soil and wasn't based on factual past battles or wars.  Here was a new idea, a new war as it were, and it was America defending its land.  Rather than America attacking on someone else’s, which is all too often the case.  The second reason was that the story they chose seems almost feasible.  The “Future History” trailer that was released told a great story that felt like it could happen.  It was a great mix of a new idea in uncharted territory with a hint of possibility.The first thing that I noticed was the graphics, they were gorgeous.  I spend so much time playing older games that I am, for all intents and purposes, a few years behind on the graphics.  This games not that much different since its already a year and a half old.  The game started with my being taken from my home and placed on a bus to an unknown destination.  The drive down the street was eye opening to the world I had entered.  It was some time after the Korean occupation and everything was about what you would expect.  There were some moments that I thought were funny, and others that I knew were there just for my shock value.It was shortly after that moment that I had fully removed the rose tinted glasses.  I came back to the game the next day, after playing for about a hour the previous night.  This time all bets were off and everything was on the table.Cut to four hours later as I watched the ending credits scroll up my screen using all of my will not to drop a huge F-bomb in front of my child.Terrible, simply horrid and a waste of my time.  I have so many other games I could have spent that time with.  And to have the single player of a game that originally was retailing at $49.99 is ridiculous.  Even its current price of $9.99 seems a bit much for the size of its single player.  It took me longer to beat the first Portal that it did Homefront.Nothing about Homefront stands out above the crowd, hell nothing about it outside its story is unique in any way.  I remember reading once that Homefront was inspired by Half-Life 2, and its guerrilla warfare.  Its clear that it was simply a handful of moments in the later moments of the game and nothing else from Half-Life 2.  Especially nothing about its ground breaking story, graphics, anything.  That’s about the same as saying that Bust-a-Move was inspired by Pong.  In other words, they say they are inspired by an already well known great game and hope more people will buy their game.There was also mention of using real companies and logos in the locations.  It was stated to give it the real feel of these locations.  I guess this is true, but I saw it more as; “Lets stick some advertising into the game to make more money!”There was a moment where I realized that I hadn’t seen any health, and in fact had no clue how much I had.  There was no HUD element with health nor had I seen any heath packs or med kits, not even a single bottle of pills.  It was after this realization that I noticed that as I would take damage the HUD would kind of darken, and once I took cover and stopped getting hit the screen would normalize.  Ah regenerative healing.  I don’t know how I feel about this, but on first use I’m not a fan.  Maybe its just Homefront, but it seems like it made the game too easy.  The only weapon I was even remotely concerned with was rocket launchers.{SPOILERS]The overall story was acceptable, but left much to be desired.  There were parts however that I found annoying and unexplained.  For example there is a level where you have to sneak into this outpost/base thing controlled by a bunch of crazy survivalist.  When we arrive the other members of  my party make mention that they don’t know these people but one member of the party did, but he’s now dead.  The crazy survivalist turn on us, what a surprise, and we have to sneak into the place and steal their helicopter.  Now once this part happens we head to the church to steal the copter.  But how the hell does this Connor♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥even know here the church is?  When the level starts he states he’s never been here, and now he knows his way around?  I call bull.Another thing, again with the great Connor, was at the end of the game.  First we ignore the fact that the US Army let use join them on their attack of the Golden Gate Bridge.  Because I refuse to believe that part.  But then, right before the last climactic moments of battle, this Connor idiot gives a little speech and ORDERS THE SOLDIERS AROUND.  Seriously, this guy is telling the army guys what to do.  By this point I had pretty much given up on the game, but when that happened I knew right then and there.  I knew that once I was done, I wouldn't be playing it again.To make things worse, the whole game you are being yelled at to do this, do that, go here, shoot him.  Just constantly being told what to do, and that gets real old, real quick.  And maybe coming off a game like Far Cry 2 has me a little skewed in my views/opinions.  But I can’t remember any other FPS that was similar to this.  This game is a rail short of being a rail-shooter.  Its really that poorly made, its really that bad.The story has no real ending.  And to make things worse, the guy that annoyed the crap out of me since the beginning of the game martyrs himself at the end.  Yea, Connor, that idiot.  I was more than happy to hit him with that air strike, but it was a really stupid moment overall.  Because why would they need a guy on the ground to use a laptop to fire an airstrike from a helicopter doing circles over the bridge target?  Why?And all the cliches where present in Homefront.  The story was pretty predictable on a few occasions, and at times the sheer number of Korean soldiers was just laughable.  Possibly the worst TF2 trade I’ve ever made, and I seriously doubt that I will ever touch that game again.

content:
Posted: February 19
HomefrontOverall Score: 5.5/10Short Summary:The storyline in this game is basic - Year is 2027 (2 years after Korean-American war), Korean military troops plan to occupy thecity. A group of american resistance fighters join togather in order to eliminate all Korean troops and retake the city.Estimated gameplay hours: 4-6.Pros & Cons:+Storyline - I guess the storyline kept me playing this game until the end to see what will happen.+Missions - I would give a positive point for the missions. [helicopter / sniping / destroying vehicles & other].-Gameplay - Basic FPS shooter really didn't find anything that made me play this game with excitement.-Graphics - The game looks alive and the atmosphere & surroundings suits well with the storyline, but can't ignore how bad the game is optimized.-Acting & Sound - Zero feel for the characters (mumbling characters), but if the game was remastered for example, it could've been different.-Animations - Not good both for enemy a.i and characters (allies / npc).Enjoyment: (6/10) - Lack of fun in killing enemies.Repetetive: (4/10)Replayability (0/10) - Hell no.Frustraiton (5/10) - Dialogue between the characters.Boredom (2/10) - Action didn't stop I would give them that.Conclusion:I expected a better experience from this game (I can say it's the opposite of Medal Of Honor in terms of graphics, gameplay execution and the feeling it gives you while playing it).I would say better skip this game and play Homefront Revolution, but I do recommend this game on sale if you want to give it a go or well, if you have some extra time to play a medicore fps military game.Overall Score: 5.5/10* Skip it.** Not Recommended.*** Give It A Try.**** Recommended On Sale.****** Recommended On Full Price.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												I wanted to like this game, I really did. And since I'm sure you see alot of that in reviews let me at least explain why.I did play this game back on xbox and when I saw it for dirt cheap I got pretty excited because in my foggy memory I remember having a bit of fun on this game and kept thinking to myself that it was just  a demo I played somewhere since it didn't seem like I had played to much into before I had to end, so of course I wanted to play it again/full game.Apparently the "demo" I thought I had played was actually the full game. Don't believe me? Look at my playtime and achievements, I already beat it (more on this later).I don't want to rip this game a new hole because in honesty there are good points.+Tons of weapons! When you start fighting hordes of enemies there could be ranging from 2 different guns to about 15 which allow unique firefights.+Great story line (We'll look more at this later.) I love "alternate universe" storylines where what-if's become the "this actually happened". Its really neat because it throws you into a world you don't recognize and forces you to try to grasp at things that just aren't there anymore.+Achievements! yay! (this is a personal preference in games. I like working towards something extra in games, not really a necessity for buying this game...)So yeah some things were good, but throughout the game I found myself frusterated with it. Things I don't remember being frusterated with when I played it on xbox.Why? Well, simply put, this game is not optimized for pc. Yesyes #pcmasterrace whatever, but this game was made for consoles like the xbox and ps, that is obvious. Keybindings are weird, moving and looking obviously needed a controller, aiming/shooting/running,crouching; pretty much anything that requires specific actions and attention are lacking.IE: Shooting down the sights..., dear god the sight aiming... (I won't even discuss sniping because it was better to shoot from the hip with them more than half the time). So You look down the sights, line up a head shot, or even a bloody body shot. 10m away, easy right? hahah yeah no. You could potentially (AND I DID) end up wasting a full clip(s) trying to shoot this one npc. It was beautifully disgusting.- x50; Ai. Stupidest ai since... erm... Sims? Yes, the sims. You know, the little imaginary people you get to control and can't figure out how to not drown in a kiddie pool once you take out their ladder, or are starving because they are tired and tired because they are starving? Yes them. THAT is your ai friends, who shoot at walls, corner you so you can't continue (ie:fallout, you know what I mean), and just are generally the most ridiculous things ever.Also, they are whiney as hell and keep yelling the same thing over and over like they have one script for the area you are in. Next area? Cool they'll say something new! Over, and over, and over again; while shooting at a wall.The enemy ai? Well, they have unlimited ammo (and yours is scarce, go figure), so not much different with them. OH, except for will direct ALL attention to you as soon as you enter the area, even if you haven't shot anything or looked at them or done anything to attract attention (including sneaking into the area and hiding behind crates. Be prepared for unlimited grenades to be thrown at you.)I can talk about damage and how you need a "few" head shots to kill a basic enemy with a m16 (decent gun in the game fyi), but with their little subs they can put you down in seconds flat, even if you can't see them, THEY SEE YOU >.> Oh and they like throwing grenades at you; not just the enemies but your friendlies too. Always a good time when they throw grenades at you, while you're searching for hidden things, when no enemies are around, while yelling at you to hurry up every 2 seconds. **ALMOST DONE I SWEAR****Caution there will be slight spoilers ahead**Storyline? I really like the idea, but I already told you that. And by the stuff I just told you, you can imagine I died close to 200 times, easily. So with load times, getting food because food is comforting when I'm distraught, eating said food instead of moving along in the game, and actually playing the game; LOOK AT MY PLAY TIME. The game is beat. donezo. I played on normal because usually my first playthrough I want it a little easier challenge but moreso for storyline, if I go back for another playthrough I go harder (easy is like, no. Not happening, ever). SO, with that I'm concluding to you that this game is way to short. And its not even like they finished the storyline! There was so much potential like meeting "The voice of freedom" or battling to washington, ect. This comes in to where I said I had thought I played the demo and then nope? Well, after the "final" chapter I was like ooooo whats next!?! GOD, DAMN, CREDITS thats what. I was mortified. There was no conclusion (good or bad or anything), its an open ended game which is cool if you want to write fanfiction for it (pl0x don't), but there was nothing! Even the final voice of freedom announcement could have led to the next mission. I'm just, UGH. I liked the gameplay, as ridiculously not good as it was for pc. I liked the storyline, as whiney and stupid the ai were and how short it was. But, really, I'm sticking with this and DO NOT recommend this. If you don't feel the same then thats ok, but I just can't bring myself to actually hit the thumbs up in this review... This game disappointed me. IF you want to feel the horror I did when playing this emotional roller coaster, then I advise you to grab it yourself when you see it DIRT♥♥♥♥♥CHEAP on sale. **Caution have comfot food (pizza) at the ready**~~Sorry, quick edit here for you~~This is just for single-player campaign, I will re-edit this when I bring myself to do multiplayer (its still a thing right?). Thank-you.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												No way could I recommend this game, especially now. I've played it, I've beaten the single player campaign, and it's the most generic shooter story ever with generic dystopian american underdog setting against North Korea (?!?). There's generic stereotype characters such as voiceless protagonist, and a compassionate rebel vs ruthless rebel dynamic. Even generic grab at your heart string moments. All under a generic, on-rails, brainless 4 hour run and gun play style where all the guns are accurate enough for head shots, so just take a big light machine gun and maybe a weapon of choice as you grind through less than 10 levels worth of enemies, all while you comprehend why they played up that you're a pilot and you only pilot an aircraft for a single level.I do believe Homefront's single player experience was supposed to be bigger and more dynamic, but clearly development time had butchered the story into what it is today. With multiplayer reportedly dead, I'd hardly see any point to buying this game for it's single player alone.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2012
												It's quite decent. Not sure why this game gets the bad rap that it often does. The campaign, although a bit on the short side (7 missions, though they are beefy-sized) is very fun and adrenaline-packed. The premise for the story is original, but the progression of it is kind of bland and the characters aren't very interesting, besides a certain war machine you get to wreak some delicious havoc with a few times (if that can constitute a character). The guns are fun to use and sexy as hell. They feel like, say, a mixture of Call of Duty's and Killzone's guns. The multiplayer is very well-done too, but the active servers are a bit on the short side.Overall, I'd say this game is a little underrated and didn't get the attention it deserved, despite it having a few weakspots. I had to play it on minimum graphics settings and the lowest resolution (800x600) because I had a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC, and I still had a great time with it. It's definitely worth at least a rental/borrow.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2012
												From what I've read, the general consensus on Homefront is that it's just average. After finally getting around to finishing it, I think the reviewers may have sold it a tad short. I mean, I wouldn't call it a masterpiece, but I also found very little wrong with it. I guess the biggest issue is that the single player (which is all I cared about) only took 4-5 hours to finish. So while it definitely wasn't worth the original asking price, now that it's only $20, it may not be a bad investment if you have ever had any interest in playing it. As far as the gameplay goes, it's pretty standard for a modern shooter. Mostly you shoot people (duh), but some levels mix it up with vehicle sections and other types of mechanics. The final level is also pretty epic. What sets Homefront apart from most shooters is the story, the premise being an alternate future where North Korea has occupied the US. All in all, it's a decent, but short game. Perfect for FPS fans to kill time on a rainy afternoon.

Posted: February 18, 2015
												Excellent, awesome, emotional opening sequence. Good campaign. Great graphics. Shooting mechanics work well, but doesn't feel as tight as some other FPS games (though you can adjust sensitivity for ADS seperately from overall sensitivity). I haven't played MP-so no comments on that, (don't know if people even still play), other than its got your typical game modes you'd find in FPS (CTF, Domination, TDM). Campaign is about 2/3 of a Call of Duty campaign, but more original (North Korean invasion instead of Russian ultranationalists as the bad guys for 3+ installments that we see in COD). I was much more invested in the story in this game than almost any other game I've played. The emotional aspect really hits "home" (especially if you consider yourself a US patriot).Excellent game to play in conjunction with watching the Australian movie Tomorrow, When the War BeganDEFINITELY BUY IT ON SALE, & prepare for the next installment of Homefront: The Revolution, coming 2015.

Posted: December 7, 2011
												A great multiplayer game that was ahead of its competition at its time of release. Sadly gamers these days prefer to cannibalize franchises until they are rotten to the core, leaving games that come out under the wrong banner, to die in the sidewalk.First off if you are thinking of buying this for the single player then don't. It's in tune with other war-themed sp campaigns out there: i.e bad. So what makes this game great? Big, detailed maps. Point based perks + killstreaks to ensure balance. Most killstreaks are skill triggered/manual. Vehicles. Guns feel solid, movement is smooth and gunplay is fast. Battle commander mode is a nice twist on regular game modes. You are given all the right tools to battle both camping and vehicle-stomps/ the game is not easy to cheese or grief. Teamwork is on the lukewarm side as you can lone-wolf if you want. All in all if you want a mp game that plays like a CoD-flavored battlefield then there's nothing that beats this at the moment

Posted: March 16, 2011
												Short but fun campaign with kick♥♥♥♥♥multiplayer that doesn't rely make you rely on twitch shooting. Although it does help in a bind.

Posted: March 7, 2015
												I only played the single player on the game so just a few comments on the game.  Single player is incredibly short but also very fun.  With the backstory to the game there probably could have been a lot more added but even with what little campaing there was it was very enjoyable.The story was great in my opinion.  Not the typical you are a military super soldier and you go to whatever country and kill a bunch of terrorists.  No you are fighting for the USA that's been invaded by a united North/South Korea.  The story worked for me because of the setting and enviroment that the Devs created.  There was some incredibly gruesome scenes as well a touch of realism as people are going to do what they feel is best for their survival and it wasn't just everyone against the invaders.Loved the setting and enviroments that you play through in the game.  Some of the areas are semi generic cover based shooting but some of the locations do evoke some sense of feeling in the game whether pity or anger at whats happening.  The only complaint is that as a FPS the areas are very linear and would have been nice to explore some of them a little more freely maybe open up more paths to achieve the goal.The game also varied the pacing in the levels for the most part as well.  In some levels it was a constant frenzy of action while others were a little slower with small burts of action to break up the tension.  Again it worked for me because if it was just all 100% constant action shooting every enemy you came across it would get bland fast.  Good deal of weapons in the game, mostly automatic weapons, would have been nice to get some more variety in pistol/shotguns or other weapons instead of just from dozens of different assult rifles.  I also liked that there wasn't just a ton of ammo laying around everywhere to collect.  I was switching between a variety of weapons to keep my ammo up as when I'd get a new weapon there wasn't always ammo for it and I'd be on the lookout for me next weapon or playing a little more conservatively to make what ammo I had count.Only complaint would be that the character model gets caught up on really odd pieces of terrain and you can't tell if you should be able to get past an area or not.  Sometimes there looks to be a path but you get caught on something.

												A solid game worth getting, especially when it goes on sale! Is still played online so you can enjoy it 100%

Posted: February 18, 2015
												Homefront is one of the most underrated games of all time!The story in this game is short but amazing!The gameplay is really fun!The graphics are still good!I can't wait for the sequel!

Posted: June 15, 2016
												This is the voice of freedom.You will constantly hear this phrase being uttered throughout the cutscenes of Homefront. It does make you sort of feel like you are fighting for a cause, which I think works well for the game.Story: Homefront's story is easily the best part of the game. The game is set in a dystopian world in the year 2027. North Korea has taken over the United States and you, Robert Jacobs, a former U.S. Marine Corps helicopter pilot is part of the Resistance who are trying to regain control of the country. You team up with other characters such as Boone, Connor and Rianna. I honestly feel that each of these characters are annoying. They are one-dimensional and offer nothing better to say than cliched phrases or cheesy dialogue. Although the plot of the game is interesting it ends quite abruptly and I felt like that could be due to time constraints and as a result, the campaign is quite short (clocks in at 3.5-4 hours).Graphics: The visuals of the game are decent for a game released in 2011. When the game released, I heard many complaints about how the games graphics were poor and looked like a PS2 game. On normal graphics settings, the game looks as good as Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 with sharp character textures, beautiful lighting and detailed environments.Sound: Each gun sounded different, with a unique pop to each of them. The characters although annoying, were not bland to listen to and each voice actor did well with the script that was given to them. Gameplay: The gameplay is fast, fluid and fun. Homefront's gameplay draws alot of inspiration from the Call of Duty series and has done well to emulate it's feel. Each gun handles differently and are a joy to use.Overall, Homefront is a decent FPS game. It's story isn't spectacular by any means and the gameplay is what you would expect in games such as Call of Duty. The campaign is short but sweet and I'd only recommend a purchase if this game is on sale.7/10.

Posted: December 31, 2014
												This game follows too far in the footsteps of Call of Duty's on-rails action. Too. Far. E.g., Instructed to snipe a buttdong once I have him in my sights, I immediately take the shot: I am detected, the mission is failed and I restart from the nearest checkpoint. I get to the same moment and wait--wait for this stupid flippin' NPC telling me what to do to finish his stupid flippin' sentence so this stupid flippin' game tells me I can take the shot--the same silenced, undetectable shot--without failing the stupid flippin' mission.Design like this in the shadow of this entire game, nearly beginning to end. The introduction is great, but the gameplay feels like you're kinda floating around in space, struggling to follow NPCs' instructions from one White Castle to next advertisement.I can't, however, decide if whether or not I regret playing it....

Posted: February 19, 2015
												Cool game. Violent, epic storyline, good voice acting, crazy cinematic action scenes. This isn't normally the type of game I'd be into but I love action games in general. It has regenerating health (at least on Easy) but it's still quite difficult. At least to me. If you die though you just reload to your last checkpoint. There were a few areas where I had to reload several times, because you're always outnumbered, you can only take a few hits, and the enemies are very good shots. You have to use cover, flank, and play smart. Easy mode is about as tough as Saints Row 3/4 on Normal or Hard. But it's cool, I really like it!Unfortunately the multiplayer is PVP only. No co-op vs. AI or bots. That's too bad because the gameplay is really good. Vehicles, good shooting mechanics, you can crouch or lay down, and the graphics are amazing. I can't tell the difference between the graphics in this game and titles that came out in 2014 or 2015.If you're looking for a really cool singleplayer campaign experience, this is a good one. My only gripes are that it's an FPS, which isn't my favorite genre, there's no FOV slider, and there's no co-op multiplayer.

Most killstreaks are skill triggered/manual. Vehicles. Guns feel solid, movement is smooth and gunplay is fast. Battle commander mode is a nice twist on regular game modes. You are given all the right tools to battle both camping and vehicle-stomps/ the game is not easy to cheese or grief. Teamwork is on the lukewarm side as you can lone-wolf if you want. All in all if you want a mp game that plays like a CoD-flavored battlefield then there's nothing that beats this at the moment

Posted: February 23, 2015
												I think this game is very underrated. It has got a great story (with a great backstory involved), good shooting, nice environments (even though sometimes it's rather gritty) and overall I think it's a enjoyable game. The only thing that I think it could do somewhat better is the characters, you don't really care that much about them... and the developers really tried to create those "sad moments" where someone dies and you get somewhat emotional, the problem is that with no emotional connection, you don't really get that emotional when that happens.Then there's the multiplayer. It's mostly a copy of Call of Duty's multiplayer with the only difference being that you can call in vehicles for you to operate. One nice thing though - it's still somewhat active. But stay away from the CHEAT SERVER!Well, Kaos Studios really outdone themselves with Homefront. Their first (and only other) game was Frontlines: Fuel of War and that game was 100% garbage.Looking forward to the sequel - Homefront: The Revolution. It's going to be great.

Posted: August 9, 2015
												Well. Homefront wasn't actually terrible. It wasn't very good either though.Lets start with the flaws. For starters, the campaign is notably short and can be beaten in about 4 hours, which includes dying a number of times. The plot is basically Call of Duty: Red Dawn, but a lot less military based and a bit more guerilla warfare based. Basically, it's not very unique. The context is that in 2013, after the Supreme Leader of North Korea dies, his son unites the North and South to form the Greater Korean Republic. This should be the biggest clue that Homefront is purely speculative fiction and not to be taken seriously as that will never happen. The South (South Korea) had seperated from North Korea just as the Korean war started because of the atrocities that were going on. Anyway, fast forward to 2025, the GKP is a world power and has already taken over four other countries and begins their invasion of the USA. Another two years later, it's 2027 and you are Robert Jacobs, a former Marine combat pilot who is awakes in his beat apartment in Montrose, Colorado. The Koreans have seized the town and are sending you to Alaska for "re-education". Well, as you can assume, you're rescued by the resistance and recruited to help fight the good fight. That's pretty much it. There's little development in character or tone, it's just very one sided. At least Call of Duty (everything since Modern Warfare)  gave the villains a sort of character to help build up their wrongdoings. You don't even get to know the Koreans, they're just targets for all of you.SPOILERS: There is one level where there might be some shift in tone, but it ends up being a massive firefight anyway. American survivalists; those nut jobs who like to keep their guns close in case something like this would ever happen, which won't. It won't ever happen. But people like the people in this game do exist. In one of the missions, these survivalists have a helicopter you need and basically you end up killing them all.Well, at least the audio design and graphics were nice. The campaign was still fun to play, but it's nothing special. More of thing where you play it just to pass the time and you only own it because it was in a THQ Humble Bundle or it was on sale for like 3 bucks.7/10

Posted: August 30, 2016
												This is essentially one of the better FPS's of it's time as it were. It was as good as Call of Duty. I thoroughly enjoyed Homefront, although I cannot say the same about the it's sequal. Not that I have played it. It just doesn't leave off from the first game which angers me. Anyhow, I have played this on the PS3 and it was awesome. I got it again on the PC because I wanted to relive it. Relive shooting North Korean soldiers. This game has been out for years now and I'm going to spoil the beginning for you because it sets you in the mood to have no sympathy for the North Koreans.Homefront is set in a dystopic United States, in the year 2027. The game's backstory dates back to the 2010s, where there are high tensions between North Korea and the global powers due to the country's military aggression, including its successful nuclear weapons test and the sinking of a South Korean ship. That's from the wiki anyhow. But you start as Robert Jacobs who is a former U.S. Marine Corps helicopter pilot. North Korean guards bust into your apartment and drag you away on an awating bus to be sent to a "re-education" camp in Alaska. As the bus starts and starts heading out of the city, you look around as people around you are also being taken away, shot and killed, or just trying to get by. The beginning is a part that gets me the most and will ultimatly show as the North Koreans and plain ruthless m0therfu ckers and if you already didn't hate them now. You'll hate them even more. (Y'all can skip this if you want) You come upto an intersection, looking to your left are two people begging for their life as their child, not much more than atleast 4 or 5 years old is standing behind them. As they beg for their life, the two North Korean guards shoot them, killing them and walk off as you hear the now orphaned child scream and cry as he walks upto his dead parents. And boy did that ever♥♥♥♥♥♥me the h311 off. What happened next is a flat nosed semi truck T-bones the bus, killing almost everyone on the bus (there weren't that many to begin with, just a couple guards and prisoners.) except you and a guard. A couple of resistance fighters board the now upside down bus and hands you a gun and off you go on a series of missions to try and get some fuel tankers to the U.S. Army held up in San Fransisco as your primary mission. Ladies and Gentlemen. My review may not do this game justice, but this game is 100% pure bada$$. The sounds are awesome, you have a nice array of weapons, there's enough explosions to make Michael Bay ♥♥♥♥♥♥, many people may not play it's multi-player anymore but who cares? You'll have enough fun slaughtering North Koreans as you fight your way through many other resistance fighters. You will love this game, trust me. You will. And if you don't. Then I have no words other than you just can't appreciate a good game such as this. ♥♥♥♥ the sequal. It doesn't do this games justice. But trust me, you'll like it.

Posted: February 10
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Homefront is a first person action game developed by KAOS Studios and published by the now defunct studio, THQ. Homefront tells the story of a resistance movement fighting back against a near future Korean occupation of the USAThe game play is a very generic FPS. Graphics wise, it looks nice, but you can tell the game was released in 2011, it looks better than most games released, however it shows it's age when comparing it to more recent titles. The graphical options are wide varyingAll the maps in the single player are very well designed, sadly you can't really explore because you are constantly reminded to keep following your squad leader. You fight through various different environments such as the streets of suburbs, department stores, and baseball fields, all of which show a disturbing outcome of the quite scary "what if?" scenario from a Korean invasionThe single player of Homefront will take about five hours to complete; this is pretty short and the game ends on a massive cliff hanger, I would of liked to have seen another two or three more missions to tire up the loose ends in the story. Multiplayer is still very much alive in Homefront, I have only played in a couple of games but I had no problem finding a map full of people to jump intoI would like to recommend Homefront; however I would wait till it is on sale, which would be an absolute bargain if you could get it for that again in an upcoming sale RECOMMENDED :)

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												Wow, I'm impressed! Homefront exceeded every expectation I had and then some. So glad I bought it on a whim when it randomly went on sale.This is the game I can imagine would be born if Half-Life 2 and Spec Ops: The Line had a baby together. If you've played both of those and then you play this I think you'll instantly be able to tell why.Mechanically, it's pretty much the same as every other shooter. The guns and enemies are pretty standard. The guns themselves have a lot of variety but most of the rifles feel so similar that it doesn't really matter. I found myself choosing which to use more based on which scope was attached than any other attribute. The enemies could have used some more variety and better AI, but in the end the game didn't hinge on either of these things.What matters is the story and the world they created. It's a distopian future where you sometimes fight alongside a squad of NPCs and a robot companion against a foreign occupying force (that's the Half-Life 2 part). But they did such a good job presenting this world I'm in awe. There are tiny touches everywhere: things happening in the background, banter that's easy to miss, all these really human moments that make the game come alive. Because of that it felt a lot like The Last of Us during the early levels.Stylistically it's a bit dated even for 2011 game - honestly it looks a lot like Half-Life 2. The models and textures have a pretty flat look to them, and none of the shininess that a lot of games from the era seem to have everywhere. The lighting and depth of field effects are amazing at points though, even if the game were made today. They're subtle but effective. The backgrounds are often pure works of art.The sound system is crisp and includes great voice acting. The score is epic and memorable and features some hilarious yet appropriate tracks from real life bands.Overall I loved playing through it twice (once on the highest difficulty and once for collectibles and achievements). I only wish that there were bots for the multiplayer so that I could try it out, as there are literally zero people online nowadays.I'm psyched that there's a sequel in development. Seriously can't wait to get back into this world. Here's a trailer: 


YouTube™ Video: Homefront 2 The Revolution Trailer (PS4/Xbox One) 

			Views: 948,477		

			Homefront 2 The Revolution Trailer (PS4/Xbox One) Wage guerrilla warfare and reclaim the streets of Philadelphia in "Homefront: The Revolution" -- a captivating new free roam FPS to be co-published...		

With grand setpieces and an emotional, evocative story, Homefront is not a game to be missed.

												Ok, so I played this game on console back when it was released, I borrowed it of a mate, completed the campaign, and gave it back.I thought it was good and worth a play, so when I saw it for <£3 I decided to pick it up on steam.Now, as I replayed the campaign, I started to remember just how much I enjoyed playing it the first time, and the same can be said for now, despite being a bit short, (Though still think it is longer than most of the Call of Duty campaigns), it is brilliant, dark and rather unsettling at points.Now one thing I never played before was the multiplayer, and I know people are saying the MP is dead, but they are WRONG.There is usually only 1 or 2 servers playing, but so what, there are people coming in and out of the servers constantly so there are usually anywhere between 24-36 player online at once, and that is more than enough for me to of played about 6 hours of online in 2 days.The online has some bad points, such as few weapons, (5 Assault rifles, 2 SMG's, 2 LMG's and 2 Sniper rifles) and low player count. But this is very minor, I have enjoyed playing the MP, using drones and vehicles alongside infantry, and the vehicles are surprisingly well balanced, maybe excluding the helicoptors, but they are aggrivating to pilot which means unless your truely skilled at piloting then your going to struggle getting kills.The graphics are good, the gameplay is good, the game is great.I only wish I had bought this when it first came out on Steam, so I could play in different servers with more players.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2011
												First I have to get this out of the way, the single player game sucks! I think that Kaos put the focus on multi-player and it shows in a brilliant execution.The maps offer something different on every change up, which will entice you to want to change weapon classes as the scenery changes. i.e shotgun in the supermarket aisles or sitting on top of the hoover damn with a sniper rifle. The battlepoint system is a great switch from the popular "killstreak system" and offers even mediocre players a chance to take out the big vehicles and airstrikes etc at least once a match if they save the points. The drones add a totally new dimension to the standard FPS format (having to watch the skies as well as the horizon), and the overall feel to game play is absolutely unique .The weapon balancing is perfect (not on all servers) and the vehicle physhics are well done. (again not on all servers weapon balance and expert vehicle control are admin options) Overall this is the best military FPS I've played yet.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												<!-- Updated Review -->Initial Thoughts & ObservationsI'll begin by acknowledging that the length of this game is very short. I would say that there's about 7 Chapters in the game, and each chapter varies in length. Gameplay & MechanicsThere is a low amount of complexity to the game overall, and it's fairly linear as to what you can do, and when you can do it. I was constantly finding myself having to wait for NPC_1 or NPC_2 to get to a location before I was able to complete an action. There were situations where I would know where the NPC was going, but because I walked there before the time I was supposed to be there, the NPC would be stuck in an animation where they would never complete the action. Story & PlotOne are that left a lot to be desired would have to be the story. I wouldn't say the story was bad, but I will say that it would have been connected better. To me, it felt as though you went from one scenario to the next too quick, and without any real explanation to why you are doing this, going there, or meeting them. The story has the ability to be high production, but because of the inability to connect each chapter seemlessly, you don't really understand the story itself, but instead understand the overall premise, which is that you're rebelling against invaders.Weapons & CustomizationThere's not many weapons to choose from, I would guess about 12, and you will probably constantly find yourself choosing between 3 of them throughout the game, minus a couple chapters. The struggle that I found myself in a lot was when I would find a weapon I liked a lot, particularly the SCAR, but ammo would be fairly scarce. Now this is not the case in all levels, but seldom did I encount enemies had SCARs versus the other handful of guns in the game, so some chapters force you to pick up a weapon that you might not like. There are different weapon skins that you can see, but it's not something that you get to choose, instead an enemy may have a gun, and when you pick it up, it might have camo, or even a different color. There's a few attachments in the game, such as different scopes to use, as well as magazine sizes, but again that's randomly generated based on what enemy had it.Graphics & Level DesignGraphically, the game isn't too bad considering when it came out. As far as level design in concerned, I feel the game borrows a lot from games like Call of Duty. It seems very cookie-cutter, but that doesn't mean it's a bad thing. It makes it a very familiar experience, but in it's own unique way. The beginning levels aren't very innovative, but as you progress midway through the game, it does add different varieties of gameplay.Final Thoughts & ConclusionThis was not a very groundbreaking game, and most people will probably feel the game seemed rushed. Having said that, I still found myself satisfied playing it. It's a FPS, that does exactly that. It's not trying to innovate in any areas, but is very reminescent of older FPS games. I wouldn't say this is a everyday shooter however, I would categorize this more as a casual FPS fore those looking to just play something quick. I would still recommend this game for any who generally loves FPS games, and who's interested in something that doesn't need heavy investment. I wouldn't necessarily pay full price for the game, but if you can find a deal on it, or for a reasonable price, I think it's worth picking up.<!-- Original Review -->To start off, I will say that this game is extremely short. As in, you can probably beat it in under 2 hours. Having said that, I enjoyed the game quite a bit. The game isn't too complex like your modern day shooters now, in fact it's really limited to what weapons there are to use, and where you can go. It's extremely linear in the sense that you have to wait for your teammates to finish their action before you can proceed. I would say there's about 12 total guns that you can use, and you really only get to use 3 of them for most of the game. I wouldn't say the story was entirely bad, but it wasn't something that pulled me in. For me, it felt like any other FPS, nothing really groundbreaking, but was satisfying as well. Regardless of it's flaws, I still found myself having a lot of fun progressing through the campaign. I wouldn't say it's a great buy for full price, but if you can find it for reasonably cheap, it's a good game that's quick, and offers fun for those who generally love FPS games.

												Idea is nice but Freedom Fighters published in 2003 did everything better. Homefront is full of invisible walls and every step feels scripted. If you go 10 meters away from the mission you get killed by invisible enemy in a hail of bullets. NPC are not memorable and plot is boring. NPC are blocking your way all the time and you have to do everything in correct order. Try to go ladders before npc, no chance. There could have been potential but this game is just poor man's Call Of Duty, I bought it from sale and for 4€ price it's okay game. Lot of action and different guns that make game playable. I would say 2/5.

Posted: July 4, 2011
												Playing this game makes me angry.Angry that I paid any amount of money for the privilege of suffering through it. Angry that I went to the effort of obtaining it from an American friend when I heard they were (initially) blocking it on Steam in the UK, due to an amazingly stupid deal THQ struck up with high-street game retailers for (initial) exclusitivity. Angry that it's Baby's First Call Of Duty Clone. Angry that its heavy-handed message is either too transparent or lost in the mud. Angry that it's STILL a buggy piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ with frequent graphical lockups and dialogue going waaaay out of synch with the animations. And finally, angry that I've had to wait until now to warn everyone about this anti-game, once again due to it not existing in the UK Steam Store until the deal expired.I'm almost disgusted that Valve gave it pride of place in the 4th Of July art for the Steam Summer Camp event. Only CoD fanatics could love this monument to everything wrong with modern 'AAA' FPSes.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Although I tend to be easily exited about games, even if other players do not like them, this isn't the case for Homefront. I did not like this game. Pros:- Rianna, one of you team mates, is beautiful- Nice Setting on the Golden Gate Bridge during the final battle. It seemed to me like the developers kind of wanted to copy the bridge level from Half-Life 2 but failed to get it as epic.- Multiplayer is still active. I just played a quick game for 20 minutes and there were 19 people in the session. Not bad for a four year old game with moderate receptionCons:- very short campaign- got stuck many times in the middle of the action because I quickly wanted to move out of the line of fire but a chair or a tiny step kept me from moving- The game didn't start at first. This was related to physX issues. It took me a while to read the forums and experimenting to get the game working. Many players complain about this problem.- Extremely linear. Usually I do not mind if a game is linear but in this game you may not even crawl under a fence or climb a ladder or open a door before the other players entered first.- Too much talking. It's OK during the first play through but starts to suck if you replay levels. And you can't skip it.- Poor voice acting, except for Rianna, at least in GermanI do not recommend this game, even on sale.

Posted: February 10, 2015
												I picked up Homefront from the $5 bin in Walmart knowing that the game was old and that it didn't receive much praise. I do agree that the story was a bit too short at only about five hours long. I still enjoyed the story based on its premise. With the USA being so high and mighty recently it is nice to see it being a hollow broken shell of itself. The look and feel of the game's atmosphere was very Red Dawn (the original 1980s movie) to me. Most of the characters where one dimensional and shallow but they do their jobs well. The game play is well complaint and works but parts of the game are very hand holding and scripted.  With a sequel on the horizon it will be interesting to see what happens with this well thought out but not quite well executed world.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2013
												This is not an instant classic, there is no innovative game mechanics, no hi-end graphics and there's even no challengeful multiplayer. But this game has something that makes you want to play it at least once, but from start to finish: great story and atmosphere. If you're a fan of Cold War setting, this one is definetly for you. This game (made with the help of John Milius, writer and director of original "Red Dawn" movie) offers you to take a look on a near-future world where Great Korean Republic had invaded USA, and this look is pretty believable, enjoying and even fascinating. The sctructure of narrative grabs you right from the start and you will see this homeland war not as a guest but as a participant. It's just an interactive remake of "Red Dawn", and I should say, it's a great remake.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												Underrated but still underwhelming, Homefront is a game that shows glimpses of promise and has tons of potential, but never fully delivers on what it could be.Homefront is a first-person shooter set in America during a fictional future in which a coalition of East Asian countries, namely Korea, control vast portions of the country. You play as a former military pilot who is rescued by an underground resistance unit fighting the occupation, with the eventual objective of assisting the scattered remnants of the U.S. military in San Francisco.While the graphics are undoubtedly dated, the gunplay here is solid, and the game shows you glimpses of this fictional America that could make for an amazing game had they been expanded upon more. Labor camps, fringe societies outside the influence of the Koreans, the resistance fighters or the U.S. government, and so many more areas that could have been expanded upon but never were.The multiplayer was underrated in its heyday but unfortunately is no longer populated and isn't really worth talking about.Since you are basically going to get this for the campaign alone, which is VERY short (3 hours on normal), you should only pick this up at a deep discount.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												Homefront is a stunningly bland, unexiting, derivative first person shooter which rips off Red Dawn but is somehow even less convincing and without any of its charm. It's gun play is mediocre. Its level design is boring, simplistic and painfully linear. It holds the players hand in an iron vice and refuses to allow any freedom. In one sequence you have to follow the instructions of your NPC commander to thin out a group of enemies. You are told exactly which enemy to shoot and when to shoot them. Deviation from this triggers a fail state. On top of all this the story is awful. It can't decide whether to be a macho action movie or a dark and gritty morally grey war story. The characters the story follows are universally paper thin and completely uninteresting. Normally when I spend five hours on a shooter I feel cheated, this time I wished it had finished sooner.Apparently the multiplayer was fantastic, but since it's dead that shouldn't influence your purchasing decision.

												This game is outstanding, in your face, awesome storytelling with non stop action all the way through. I found myself thoroughly engaged in the world. I had an absolute blast playing it. The online mode is comparable to other online FPS gems like CSGO. There is nothing like standing on top of a white castle sniping people who are running around the Hooters next door.The story mode took me somewhere between 6 and 8 hours to complete. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												As an idle diversion this was alright. If you're bored and it's on sale and you just wanna mindlessly destroy enemies, go for it.If you're going for something for story content, innovative gameplay or a new experience I'd suggest running away as fast as you can.I bought this title on sale for five dollars US, for five bucks I'd say it was worth it, I enjoyed it *JUST* enough to warrant it. For full price? I'd probably be pretty mad I bought it.My take on things:The Story:The story's background is so impossible you'd be more likely to encounter Santa astride a Unicorn than the scenario depicted in this game.The characters are tired stereotypes and overacted, sometimes hilarious so.The writers seemed to really want me to have an emotional response to this game and the events in it. If their goal was annoying me, they succeeded. If the intent was making me feel something for their poorly written characters they utterly failed.It was also extremely predictable, so many moments meant to be surprising weren't in the slightest.The Gameplay:It's a retextured Call of Duty, and it somehow managed to actually be worse than call of duty. This includes the "shocking" moments and first-person moments of your character being tossed about and blown around.It works off the exact same mechanics as Call of Duty, enemies endlessly spawn until the player advances to a certain point.All engagements play out almost exactly the same and get exceptionally boring.There's a complete lack of bullet penetration, shooting at an enemy behind plywood or a plastic traffic pylon results in absolutely nothing.I can recall years ago when this game was coming out a trailer touting that "this game will be different" and something close to "we won't have you killing hordes of enemies, we want to avoid kill-fatigue in games like Call of Duty where you just kill people on automatic and don't even think about it after a certain point". It was a blatant lie, I'd be hard pressed to point out a game with more generic enemies packed into small areas than this one.At the end of the day I've played worse, but not many.If you want a game wherein America is the one getting invaded and you don't mind an RTS I'd highly suggest World in Conflict as a viable and fun alternative. Much better writing, much more plausible story.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												 If you like short reviews....then let me just say that 'Homefront' is one of the most disappointing games that I've ever played. If you want to stick around for a bit while I elaborate....then here goes. While the 'Red Dawn' inspired story isn't too bad....the gameplay is super generic. Trust me....everything that this games does....has been done before and done much better. Basically you follow a squad of extremely broken A.I. soldiers and I mean that literally. There will be plenty of times where you can't proceed until your numbskull teammates kick in a door....climb a ladder....or crawl underneath a fence. Sometimes....the person that you are supposed to be following....won't even budge. The guy will just sit there like he is writing his name in his own♥♥♥♥♥♥and you have no choice but to restart from a checkpoint. That's right....I said checkpoint. This game doesn't believe in saving....but that doesn't mean that you shouldn't. You should all save your money and spend it on a game that doesn't feature a rail sequence....where you shoot rockets at trucks....that are actually pretty rocket resistant. Seriously....that sequence is probably one of the worst levels in the history of gaming. Moving on....the graphics are actually quite good....aside from the few occasions where some of your teammates will radiate a glow like they drank the finest water that Chernobyl has to offer. The weapon selection is decent....and you can switch between two firearms at any given time. The controls are fairly responsive....when you are not flying a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥helicopter....that handles worse than a three-legged horse and buggy. Multiplayer is there....but not there at the same time....since nobody actually participates in it anymore. The game has numerous achievements....but I for one am not planning on spending any more time slogging through the kind of game that treats you alright one second....and then turns on you by slapping you in the face....and forcing you to pay for it's own rehab.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												First off I know that this is a very late review but i have to warn people NOT to get this game. Reason? (TL;DR at bottom, also ignore time played steam didn't even record down anything)Well to put it frankly the single player is boring, like really boring. It's your normal mordern FPS on the rail shooter. The game is slowed down by how many time you have to stop and wait for your NPC teammates to come and help you kick down a door. If you're not American the game becomes really really stale listening to American patrioism over and over again in the cutscene and how "we" must free ourselves how america is great and so on. It gets boring, and yes we know war is bad, the enemies are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and so on and so forth.BUT what really prompted me to write this review was how bad the gameplay was, in the starting it was smooth and quite alright. Then you see these heavily armour enemies go down in a few shots (First bad point) I mean ok fine throw more guys at me.Then you have your "Allies" being not very helpful, pushing you out of cover shooting you if you ever walk to the left a bit, listening to them repeat the same 3 sentences again and again when there's nothing you can do but slowly clear them while they're being obstructive (Second bad point, if you didn't know).The thing that got to me most was not the very linear gameplay, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI, or how most of the enemy AI is weak AF. What got to me was (WARNING A LITTLE SPOILER) one part of the game where you fight this lightly equppied enemies, they wear tee shirts and baggy pants with NO armour whatsoever, and you take half your magazine to kill one.... HEAVILY ARMOURED TROOPS go down in 3-6 bullets but UNARMOURED THUGS go down after you're almost out of rounds. YAY LOGIC.And that was the final straw for me, i'm still gonna complete it though (Last mission after all) but i really can't in good conscience recommend this garbage to anyone.TL;DRGameplay is bland, AI is♥♥♥♥♥♥ Story makes me want to kill myself, Voice acting is bad, and people are giving this a good review because MURICA
