content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Homefront is nothing more than a boring but thankfully short shooting gallery. The premise of the game is actually quite good and is probably the only saving grace of the game. If you are a fan of Red Dawn than you will be extremely dissapointed as this game has a pretty decent premise but terrible execution. The story is terrible with shallow characters that will leave you with no emotional attatchment at all. Homefront tries to be a serious game but it ultimately fails . Even in its most "emotional" moments you really wont feel sorry for anyone. The graphics are extremely dated. Textures look terrible especially on bigger levels and the same 4 North Korean enemies are recycled throughout the game. Your allies also look extremely bad and are usually blank faced or have some ridiculous stare that was meant to show the intensity of the battle but ends up just making the player laugh. The guns are also pretty bad looking and their sounds are god awful. The voice acting is sub par as well. One of the bigger faults of this game is that it is extremely boring. The game basically boils down to killing a mass of enemies before going and pushing a switch or blowing something up. After the task is complete you run around for a bit more and to it again. Homefront is also extremely easy. The game offers no challenge on medium difficulty. I died about 3-4 times during my run of the whole campaign and that was only because I tried to "rambo" it a couple of times. The only ridiculous mechanic that offers even the slightest challenge is the fact that enemies are ♥♥♥♥ing sharpshooters that can hit you from across the map when they see just a sliver of your shoulder. But even with this just proning behind cover every once in a while will do the trick. This game is also extremely short. I finished the 7 chapters of the campaign in a mere 3.4 hours. That is ridiculous and should not be acceptable by any means even if the game has a good story.  Those 3,4 hours were extremel tedious and painfull. By the end of the game you are just relieved that the nightmare is almost over then Homefront decides to give you one last ♥♥♥♥♥slap across the face by sequel baiting and leaving a cliffhanger. ♥♥♥♥ off at least we deserved a proper ending but nooooo. Dont go near this ♥♥♥♥ing awful game. TLDR: Everything about homefront is terrible and you would get more enjoyment out of a cup of coffee than this game. Its not worth $19.99 and its not even worth $4.99 when its on sale. Dont touch it. Forget about it. Burn it with fire. Please run before its too late.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												SINGLEPLAYERHomefront is an alright game, but I do not recommend it due to the fact that it has more cons than pros. The story is alright. But has quite a few plotholes in it. The first couple minutes though, really shows you some of the depressing things in the world of Homefront and they are actually pretty well done. The enemy AI is alright but your teammate AI is honestly pretty bad at least from my experience. Graphics are gritty looking and ugly, but the gun models, people other than important characters and dead bodies are weirdly good looking compared to the rest of the game. Especially the guns, seriously, they look REALLY good. Non of the characters are really all that likable and you play as a silent character (Which is a gripe that some people have with certain games. I for one don't mind silent characters if they are properly done, however, in Homefront it adds plotholes. Looking through iron sights is a toggle rather than a hold (You can't change it in settings). There are A LOT of invisible walls. This game is extremely linear. There are invisible walls in places where you would think it makes sense to go. When you're in calm areas where you can interact with people you move at a snails pace. Like, REALLY slow. For the most part the game is boring but it kinda ramps up when you're halfway through the campaign, especially with the last level which in my opinion is the best part of the campaign. When you're in areas with team AI, you have to wait for them to reach the end of the level for you to proceed to another area (It's probably a way that the devs made to load the next level). Also it's really easy for you to die, at least for me (Difficulty is a preference but even on easy the enemy AI were pretty unforgiving).Oh and the campaign is 4 hours long. Shorter, depending on how you play (I died a lot).Overall, I don't recommend this game. There are too many cons with this game and not enough pros. I thought almost the entire game was really boring other than the last hour or so. If you want to dive into the world of Homefront you might as well wait for the sequel, Homefront: The Revolution which is an open world game that fixes all the problems I have it this game. But if you want to, get this game when it's on sale.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												This game felt unfinished. For starters, the campaign is all of 3 hours long. And a large chunk of that 3 hours is you twiddling your thumbs waiting for the next highly scripted segment of gameplay to trigger because you as the player can't do much of anything alone. Despite supposedly being an important key figure in the rebellion (which never gets explained, not that much does), you are led by the hand the entire time and trusted to do nothing on your own. You are treated like an incompetent child. You have zero player agency. You can't even climb a ladder until the game gives you a button prompt. The game literally thinks that you are too stupid to perform even the most basic functions without instruction. I don't mind linear games, but this game is so linear that it makes the Call Of Duty franchise look like a series of expansive open world games with great player freedom. The game also suffers from horrific collision detection problems as well as physX issues, leading to many silly deaths and flat out broken sections of gameplay. The story also makes no sense, has terrible pacing, as you would expect from a 3 hour campaign, and is tonally all over the place. It has it's moments of fun, it isn't all bad, but the good moments are rare and aren’t nearly good enough to compensate for how dull and infuriating the experience is for the other 75% of the time. In all honesty, I wouldn't recommend this game at any price.   Here is my full in-depth review

content:
Posted: January 20, 2013
												Well... how to resume that poor Call of Duty clone as fast as possible... easy!PROS:+The "WHAT-IF" occupation of America scenario is interesting.+Decent graphics (DX11)+Crouch, prone positions (it is rare that you have the possibility to prone in modern FPS).+Soundtrack is decent+Multiplayer mode has potential, if that's your bag!CONS:-Improbable silly story. Koreans invading not only USA but many other countries? C'mon!-Campaign playtime is VERY short (3-5 hours top, depending of difficulty level)-Scripted like hell. Lots of enemies running at you until you kill that specific RPG soldier so they stop spawning!-Lots of "invisible walls"... and door blocking lockers until lifted up by NPC.-Your running speed is like my grandpa walking speed.-Collectibles are annoying to search as your prompted from NPC's to carry on and move on to next objective.OVERALL:That is about all that come's to mind for now and if you are slightly interested in Homefront, buy it only at a decent deal. Besides, there are plenty of wargames alternatives.RECOMMENDATION:I only recommend this game for wargames purists, that always want some more wargame and can't seem to fill their shooting needs.RATING: 5.0 / 10

content:
Posted: February 16
												Homefront is a FPS with a short campaign and a dead multiplayer. It takes place in a scenario where Korea is united and occupies the US. You might ask how? The game answers the question with supposedly superior technology, but it never shows it. The Korean towers are the only new thing the Koreans seem to bring to the fight, but with the obvious weakness at the outside, it doesn't really help to explain anything. + It looks great+ It tried to show some memorable moments. Well, at least tried.+ There are civilians+ Lots of different American rifles I love to use- Koreans apparently also often use American weapons. Thus, many weapons felt too smiliar.- You are constalty accompanied by some resistance fighters- Why is Connor leading the squad? He is nuts and annoying.- It's too short. You might need 3-5h to finish the campaign.- Plot doesn't explain how United Korea is able to occupy the US.- too linear- The memorable scenes didn't really work.The game shows potential, but it just falls short. There are better alternatives than this. But if you really want to play it, get it on a sale.Replay value: Average (too linear, nothing really special nor memorable)Rating: 5.5/10Recommendation: No

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												Homefront was a strange experience.I was huge into Team Fortress 2 at the time and they were giving away a copy of Metro 2033 and a hat for the Soldier class aa a pre-purchase bonus so I figured why not? It turns out I got more mileage out of the Genuine hat than either game I got out of that deal.One has to look at the media blitz surrounding this game as an indicator that when you have people dress up as the antagonists of the game at gaming conventions and events and releasing hundreds of balloons over the Golden Gate Bridge to promote it you have to wonder if the developer is putting too many of their eggs in the basket. If you can, go look up the review PlayitBogart did of Rise of the Robots to get the gist of what I'm saying.To the game itself now.Homefront was not a hot mess; it played just fine and controlled like a modern FPS should despite all the difficulties I had adjusting to the keyboard and mouse after playing shooters on consoles for almost seven years prior. A lot of the high points of the game came in the first half of the campaign showcasing the cruelty of the North Koreans by having things such as piles of dead Americans being buried en masse in a baseball field or a childs parents being shot in right in front of you as you are transported on a bus. They even briefly touched on one of your companions facing racism due to the fact he was half-Korean. Surely some attempts to invoke emotion were expected in a game touching on this subject matter....That's about the end of the positives however. Looking back I disliked this game for the lack of content it had and all the glaring flaws in how it tried to do what it did. For starters, all the main characters played out as pure sterotypes which for the purpose of this review I will refer to them as Jarhead, Girl, Target of Racism (TOR), and Father Figure.You escape from a bus and turn into Dothis McPlotdrive III as you try to meet up with Jarhead's friends to try and fight back against the Koreans who were somehow able to unite almost all of East Asia and occupy an economically crippled United States. Is your immersion broken yet? Don't worry, I was somehow able to care less about the characters in this game by the end of it all. Jarhead and Girl argue constantly as you are led through the war torn suburbs to a hidden oasis where the resistance has set up a self-sufficient hide-a-way led by Father Figure.You are then led through a night mission where you are bombarded by advertisments for actual real world companies and establishments to the point where you actualy have to fight your way through a Tiger Direct store and pass by a Hooters. I wish I was kidding. This was a design choice by the developers to try and increase the immersion but astute gamers will see this as a disturbing trend where fiction and reality break down. The same thing happened when I noticed real world ads would start appearing on billboards in Saints Row 2; it takes me out of the game and reminds me the crappy real world exists.You go through American held lands with TOR to do something in the cornfields. I think it was to find a helicopter to escort some fuel trucks for the military to use to fight against the Koreans. The game just spirals down into oblivion after this.The whole premise of the game is laughable at best anyway. You expect me to believe a small nation that refuses to feed it's populace would just somehow take over it's neighbors and confront the only real Superpower on the planet? Would this make more sense if the antagonists were Chinese as was originally planned? A change that was made because the devs were afraid of a people who are notorious for breaking copyright law like it's nothing and banning anything that portrays their nation in a bad light?The worst problem I had with this game was the fact it was obvious sequel bait. When you finally get to the climax of the game you expect to confront the main bad guy that they built up all game to, only to be blue-balled by "We are finally turning this war around" before the credits roll.There was no follow-up until recently with Homefront: The Revolution serving as a reboot of the series, effectively making this game pointless story wise. But hopefully developers look at it as a lesson of how much high expectations can sink a company. Kaos Studios was shuttered shortly after release and according to Wikipedia shares of THQ declined by almost a quarter, ultimately leading to the demise of THQ.Multiplayer was also a strange mix of Battlefield and Counter-strike where you fought in tug of war style battles and earned credits to purchase weapons, armor, vehicles and the like. In retrospect, it wasn't unique enough for me to continue trying to do better. I just went back to TF2 shortly after with my Genuine Hachimaki.I could only recommend this at a steep discount or as a video playthrough. Aside from that, you didn't miss much.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												As generic as they come, Homefront is a game for lovers of the point-and-shoot variety. The story wants to be as poignant as Spec Ops: The Line. The gameplay wants to be as solid as the Call of Duty series. The visuals want to be like Battlefield 3. Unfortunately, all of those aspects fall incredible short of their ideals. The voice acting is surprisingly strong, but it completely undermined by the utterly dumb AI. Friendly NPCs block you from cover, exposing you to enemy fire. Enemies are very predictable. Difficulty is only ramped up by adding more enemies to the screen. There are a few shining moments of cinematic brilliance, like when you are first escorted as a prisoner through a typical American suburb taken over by the brutal Korean forces, but all of that great storytelling is destroyed by blocky NPC models and outdated textures. I can't speak for the multiplayer as I only played the single-player.I give this game a 4/10. It's not worth the $20 price tag, but if you pick it up from a Humble Bundle or on sale, it might be worth the measly ~4 hours it takes to complete the single-player campaign.Pros: Superb Voice ActingGreat Cinematic Moments and StorytellingCons:Outdated GraphicsClunky GameplayFrustrating NPCsDumb Enemies

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												OK while it lasted.  It took me five hours to complete the game and I tend to take my time.  Not that you really get a chance to do that in this game.  It is basically non-stop action while it lasts.  If you like that you will like the game.  The story and characters do not leave any impression.  Just there to move the action along.Overall, I would say do not buy unless you get it for a couple bucks or in a bundle for cheap.  The game is short.  There is zero replay value.  It is on rails which is slightly noticable in say COD but very noticible in this title.  There are a bunch of irratating things I would blame on poor programming.  Such as getting entangled with your AI support, not moving because their is some object you can not see but is seemingly too high for you to walk over, AI enemies fire and explosions affecting  only you, etc.  At one point I was waiting for my AI team to open a door so we could move forward but we were stuck for some reason.  I spent a few minutes running around trying to see if there was something needed that I missed.  It turns out, the AI engineer guy was stuck on something outside and I had to walk into him a few times to free him and then he joined us at the door inside and we moved forward.So, not the worst but no where near the best.

												I wouldn't imagine a game built so strongly around Republican fantasises would be so eager to take away my guns. Awkward weapon changes happen every scene, and the main character can't carry more than 90 rounds for any one rifle, and none of the ammo is compatible with the fancy guns you'll occasionally pick up. The action is mediocre, the plot is perhaps more interesting than I would have guessed. The interaction with NPC squadmates is hamfisted, and most of the characters are unlikable. I do have to give it credit for not being as racist or terrible as I had expected. Bonus points for the TigerDirect product placement. You probably already own this game as part of a THQ bundle pack. Otherwise, I wouldn't buy it.

												I was going to make a list of games less linear than Homefront, but since I started with "Bowling," I decided that was going to be too long of a list.The general rule of the game is that if you didn't get a prompt onscreen to do something, or weren't specifically told to do something by another character, it's not the right thing to do. You don't need to worry about that though, since if it's not exactly what the game just told you to do, it's not going to allow you to do it. Invisible walls are everywhere, and don't ever try to walk ahead of a scripted character or the game will stop until you get back where it told you to be.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2013
												I wouldn't imagine a game built so strongly around Republican fantasises would be so eager to take away my guns. Awkward weapon changes happen every scene, and the main character can't carry more than 90 rounds for any one rifle, and none of the ammo is compatible with the fancy guns you'll occasionally pick up. The action is mediocre, the plot is perhaps more interesting than I would have guessed. The interaction with NPC squadmates is hamfisted, and most of the characters are unlikable. I do have to give it credit for not being as racist or terrible as I had expected. Bonus points for the TigerDirect product placement. You probably already own this game as part of a THQ bundle pack. Otherwise, I wouldn't buy it.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												So i bought this game years ago, it wouldn't launch on Server 2012 R2, and I finally got around to running Win 10 and decided to give it a try. Ignoring what a bad FPS it is, how bland the story is, the poor graphics on the higest setting, it still manages to have negative SLI scaling so many years after launch. On a GTX 980 it gets about 30 fps on the higest setting with AA turned off, with SLI its 10-20 fps with constant stuttering. And even wrose (or perhaps a redeeming factor) is that single player campaign is maybe 3 or 4 hours long. I'm not even sure how I have 12 hours played, I can only assume it crashed years ago and steam still thought it was running. Its not even worth $5.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												When you decide to look away from the broken menus and the rather.. Questionable theme of the entire game, then it opens up to what feels like a very, very, very long tutorial. Every level feels like a tutorial, every objective feels arbitrary and pointless, and even when you try and freshen things up by doing something even vaguely interesting, like not crawling from cover to cover, but actually fight the enemies, you are immediately punished for it. These punishments come in the form of invisble walls, or enemies immediately dropping anything they have in their hands to all target you.Other than these issues, the game likes to throw overly long 'interactive' cutscenes at you, no doubt hoping to force you into loving it's cardboard cutout characters. As soon as you start up level 2, you're actually stuck for about 20 minutes waiting for NPC's to carry out their scripted conversations of absolutely no consequence, with your objective being 'Follow'. If you want a good shooter, don't pick this. The gameplay is 'meh' while you're forced to spend way too long on doing absolutely nothing but watching men milk goats, and listen to people talking about nothing at all.3/7

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												The year is 2027. The world as we know it is unraveling after fifteen years of economic meltdown and widespread global conflict over dwindling natural resources.


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Homefront' 

			Views: 31		

			LOVE MUSIC? - GRAB SOME GREAT MUSIC HERE: http://paradisedecay.bandcamp.com/ I take a quick look @ 'Homefront' The year is 2027.		

 A once proud America has fallen, her infrastructure shattered and military in disarray. Crippled by a devastating EMP strike, the USA is powerless to resist the ever expanding occupation of a savage, nuclear armed Greater Korean Republic. Abandoned by her former allies, the United States is a bleak landscape of walled towns and abandoned suburbs. This is a police state where high school stadiums have become detention centers, and shopping malls shelter armored attack vehicles. A once-free people are now prisoners… or collaborators… or revolutionaries. Join the Resistance, stand united and fight for freedom against an overwhelming military force in Homefront’s gripping single player campaign penned by John Milius (Apocalypse Now, Red Dawn). Stand alongside a cast of memorable characters as an emotional plot unfolds in this terrifyingly plausible near-future world. Experience visceral, cinematic first-person shooter action as you fight your way across Occupied USA using guerrilla tactics, and commandeer military vehicles and advanced drone technology to defeat the enemy.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I wanted to like this game... This is a review of the campaign. I can say this: The graphics are good, it runs well, the story is believable (almost), and it's certainly action packed, full of big explosions. But sadly it's let down by far too many things for me to reccomend it:First and foremost is that I feel so bored after completing the campaign that the very idea of even trying multiplayer makes me feel like I should do something more productive with my time... Pull a lump of wax out of my ear, pick my nose, or scratch my nuts or something...  You just play "follow the leader" for 90% of the campaign. Deviating from the leaders course is unrewarding/pointless, and in some cases causes the mission to restart.4 hours to complete, and the first 3 hours was at best: "meh". The final hour of gameplay I was sort of starting to enjoy it. Stockholm syndrome maybe. Then it was over.Lacklustre animations, people sliding sideways without their feet moving, or running but not going anywhere (enemy soldier stuck at the top of the stairs for instance), wheels on vehicles that turn too slowly for the speed the vehicle is moving at...Special effects from two different games: explosions and the resulting fireballs look brilliant. Get stuck in an area where most of the scenery is on fire though and it's a different story... Running through a burning shop I noticed "fires" that looked like they came straight out of a game from 15 years ago.Ambient occlusion? Turn it off, it looks like lego land smoke on everything that gets close to another surface. Turning it off didn't make a noticeable difference to the general look of the game, but did get rid of the horrible blocky smoke around everything.All the guns handle the same with nothing to distinguish them besides the scope stuck on top (of which you can choose 3 varieties of acog scope, and 3 varieties of red dot sight). Whether it be an SMG, LMG or assault rifle; recoil is non existant (with the exception of the two sniper rifles, but they auto center after each shot making the recoil pretty much pointless on them).There's a heli flying section in the game that is absolutely dire, it shouldn't be in the game at all but part of the story is you're a heli pilot... Unfortunately whoever designed the heli section of the game had absolutely no idea of what a helicopter actually is... You basically fly a magical hovering cannon that can bounce off everything, including cliffs, trucks, enemy tanks etc. You can point the nose of the heli at the ground and not go anywhere...Then there's bugs, invisible walls, not being able to walk through certain doors when they're open because you have to wait for the NPCs to go through first and that sort of rubbish.Friendly NPCs who are totally invincible, soaking up hundreds of rounds of ammo and eating a few grenades to boot without so much as stumbling.The stealth sections are atrocious, and the AI is pretty much non existant. My first warning of this was when I nearly tripped over an enemy soldier after running upstairs, but he didn't notice me because apparenlty he was stone deaf and for some reason was inspecting the paintwork on a door by pressing his nose against it... I couldn't shoot him, I couldn't even raise my gun (maybe your character pitied the simple minded fool or something). Then a friendly npc walks up behind him, chatting casually, and strangles him in 1 second flat.She then looks all sad before saying "It never gets any easier". I dunno love, that vulcan nerve pinch shiz you just pulled on that soldier looked pretty damn easy to me.The sad truth is it literally couldn't be any easier: You can literally walk around in the open in broad daylight and they won't notice you unless you are directly in front of them.One time a friendly NPC (yeah, same one) went to kill a guard, in plain view of 3 other guards and a couple of prisoners, they didn't even blink. I shot someone on a tower with a silenced sniper rifle and the mission ended because I took the shot 2 seconds before I was told to. 2nd attempt, friendly NPC goes to kill the guard, I hide behind a tractor with my team until I'm told to take the shot, mission ended for no apparent reason. 3rd attempt, I stood in front of the tractor in the open between the friendly NPC and the 3 guards who don't care about their friend being choked to death behind me. Still standing in front of them I shoot the guy in the tower. Nobody cares, the mission is allowed to go on.It doesn't feel like it's finished. BF3 in beta was a more polished experience than this tripe. Though you can see the influences of other games, the one that really stands out is CoD. This game tries so hard to be CoD, that it's almost as bad as a CoD game. CoD and Half Life had a baby, CoD smothered the baby. Half Life decided that things weren't working out and scarpered, but then CoD decided to keep and raise the afterbirth. Homefront, the mouldy placenta of FPS games is a casual shooter. Are you a casual? If you've read this far I doubt it. If you're really desperate for another generic CoD clone this might keep you entertained briefly... If you want a game that has real substance and lasting replayability, look elsewhere because this is duller than dishwater.TLDR: Yet another generic, run of the mill CoD clone that was a chore to play... If you've got 4 hours to waste and it's 75% off, do yourself a favour and still don't buy it. Unless you're a CoD fanboy, in which case you'll probably love it. Sad, deluded fool that you are.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2011
												Starting off with the obvious flaws this game has: The singleplayer campaign is short , it is plagued with in-game advertising for many early sections, many of the animations are stuttery, and a lot of the combat feels like a generic COD clone.That being said, this game does have it's merits. The concept of itself is both brilliantly created and masterfully implimented as the story, like "Freedom Fighters" shows a conflict outside of the generic us vs arabs conflict, and puts the war on american soil in the defensive. The explanation is deep and intricate, and in many ways almost feasible, but even there isn't where this game truly shines.The game juxtapositions the ideals of two of your partners, emotional vs mechanical, against each other in a way that makes the player question his actions. It also forces him to experience the backlash of "heroic actions" as negative effects most games leave out. Consequences for actions is a recurrant theme, and is artfully displayed within.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												Bad plot devices due to bad writing meets poor programing and clunky controls. Oh and bad voiceover acting too. Let's recap the first hour for me. Get rescued from concentration camp by insurgent forces, got through hell to get away...have to wait for AI to open every single door, because they have the majic kick the door in ability.Get stuck on wall, because I walked into it. Reload checkpoint...move forward.Hail of gunfire yet I can here screaming childGrenade magically appears next to me, die. Lose ability to walk at normal pace so that I can hear about the insurgent camp. regain when devs are through boring me. Bounce off open door, open staircase and several othe invisible objects until my team goes ahead of me through them. Devs must be implying that my character has a stong sense of the "...last out" mentality.Connor has moment of hatred against invading army, does something stupid while giving a b-movie voice over. Grenade magically appears next to me, die.Magically teleport several feet forward upon reload. Apparantly dying=progress in this game.Grenade magically appears next to me, die.Lose ability to walk or use weapon so that female can slit the throat of enemy gaurd convieniently staring at an exit door...to a balcony with no stairs. Apparently what the devs are saying is that a female could only kill the dumbest guard in history. How sexist. It would apear that they also have a shakey understanding of firecodes.Grenade magically appears next to me, die.Blow the living daylights out of enemy forces using Goliath targeting system. Experience is enjoyable exept that each time I use its targeting system it jumps into my pocket and puts a gun into my hands. Multiple targets ensure the joy of repeatedly pressing the 4 key to bring it back up for use..this creates palpable tension.Several grenades appear around me. Whilst I try to run away Connor jumps in front of me...no through me. So that I can shield the team from the blast of grenade with my crotch. The plan worked, I die, but Connor lives on.Buy the game for one reasone (when it is on mega sale of course) it's so bad that it is actually fun to make fun of.

The POV is like everyone is at least one head taller than "me".• The story.I've read the multiplayer-part of this game is decent, but beeing almost a pure single player I can't judge. For SPs like me I can not recommend this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Homefront Review (Spoiler Free)(Story)In the near future, global crises force countries to make aggressive decisions about their survival.  North Korea ends up coming out on top and once it solidifies its presence in Europe and Asia, it turns to North America.  The NK's invade from the West and life becomes hell for the average U.S. citizen.  You play a member of the resistance movement and are quickly hurled into the fight to break the NK's hold on the U.S.(Gameplay)Homefront is an FPS with rechargeable health, much like COD4.  There is no cover system though you can peak and lean once you aim down sights.  You can carry several weapons plus equipment and pick up weapons on the ground.  Most of the time you will be doing on-foot shooting however there are a few land and air vehicular segments.  You will usually fight with a team of resistance members, though do not expect much in terms AI competency.  Enemies on the other hand show average to below average intelligence.  Other than a few set moments, it's one shooting gallery after another, just at various times of day.  My favorite moment in the game is when you are given the ability to direct an unmanned rover and use it to clear your way through a neighborhood.  Most will complete the game in under three (that's right, 3) hours making this game a hard sell, especially with stronger competitors out there.  Multiplayer tries to mimic Battlefield style gameplay with vehicles, gadgets, and large maps but there are not many people except fans playing anymore.    (Design)The game looks and sounds decent.  As others have said, the opening sequence sets the stage for an epic game.  There are many good looking set piece moments, but they are marred by short levels and average gameplay.  Dialogue feels okay though nothing is worth quoting.(Final Comments)I believe the multiplayer component of this game was the primary focus during its creation.  Unfortunately it could not compete with Battlefield and instead, players are left with an average single player.  With a short campaign experience devoid of replayability and a relatively empty multiplayer, I do not recommend Homefront.  Hopefully the sequel fares better.

Although the multiplayer is dead, if it's cheap enough, the campaign MIGHT be worth it to you. As PC Gamer's Andy Chalk so accurately put it - this is essentially the video game equivalent of Sharknado - if that's your thing, go ahead and take a look. Otherwise stay clear.-on the plus side however, the sequel looks to be an entirely different genre of shooter. One that it looks like I could enjoy-

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Soooo...Homefront, homefront. This is kinda an odd game to speak, I mean it's not a very good game but nor is it bad. Originally as many recall this game was developed by THQ before they went bankrupt, after which they sold the rights to the developers of Crysis and the game was back on steam (after the companus bankrupcy it was removed from steam for some odd reason)So, Homefront takes place in the far future where the leader of North Korea is dead, his son took over and somehow managed to unify the North and South Korea (wishful thinking much?), then they somehow take over Japan and China. While this is going on the US is being kicked around like a Juarez ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, going bankrupt and losing it's major wars in the middle east (Oh hey, George Bushes worst dream came true, America no longer having a big♥♥♥♥♥♥, being hit by a deadly bird flu an etc. All this leaves America crippled and North Korea rolls in an takes ground, an it's up to the glorious resistance to save America an all it's Apple pie/Burger king eating citizens from the evil Korean cooking.Now, if you read trough this synopsis and haven't blown your brains out, then congrats you're the small part of us squishy humans that likes using their brain thingies. Yes, this script reads like something a basement dwelling paranoid whackjob would write and then put on youtube, because it is. The script for this game was writen by John Millius, the same clown who wrote Red Dawn -frankly, you'd think after THAT stink burger someone would take away his writing pen-, and he pretty much brings the same jingoism here as he did in Red Dawn. To make it short, in Miliuse's eyes anyone who isn't American is apperantly a equivilent of a Nazi, because as in Red Dawn, the Koreans in this game do everything except twirlling moustache's or having swastikas. It's clear they are trying to make you hate these guys with every cheap way possible, which just comes off as juvenile and laughable (or maybe I really don't care 'cause I'm not American an the plot to this game is seven layer cakes of stupid)Anyway, let's forget the stupid plot and speak about the gameplay itself. Aaaan...there isn't much to say really, the game is your standart Modern Military shooter, if you played enough CoD you pretty much got this in the bag. The game can be clocked out in four hours tops (if you don't die that often) and after that there's an abrupt end for the upcoming sequel (which I honestly wanna see, it kinda seems more promising than this game.) The weapons are standart, the characters are all bland as hell, you are silent and actually don't have the ability to open doors for some unknow reason.Honestly, I'd say the real best part of this game is the multiplayer itself. It has 32 players limit, it def feels more like a Bad Company 2 or something Battlefield esque, rather than CoD arena/twitch reflexes shooting. There's some fun maps and mods, and it really feels like you're on a battle.Now, can I recommend this game?  Well, I'd say you should only buy it on sales and just for the multiplayer itself, because the single player isn't really worth it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												tl;dr: A bunch of great ideas with poor execution: the game. This game isn't really worth the $20 asking price. Campaign is three hours long on a good day, and the mulitplayer is a bland, unpopulated experience. For the same price you can buy battlefield 3 or 4 on Origin, which outclass this game in just about every aspect. Don't waste your time here.What it does right: I was hyped as hell when this first showed up, and the amount of advertisement and weird♥♥♥♥♥♥they did at E3 that year really made me want to buy it. The setting is a great idea. I wish more shooters would stray away from the modern military shooter that we're so used to by now and do things like this. However, when the reviews started coming out I'd figure I'd try it once it dropped in price... four years later.The mechanics work, I guess. It's nothing special, other than maybe getting to use the Goliath to shoot rockets at enemies that are giving you a hard time. None of the guns feel bad to use, and they have a good amount of punch on enemies, but at the same time they do feel kinda flimsy. For a shooter that came out in 2011, it works. It's nothing special but it's not like the mechanics of the game are terrible.A few of the set pieces were pretty cool, but those were a mix between laughable and alright. None of it felt particularly epic, but again, it served its purpose.What it does wrong: Oh boy where to start. I guess we can start with the singleplayer. It's overly linear. I don't mean the good kind of linear like Metro 2033 or Killzone. I mean straight out of call of duty corridoor nose-leading. If you go in any direction other than which one the game wants you to go, you'll run face first into an invisible wall. It doesn't matter if you just passed through that open door ten seconds ago, you go one way and one way only. And you can tell the designating fighting zones from the talking corridors by the random stacks of chest-high cover littered around. It's painfully obvious that this game doesn't really want you to go out on your own or do anything other than move from cover to cover shooting bad guys. There is no variety to any of it.The graphics also haven't aged well. I don't think they were even that great at the time. I think Half Life 2 looks better and it came out seven years before. The color scheme is bland and uninteresting, and you can't interact with anything other than picking up guns. Even your teammates have to open doors for you like this was a ps2 ww2 shooter.The campaign is, in its entirety, maybe three hours long if you stop to look at the scenery once in a while. I beat it in two and a half. It isn't even a good three hours either. I was actually kinda thankful it wasn't longer, otherwise I might not have gotten through it. None of your npc companions are even remotely interesting and they don't bother to characterize any of them beyond very basic traits. You have no reason to be invested in any of it, as they just sling you into the action three minutes into it with barely any explanation. This doesn't change the further you get into it, either. Only after following these rebels for an hour and a half or so do they finally tell me in the form of an off-hand comment that they needed me to fly a helicopter for them. You think they would have taken the time to brief the pilot on that important detail, or at least asked if he could fly a helicopter and wasn't just a jet pilot or something. The most motivation you get is the objective marker. No overall reason behind it, or important motive, just follow the arrow. Sure, I want to liberate the home of the free just as much as anyone, but blindly following the first couple of idiots that almost kill me in a car crash doesn't seem like it's the most solid of motivations.And another thing, I'm getting really tired of silent protagonists. It worked in games like Dead Space because Isaac was completely alone, and didn't need to talk to anyone most of the time, but here? There are usually three other people that need to be interacted with in combat situations. Games like Far Cry 3 and Spec Ops: The Line have completely destroyed the notion that video game protagonists are better silent. I have no interest in Jacobs like I did Jason. Being invested in your character as a person goes a long way into being better invested in the game overall. This game did nothing towards this and ended up being bland and forgettable.One last little rant before I get to the multiplayer: North Korea? Really? The only reason anyone ever gives them any respect is because they're allies with China. Never would a tiny, economically weak nation like North Korea ever be able to hold as much land as we are led to believe, or be able to invade and occupy the nation with the world's strongest military, even while under economic collapse.  The logistics of such things are simply impossible for North Korea, even if they did have the military size they say they do, which is most likely a lie. As much as I give battlefield 4's singleplayer♥♥♥♥♥♥ it at least had a believable scenario. Plus North Korean soldiers using Colt, Bushmaster, and Kriss USA firearms (All American-based firearm companies if you didn't know)? Did they even bother to do any research into this matter? Now for the Multiplayer: They tried to add some unique features like battlepoints to build up like killstreaks, using this money to spawn into vehicles and use special weapons. I like this better than cod's killstreak system, since it allows you to buy things even if you're not doing that well, but I still don't like it that much. First, just about every class gets a rocket launcher, and you can buy it after one kill. This is not good game design. Vehicles are pretty much useless beyond a quick kill or two if you find a group of enemies that knows what they're doing. Vehicles are pretty much instant kills on infantry too, so that's annoying, and you can't even use environmental ques to tell where they are like you might in battlefield, where you might hear it coming or see it firing on the minimap. I think it did show up on the minimap, but I never saw it before one killed me.It's got the standard setup for multiplayer unlocking systems. Get kills and unlock guns. I didn't play enough to unlock anything, but I never felt like using anything other than the first class was really necessary. I didn't see much variety in the enemies either, but then again the killcam gives you absolutely no information other than where the person who killed you was at. Since just about every class gets a rocket launcher, and sniping is pretty pointless on smaller maps imo, there didn't seem to be much variety to be had. I played a few games and there wasn't much exciting going on. The maps are too big for there to be large chunks of action, and I doubt that's ever going to change with the player counts as they are. Other games do everything so much better. Overall, this game is nothing but all of the stereotypical elements of first person shooters from 2011. It seems like a lazy attempt to pull away customers from cod's fanbase, and even then, it doesn't do anything better than call of duty, it just imitates it in a different setting. If this game had come out on the ps2 seven years before, then I think it might have been a lot better received. As it is now, that's kinda what it feels like: a generic ww2 shooter from the ps2 made for a later generation. There's nothing special about it other than its setting. The multiplayer is bland, the singleplayer is forgettable, and the entire thing is nothing but a cynical attempt at checkboxing fps elements to try to bring in the cod crowd.If you read this far and are still thinking about buying the game, please don't. I can not in good conscience recommend this game to anyone when battlefield 4, an infinitely better experience, is the exact same price. Buy that game for a much better fps experience.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2011
												HomeFront, is an interesting game. The story and tight narrative really hold the action together almost like the quality FPS's from developer valve. Kaos Studios has done something that the choked sea of call of duty clones has sorely needed in the FPS market, originality. This game is dripping with atmosphere thanks to its well thought out and executed graphical design and the games excellent pacing. You never feel ovewhelmed, but you are always on your toes. This game is a winner for me, the downside is its short, but honestly what game is not now adays? Its about 5 hours long which may♥♥♥♥♥♥people off but the story is so well done and the game play is paced and designed so well that I can't believe people would turn this one down. The multiplayer is excellent, and the single player is a very well crafted story to which I look forward to returning to in the next game of the series {hopefully} This game deserves your dollars, its only 50 dollars. Buy it.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												Your character is slow, limited, and load-outs are barely enough and difficult to refill.  Game allows NPC to shoot through materials that will block your shots.  NPCs throw grenades at you and are usually accurate while yours take weird flights and often miss the intended location.  Hate not having save-game available but having the check-point system is tedious and awkward at the higher settings.  Limited landscapes restrict the freedom of movement for flanking and force the player into kill-zones where swarming attacks are typical.  Compared to STALKER, SoC, this is inflexible and player input seems to be altered to make it more difficult to control and access anything.  Wouldn't have bought this game if I had known about the custom key alterations as opposed to a better NPC program.    3 out of 5 stars.

												Homefront is a bland game.The campaign's theme is great and originally what made me interested in the game, but the gameplay consists mostly of running through corridors and following AI buddies onsiderably slower than you. And you know how in regular FPS's you start off with meager equipment and get more and stronger toys throughout the game? Homefront bizarrely does the reverse. It gradually strips away your best guns and gimmicks and mission by mission turns the game more from a semi-interesting FPS to a run-to-the-mill shootmans. Thankfully you won't have to suffer long because the campaign is super short. You can easily blitz through it in five or so hours on normal difficulty.Multiplayer is dead to no-one's surprise.Skip this game and look forward to Homefront 2: Revolution instead. Coming in 2016 from Dambuster Studios and Deep Silver (latter being the guys who bought the publishers of this first Homefront, THQ).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												The Gist:Set in a post WW III America, occupied by North Korean, this game came out in the heyday of CoD: Modernwarfare. Though it rang many of the bells of the direct competitor, it also fell short in many regards the former did. Ultimately a severely mediocre game which did not manage to dethrone any other game.The Pros:-Good graphics and a good visual presentation over all.-A not too overused setting (at the time anyways).-The multiplayer acutally set itself aside quite well from its competition.The Cons:-First the worst: the movement in this game feels terrible. Described as "floaty" and "unresponsive" by reviewers, when it first came out, it displays all that can go wrong with a CoD-esque game. You move at a literal snail's pace - try to sprint and your unathletic avatar give up after five meters.-On top of the former, in all the ingame cutscenes (and there are plenty, dragging out the expierence) you move even slower, forced to endure unskippable, cammy at best but mostly boring text.-Some sad technical shortcomings, FOV is very narrow, some sound bugs.-The story meanders between shallow and melodramatic, a short and unsatisfying bore.-Though interesting at the time, the multiplayer is dead now.-There is an unjustified amount of expensive DLC, splitting the community (not that there is anything like that anymore).

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												So, first off, I should say that I bought this game purely for the single-player experience, and can't really comment on the multiplayer.  I gather there isn't much of a multiplayer community to speak of, so I just didn't bother.My "thumbs down" rating is based largely on the $19.99 standard price, which is NOT what I paid for the game, fortunately.  This game is in no way, shape, or form worth $19.99.  Instead, I paid about $5, which is what I'd say is a fair price for the game in terms of the quality of gameplay and amount of entertainment you get, compared to other games out there.  I went into this game, having paid my $5, looking for basically a diverting shooting gallery, and I got exactly that, so I'm perfectly satisfied with my purchase.  But, again, I wouldn't pay just shy of $20 for it.  As for why, read on.The graphics are...eh, fine.  I'm not really a graphics snob, so that's not a big deal to me.  They ran fine at max settings on my 6-year-old computer, which makes sense, considering the game came out...5 years ago.  The visuals themseles aren't up to snuff for a AAA title, but then I don't think this game could claim to be a AAA title.  Gameplay attempts to be similar to your basic Call of Duty game, with you as one of 4-5 resistance fighters in a United States under occupation by North Korea.  The game tries to make this ludicrous scenario seem reasonably plausible.  It doesn't really matter who they are, though.  They're the bad guys who've taken over the good ol' US of A, and it's up to you to shoot them in the face and do...pretty much everything else.  Your character, I think, is named Jackson or something, but he might as well be Ramirez from Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2.  ("Ramirez!  Do [task]!")Movement is kind of clunky, and the gunplay isn't all that satisfying.  Sound design for the guns is passable, but they tend to have this sort of "clanky" quality to them.  There's probably, like, 10 different common firearms you can pick up, with 2-3 rocket launchers and such, but they all felt mostly the same to me.  There are some missions where you control this or that vehicle or assign this or that target to some mobile bringer-of-death (e.g. calling in a fire mission), but the bulk of the game is what you'd expect it to be: you running around shooting dudes.Voice acting is nothing special, and you don't end up really caring about the characters.  No surprise there.  There aren't any real cutscenes to speak of, other than the occasional mission interlude where your characters talk a bit before you can equip your gun and shoot stuff.  You get loading screens with the "Voice of America" providing a bit of context for the next mission.  Basically, if you want to play "Red Dawn: The Game" this is about as close as you'll get.  And for that, it's kinda fun, but it's not particularly polished.

content:
Posted: February 2
												A mechanical facsimilie of Call of Duty set against a surprisingly novel backdrop, but released at a time when appetite for cookie-cutter corridor shooters was already declining. While it's a technically sound shooter with decent artwork and design, and a few memorable scripted moments sprinkled in, it's painfully formulaic; if you're a fan of Call of Duty, it'll seem like a less interesting knock-off. If you're tired of Call of Duty, this won't do anything to relieve your fatigue. If you hate Call of Duty, this won't do anything to win you over. The developers clearly believed in their project, but one can't help but wonder if their efforts might have been better spent elsewhere.Overall: 3.5/10

												This game doesn't feel right. The Story—North Koreans sucessfully invade and occupy the US of A—could be a wonderful setup for an excellent B-Movie style plot but personally I don't care much about any of the characters. At least the pilot guy I'm playing. The NPCs (the Goliath drone, too) just stand in the way, slow me down, won't let me open any door by myself and block the frame after kicking down the door, and so on and so on…What I like:• The graphics—not top notch anymore and probably never were, but the game looks cohesive in a good way;• Beeing able to stand, crouch and prone is good—switching between crouching and standing is good for getting in and out of cover fast, and to prone helped me in some tough scenes;• The setup of the story.What I do not like:• Guys, girls and drones standing in the way, blocking my view and blocking my way;• Doors magically closing behind me;• The weapons' sounds;• Somehow I feel small in this game. The POV is like everyone is at least one head taller than "me".• The story.I've read the multiplayer-part of this game is decent, but beeing almost a pure single player I can't judge. For SPs like me I can not recommend this game.

Everything about this game had the makings to compete with the COD series, but it continually fell just short or was consistent throughout the game. A great example of that consistency is the story. When the story first starts and it hits the fan, the story is powerful and driving you on. You feel compelled to take back your country. The game really isn't bad, and is definitely worth a few bucks if on sale, but I cannot honestly recommend this game with so many other and better qualified games out there.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Homefront Review (Spoiler Free)(Story)In the near future, global crises force countries to make aggressive decisions about their survival.  North Korea ends up coming out on top and once it solidifies its presence in Europe and Asia, it turns to North America.  The NK's invade from the West and life becomes hell for the average U.S. citizen.  You play a member of the resistance movement and are quickly hurled into the fight to break the NK's hold on the U.S.(Gameplay)Homefront is an FPS with rechargeable health, much like COD4.  There is no cover system though you can peak and lean once you aim down sights.  You can carry several weapons plus equipment and pick up weapons on the ground.  Most of the time you will be doing on-foot shooting however there are a few land and air vehicular segments.  You will usually fight with a team of resistance members, though do not expect much in terms AI competency.  Enemies on the other hand show average to below average intelligence.  Other than a few set moments, it's one shooting gallery after another, just at various times of day.  My favorite moment in the game is when you are given the ability to direct an unmanned rover and use it to clear your way through a neighborhood.  Most will complete the game in under three (that's right, 3) hours making this game a hard sell, especially with stronger competitors out there.  Multiplayer tries to mimic Battlefield style gameplay with vehicles, gadgets, and large maps but there are not many people except fans playing anymore.    (Design)The game looks and sounds decent.  As others have said, the opening sequence sets the stage for an epic game.  There are many good looking set piece moments, but they are marred by short levels and average gameplay.  Dialogue feels okay though nothing is worth quoting.(Final Comments)I believe the multiplayer component of this game was the primary focus during its creation.  Unfortunately it could not compete with Battlefield and instead, players are left with an average single player.  With a short campaign experience devoid of replayability and a relatively empty multiplayer, I do not recommend Homefront.  Hopefully the sequel fares better.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												tl;dr: A bunch of great ideas with poor execution: the game. This game isn't really worth the $20 asking price. Campaign is three hours long on a good day, and the mulitplayer is a bland, unpopulated experience. For the same price you can buy battlefield 3 or 4 on Origin, which outclass this game in just about every aspect. Don't waste your time here.What it does right: I was hyped as hell when this first showed up, and the amount of advertisement and weird♥♥♥♥♥♥they did at E3 that year really made me want to buy it. The setting is a great idea. I wish more shooters would stray away from the modern military shooter that we're so used to by now and do things like this. However, when the reviews started coming out I'd figure I'd try it once it dropped in price... four years later.The mechanics work, I guess. It's nothing special, other than maybe getting to use the Goliath to shoot rockets at enemies that are giving you a hard time. None of the guns feel bad to use, and they have a good amount of punch on enemies, but at the same time they do feel kinda flimsy. For a shooter that came out in 2011, it works. It's nothing special but it's not like the mechanics of the game are terrible.A few of the set pieces were pretty cool, but those were a mix between laughable and alright. None of it felt particularly epic, but again, it served its purpose.What it does wrong: Oh boy where to start. I guess we can start with the singleplayer. It's overly linear. I don't mean the good kind of linear like Metro 2033 or Killzone. I mean straight out of call of duty corridoor nose-leading. If you go in any direction other than which one the game wants you to go, you'll run face first into an invisible wall. It doesn't matter if you just passed through that open door ten seconds ago, you go one way and one way only. And you can tell the designating fighting zones from the talking corridors by the random stacks of chest-high cover littered around. It's painfully obvious that this game doesn't really want you to go out on your own or do anything other than move from cover to cover shooting bad guys. There is no variety to any of it.The graphics also haven't aged well. I don't think they were even that great at the time. I think Half Life 2 looks better and it came out seven years before. The color scheme is bland and uninteresting, and you can't interact with anything other than picking up guns. Even your teammates have to open doors for you like this was a ps2 ww2 shooter.The campaign is, in its entirety, maybe three hours long if you stop to look at the scenery once in a while. I beat it in two and a half. It isn't even a good three hours either. I was actually kinda thankful it wasn't longer, otherwise I might not have gotten through it. None of your npc companions are even remotely interesting and they don't bother to characterize any of them beyond very basic traits. You have no reason to be invested in any of it, as they just sling you into the action three minutes into it with barely any explanation. This doesn't change the further you get into it, either. Only after following these rebels for an hour and a half or so do they finally tell me in the form of an off-hand comment that they needed me to fly a helicopter for them. You think they would have taken the time to brief the pilot on that important detail, or at least asked if he could fly a helicopter and wasn't just a jet pilot or something. The most motivation you get is the objective marker. No overall reason behind it, or important motive, just follow the arrow. Sure, I want to liberate the home of the free just as much as anyone, but blindly following the first couple of idiots that almost kill me in a car crash doesn't seem like it's the most solid of motivations.And another thing, I'm getting really tired of silent protagonists. It worked in games like Dead Space because Isaac was completely alone, and didn't need to talk to anyone most of the time, but here? There are usually three other people that need to be interacted with in combat situations. Games like Far Cry 3 and Spec Ops: The Line have completely destroyed the notion that video game protagonists are better silent. I have no interest in Jacobs like I did Jason. Being invested in your character as a person goes a long way into being better invested in the game overall. This game did nothing towards this and ended up being bland and forgettable.One last little rant before I get to the multiplayer: North Korea? Really? The only reason anyone ever gives them any respect is because they're allies with China. Never would a tiny, economically weak nation like North Korea ever be able to hold as much land as we are led to believe, or be able to invade and occupy the nation with the world's strongest military, even while under economic collapse.  The logistics of such things are simply impossible for North Korea, even if they did have the military size they say they do, which is most likely a lie. As much as I give battlefield 4's singleplayer♥♥♥♥♥♥ it at least had a believable scenario. Plus North Korean soldiers using Colt, Bushmaster, and Kriss USA firearms (All American-based firearm companies if you didn't know)? Did they even bother to do any research into this matter? Now for the Multiplayer: They tried to add some unique features like battlepoints to build up like killstreaks, using this money to spawn into vehicles and use special weapons. I like this better than cod's killstreak system, since it allows you to buy things even if you're not doing that well, but I still don't like it that much. First, just about every class gets a rocket launcher, and you can buy it after one kill. This is not good game design. Vehicles are pretty much useless beyond a quick kill or two if you find a group of enemies that knows what they're doing. Vehicles are pretty much instant kills on infantry too, so that's annoying, and you can't even use environmental ques to tell where they are like you might in battlefield, where you might hear it coming or see it firing on the minimap. I think it did show up on the minimap, but I never saw it before one killed me.It's got the standard setup for multiplayer unlocking systems. Get kills and unlock guns. I didn't play enough to unlock anything, but I never felt like using anything other than the first class was really necessary. I didn't see much variety in the enemies either, but then again the killcam gives you absolutely no information other than where the person who killed you was at. Since just about every class gets a rocket launcher, and sniping is pretty pointless on smaller maps imo, there didn't seem to be much variety to be had. I played a few games and there wasn't much exciting going on. The maps are too big for there to be large chunks of action, and I doubt that's ever going to change with the player counts as they are. Other games do everything so much better. Overall, this game is nothing but all of the stereotypical elements of first person shooters from 2011. It seems like a lazy attempt to pull away customers from cod's fanbase, and even then, it doesn't do anything better than call of duty, it just imitates it in a different setting. If this game had come out on the ps2 seven years before, then I think it might have been a lot better received. As it is now, that's kinda what it feels like: a generic ww2 shooter from the ps2 made for a later generation. There's nothing special about it other than its setting. The multiplayer is bland, the singleplayer is forgettable, and the entire thing is nothing but a cynical attempt at checkboxing fps elements to try to bring in the cod crowd.If you read this far and are still thinking about buying the game, please don't. I can not in good conscience recommend this game to anyone when battlefield 4, an infinitely better experience, is the exact same price. Buy that game for a much better fps experience.

content:
Posted: February 2
												A mechanical facsimilie of Call of Duty set against a surprisingly novel backdrop, but released at a time when appetite for cookie-cutter corridor shooters was already declining. While it's a technically sound shooter with decent artwork and design, and a few memorable scripted moments sprinkled in, it's painfully formulaic; if you're a fan of Call of Duty, it'll seem like a less interesting knock-off. If you're tired of Call of Duty, this won't do anything to relieve your fatigue. If you hate Call of Duty, this won't do anything to win you over. The developers clearly believed in their project, but one can't help but wonder if their efforts might have been better spent elsewhere.Overall: 3.5/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												I really struggled with giving this game a like, but not for that reason. The short version is I got the interactive directors cut of Wolverines for $5. That is worth a like. I would call this game a good B movie.Long version (spoilers):This is not a great game. I kind of picked it apart on my play through, and these are in no particular order. The graphics are sub par, and I don’t mean that in the "it's not ray-traced at 4K so it's crap" kind of way. The visuals are muddy. Thank god the KPA doesn’t know what camouflage is, because the way everything blends is too much as is. More than this the LOD (level of detail) is very inconsistent. It really looks like every model uses the same texture resolution. While things like loose bricks look great, trucks look pixilated. Also, the game seems to have abandoned ANY post processing adding to the muddy problem. Those things aside though the game does a good job of selling the apocalyptic landscape. Trash and clutter are everywhere, and the graffiti is remarkably well done. The levels are dense, and complex, and chaotic. That is perfect for a semi-casual shooter like this. Best part, real business names. I got to shoot a KPA in a Hooters. It’s more fun than it sounds. I also got in a fire fight in a blazing Tiger Direct store, symbolic really. Every time I tossed a grenade I yelled “NewEgg!”The animations are acceptable. The facial animations look like Saturday morning cartoons since everyone has about two expressions and lip syncing didn't happen. All doors kick down the same with the same dust animation. Finally the weapon animations look like they were sped up after being animated at a realistic speed. That being said the animation are not buggy, and are actually really smooth and consistent. Taking into account how mal-proportioned the characters are the animations look pretty good.The story… OK, let’s play pretend. Let’s pretend that N. Korea had a GDP above $10. Let’s pretend that the DPRK’s NADA (National Aerospace Development Administration) has ever launched anything but a propaganda campaign. Let’s pretend that China would tolerate the Kims making a power play before them. Let’s pretend Russia wouldn’t turn N. Korea into glass for fun. This game does get one thing right. In an invasion of the US, the military would be the least of your problems. Despite the huge suspension of disbelief, I actually wanted to finish the story, and was disappointed when it ended at chapter 7. That alone earned the like rating.Just going to get this out there, this game wants to be Call of Duty: Modern Warefare (series) sooooooo bad. Problem is, they didn’t do anything worse, and actually did some things better, despite the lack in overall polish. *spoiler*“Why We Fight” opens with a solid 3 minute presentation on why we need the Geneva Convention, and it is so much better at it than “No Russian” and (and Davis Family Vacation for that matter). I will readily stack “Heartland” Against “Back on the Grid” and “Golden Gate” feels like “Iron Lady” without being tedious. “Firesale”… meh Spec Ops; The Line did it better in “The Gate” Unfortunately Connor is always there spouting 80s action movie one liners (I swear he was plucked from Command and Conquer: Renegade or a Schwarzenegger film). Price was so much cooler. Hell, Sandman is better than Connor. That aside, Rianna is a nice squad mate. Now I choose to ignore that she is dressed like that in a war zone. It’s not overt, but ARs and midriff only mix at a trade show. She does make up for that by giving the Bechtel test two to the head in every chapter. Nice to see we are getting closer to equality. I think of her as an early draft Miranda Lawson.Game play is alright. The controls are sloppy, but I knew that going in. That is just how THQ does things. Weapon damage tables are really good for a COD clone. The shotgun is actually useable. All the weapons feel different, but there are some glaring issues. The M16 has a 20RD magazine, and does not use M4, or Diablo SMG magazines. The M200 rifle has no kick when fired standing (at least compared to what a .338 should do to your shoulder) and somebody got “clipped” by a 20MM cannon. The Goliath thing is… Juggernaut. For a game that mentions taking cover in every level, there is no cover system. Over all, it’s alright. Buy this, buy Wolverines, either way it's worth a couple bucks.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												A pleasant little FPS game. There is nothing particularly exceptional about the game: the mechanics are fairly standard, the narrative is good, though not perhaps as good a treatment of the idea (SE Asian upstart invades US West Coast) as others have done. The mechanics for the PC are unpolished: hints at the bottom of the screen gave button numbers, which doesn't help if you play with mouse+keyboard as I did. And in two cases (Goliath and grenade launcher), the only way to access these necessary functions was by reaching down and pushing the joystick on the otherwise unused controller. In another case, it gave no useful indication of how to control the helicopter's altitude, leaving me to button mash for a good ten minutes (failing the mission at one point) (it turned out to be, absurdly, the 5th button on the mouse). Nevertheless, I played the game for the narrative, and it has a couple of stand-out points. The first for sure is the opening mission, where you play as one being arrested (why? who knows. For harboring rebellious attitudes, it seems) and on the bus ride to your eventual fate, you see the world around you being corrupted and destroyed, invaders "cleansing" (?) the local population. I'm not entirely sure why the occupying force would willy-nilly kill mothers and fathers, citizens and non-aggressive individuals, but they are certainly familiar to us as the most iconic images of war and dictatorships, whether Nazi or Chinese, Serbian or Chilean, and they have a strong effect on the reader. The second is the burning of the city (Colorado, somewhere), that is revealed at a moment when the characters leave on a mission. The game certainly brings home the consequences of war - I'm not sure how much of it is entirely credible (I very much doubt the Koreans could take down the entire midwest with paratroopers), but it gives plenty of haunting images of what life would be like in a very different, and as far as a political collapse of the US, somewhat plausible America. The collage of news reports and video documentaries that provide the prologue to the game is well done. Otherwise, the arc of the characters is fairly predictable ("I bet _he's_ gonna die") and I never actually attached to my own character, but rather than a fault, this is really only a missed opportunity. The game itself is rather short, as well. I only played about 5 hours, and it ended rather abruptly. It hinted at the turning point of the war, but I would have preferred the thrill to get to see that happen, and the Koreans begin to retreat. I was expecting it, and to not have it I felt was another missed opportunity.For the $5 I paid, certainly worth it. Total: 7/10 (mostly for the haunting images and sequences).

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												This game one of most underrated game I play.Single player campaign is fresh with American empire taken over by missile mad Koreans.  People say campaign too short or not as good as Modern Warfare game.  I don't see problem.  The game has good direction as you move through occupied America watching Korean kick♥♥♥♥♥before big battle on red bridge.As well as killing many Korean I also like that you can do some parts where you also kill Americans.  Without this I would not like game as much.  Campaign not hard but good to see story and horror of war, such as Americans thrown into ditch.  Maybe a new Homefront could be made where Jalalabad control America.  This would be true epic and big seller in my country.  More so that pirated copies of Windows XP.Multiplayer is really really good.  You run, kill, die, respawn... over and over repeat process.  More kills and objective points give you bonuses like unlock vehicles and air strike.  Within few minutes of game you see people bring chopper and tank.  No spawn killing as spawn keep moving away from enemy.Another thing about online that make me hard is knifing.  You can spam knife running through building to make new Kill Bill 3 movie.  Watching bodies pile up then dropping payload on reinforcements is better than stale bread.  Once I do cartwheel after getting 10 kill streak with knife only.  I kick my light.

												It's honestly a good game. The single player is fun and challenging. You fight alongside a loosing rebellion to resist the korean occupation of America in a near future scenario. The plot becomes less ridiculous and more frighteningly surreal as you learn about all the events leading up to occupation through news papers you find lying around the levels. Enemy AI is nothing special but challenging enough. Some levels are garbage though (like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ stealth level with no action that you have to crawl through), and the story parts are slow and can't be skipped.The multiplayer is fun too, with progression/unlockables like CoD or BF, and has its own unique  feel to it, which is refreshing for people looking to take time away from the big names. BUT the movement needs patching, it's easy to get caught on stupid things like stones on the ground as big as your foot, and the weapons need rebalancing. The accuracy is a big issue, and the sniper rifle almost feels mandato

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Supposedly a good multiplayer experience. But if you, like me, just like to experience a good single player campaign, don't bother. Even if you are a John Milius fan (this is not the expected "Call of Duty meets Red Dawn"). On the pro side (which is more of a "not completely distgusting" side) you get some distinctive characters (well, you'll be able to distinguish between the philosophical positions of Rianna and Connor. And you'll recognize Hopper because he's the Korean kid. Let's not overdo it with character depth), you get a "Go Wolverines" banner, the story is kinda sorta engaging, the 4 hours needed to complete it are kinda sorta acceptable and the cliffhanger ending qualifies as "it was probably pretty cool when Milius described it to the designers". What really kills it is the implementation in the game: The flow is generally interrupted by barriers of the invisible (ah, okay, I am not supposed to go explore a bit, yes?) and visible kind (it is annoying to see the NPCs hurdle them and not being able to oneself), the events are badly timed (ah, to get rid of the enemy Goliath, I need to press this button exactly now?) and the mix of required interaction and watching pre-scripted scenes is badly balanced. All of that ruins the immersion feeling.So: No reason to play this for single player fans. Go watch any version of Red Dawn instead, at least these movies won't bother you with bad interaction design. And while you are at it, check out Tomorrow When The War Began. P.S.: Does anyone know what Primary Weapons System paid to get their Diablo into that game? I like long-stroke piston guns like the next guy, but seeing this rather obscure thing as a standard weapon in the game was kinda distracting.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Let me list the ways you can die in this game. Grenade that's 10M away from you Insanely accurate machine gunner from 100M+ RPG Units that know exactly when you're coming up from prone Following your squad leader Tanks/APCs with Terminator level guidence systems Random explosionsNow to the serious stuff, this game is really not good. You are some indiscriminate character drafted into the resistance, after some event happens. I honestly don't remember what it was, as it was that forgetable. And seriously, the North Koreans as an enemy? Could they not find a smaller army?Homefront suffers from horrible AI, both enemy and friendly. Enemies will stand out in the open, laying down massive and accurate rounds of fire on you. Fire one shot, and they all train their sights on you instantly. Friendlies will get in the way at every single chance. Also, you are forced to be the last person through any entry point. Meaning; have to climb up a ladder? Have fun watching your three squad mates climb up it frirst before you get a prompt to climb. Wanna crawl under that fence? Nope, have to wait till everyone goes before you.None of the characters are memorable, including the one you play. In fact, there were plenty of times where commands were issued and I had to question if I was the one being commanded to do them. The story is disjointed at best. A game about the occupation of the US? Cool, I'm in, but this was poorly done and felt rushed. Great potential with the idea, making US citizens insurgents, but more time could have been spent fleshing it out. After 4.5 hours I had the game beat, and that was after I died, a lot.Speaking of which, the ending, talk about the most lack luster ending ever. Granted I didn't stay past the first couple of credits (I exited quickly to write this review) but there was no gratification, no bad guy to defeat, no nemisis to duel. Just a quick battle for a landmark and roll credits. This could have easily been a trilogy if the time was taken to create a proper story.At 75% off it's still not worth it. Although I should note that I have not played the multiplayer (And won't) so I can't comment on its value there.This is a great idea for a game, but horribly executed, painfully short and terribly forgetable.

content:
