												I have no idea why this game is good. I mean, it looks good, and the gameplay is meh, but damn, I love this game. Lots of making the Koreans seem like total asshats in the first 15 minutes. I mean, you see them shoot some parents of a little kid, beat up some people, execute some others. Then you see them put people in mass graves, then you burn them alive, then you see them touture your leader. I mean, jesus. But then you kill them all with 'Murican music and make them pay. I haven't felt this invested in a single player shooter since ever.Besides, it has some interesting lore as well.♥♥♥♥ NORTH KOREA YOU SCUM. THE ONLY GOOD KOREAN IS A DEAD KOREAN.Too far?*I've beaten this on the 360, just so i don't seem like a first impressions scrub*

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
												A first-person shooter by every definition of the term, but not a particularly interesting one. The plot is at least an interesting take on the same old America-vs.-commies plot we've all grown used to and the voice acting is actually quite good, but the gameplay doesn't really do enough to supplement it. Your character feels like he moves too slow, the enemies are far too numerous, the levels aren't very variable and even the guns feel weirdly... soggy. They don't have the "oomph" that the weapons of games like Call of Duty do. It reallyt is a shame, sine this game really could have done something good with the story it has - but the gameplay honestly wastes it all.Pros:+ Interesting plot+ Pretty good voice actingCons:- Movement feels sluggish- Guns aren't fun to use- Unremarkable level design.

												A bit dull and generic, the movement and gunplay seems to be intentionally almost identical to recent Call Of Duty games. Completely forgettable storyline. number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
												6/10.This is a tough one. Homefront generally is a subpar CoD. That's one reason why it's a negative review. The other is that the game offers moderately ok gunplay, shallow characters, stuck on terrain bugs, basically no innovative features and an incoherent plot that only takes you about 3 to 4 hours to complete. Just when you think things start rolling in the US again, the game is suddenly over. Just like that. No conclusion. We don't even know up until the very end what we even did and why we did what we did and how THAT helped win the battle. Which is disappointing.That isn't to say that Homefront can't be a nice little experience. Especially the setting and the disgusting nature of the occupation are pretty well presented. The graphics aren't ugly, but nothing to look up to either. Crysis 1 looks better for example, but is a lot older as far as I can recall.Homefront is simply a game of missed opportunities and at still 20 bucks I can't recomment buying it. Got it during a sale for 5 bucks, which is "ok-ish". If you like CoD gameplay, grab it, if not, just leave it. Unfortunately the whole Homefront project got pretty much abandoned and "remade" into something, which is apparently just as mediocre. It's sad, because if you extend the story by about 100 to 200% (so maybe 6 to 8 hours at least), spread in some more interesting missions, for example infiltration or something in the wilds, I dunno. Not just shooty shooty though and garnish everything with some interesting characters (Hell, the Duke has more character than these guys) and a well-thought out plot with maybe a bit better gameplay as well. And you have yourselves a winner. As it stands right now, this serves as a 10 dollar prequel game to an actual game.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2013
												The campaign was over before it really started. It was only a few hours long and it felt like the beginning of a much longer game that might have had potential. As it is, it's a  very short standard linear modern shooter. It got frustrating having to wait for an NPC to open a door or remove an obstacle so the story can progress. The graphics looked nice at times and also some of the weapons were a lot of fun to shoot. There's a helicopter part thrown in that was entertaining. I played one game of multiplayer on the only server (it was laggy) that's still up. I'd say give Homefront a try if you're bored and the game is on sale for cheap.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												You know how you remember certain moments in a game, when you got all excited you did this and that happened, well none spring to mind with homefront.A brief and dull affair badly trumped in my opinion by bulletstorm.If being comparative is left to one side we have an FPS playing out a rather generic possible reality where natural resources are so scarce that its every man for himself. Usher in the words resistence and government and you have the well done dish of the day that is one world governance as country after country slaves for out right dominance, sadly with you not invited. Your tubed from one section to the next with little concern for connecting or indentifying with friendly AI others. The weapons are bland and more a rat, at, tat than a thud, thud of bullets ripping there way through the enemy AI's torso. Graphics and sound are unrevolutionary and single play very very short.You see no matter how you slice it and dice it, this game comes up familiar and wanting so unless its cheaper than the asking price when your making a decision, there are others better suited to waste time on.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												Wow. Where do I start with this one?After reading some of the other positive reviews it seems that most people enjoy this game for its multiplayer. I am not really that into multiplayer games and even if I wanted to play multiplayer on this game I doubt there would be very many open servers (I could be wrong).That aside my review is based solely on the single player campaign and it is for those of you who are considering getting this game for the campaign.It's not worth it. It's not worth 19.99. Luckily I was able to get my copy from Amazon which was much cheaper but if you were to purchase this on steam I would wait for a sale.The combat is okay, nothing special, typical FPS really. The enemies and allies alike make the same sounds when being shot, the guy Connor barks at you constantly as if his testicles have been punched into his stomach, and the game gets a little buggy when the NPC's are waiting/expecting you to follow them - when in fact I would be in front of them. Also barking orders after I've already done what they told me to do, just simple sort of bugs like that.The story.. er.. plot, there isn't really much of one. Which is disappointing because I applaud this FPS unique choice to have a guerilla warfare shooter take place in the USA, but they really dropped the ball with this one. I couldn't care less about any of the characters, in fact I wanted Connor to die. He annoyed the crap out of me.The story/plot felt so mediocre that they even managed to fulfill the stereotypical Asian engineer/computer technical guy and the black guy that dies halfway through the game. Shocker. Nah, I'm kind of kidding about that part, I mean yeah, I noticed it was kind of a stereotypical thing but that's not really a big deal to me. It's just it was the cherry on top of an already lackluster sundae.In a few months I'll probably not even remember a single thing about this game because none of it was memorable. I should have listened to the reviews that said not to get the game if you were just interested in the campaign. Well, reviewers that said that - You were right.Also the game is kind of short. I know that 8-12 hours is a standard length for a FPS, but I played the game on hard and beat it within 5ish hours. (The almost 10 hours thats recorded on Steam was because I left for several hours with the game paused a couple of times).If I played the game on easy or normal, I'd imagine one could finish this within 4 or less easily.Anyway guys, I don't recommend getting this game. It's not worth the price they are asking for it. It would be worth a consider if they were asking maybe 4.99-7.99, but definitely not 19.99

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												OhMyGod.This is possibly the worst generic first person shooter there is, you thought that all the CODs are bad? You've seen nothing yet,  this is...linear corridor heavily scripted fest...which lasts 5 hours! I hated every minute I spended in this game. And it was just 5 hours, jesus, jesusity christ.You would except big polish from games like this, say what you want about CODs, yes they kind of suck,but when it comes to polish and detail they tend to be rather good. This game..you can't even see the hands of the main hero when he's clmbing. The only good thing that came out of this game was the soundtrack, which is really good and I remember it to this day...multiplayer was decent, nobody plays it anymore of course, so there's no point mentioning it, as you are not going to be playing it.The story....eeeuuugh Korea (lol) takes over the entire world (lolololol) and some other crap I don't care about, all characters are generic, you've got your gurl soldier, your♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥soldier and your silent Gordon Freeman protagonist. Oh, and there is some guy who dies, he is charming. The game really wants to shock you, first thing you see is soldiers killing son's parents in front of his eyes. It gets old.I also remember this game having some poor optimization with mediocre graphics to go along with it. The game had super big hype, and it didn't deliver on it. At all.Gameplay...Call of Duty...regenerating health...two weapons limit....gunplay's the same...what more can I possibly say? And there is boss at the end! QTE boss! Have fun!There is apparently next game in the works by Crytek. So I guess next Homefront is going to be graphics ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game with the same gameplay of this game? I'll pass.Sooo...in the end..any pluses? Well...the game's super short...and the soundtrack, I really like the soundtrack.3/10

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2012
												Sweet merciful CRAP was that a short game or what? Steam says that I played 3 hours of it, and that's not even an I-beat-it-quicker-than-you brag; I was trying to explore.Anyway, I thought it was awesome. The campaign is insanely epic, even if there are some annoying parts, and the shooting mechanics are absolutely top-notch. The guns react amazingly, and if you have a decent sound system, you can really feel each shot. The graphics aren't the greatest if you get right up close, but for the most part they're pretty good. Character models and animations are very well done, so that's at least something. If I'd paid $60 for it, I would be livid, but as I paid more like $7 for it, I think it was worth it. Check it out if you like shooters, and can find it on sale. I have no comment on multiplayer, as I don't care for competitive shooters in the slightest.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												My rating: 3.5 / 10The majority of the entertainment that can be derived from Homefront is mostly just from how remarkably terrible it is, as it achieves nothing more than being an underwhelming and bug ridden CoD clone.Pros: - A number of creative scenarios for the player that adds some variety to the gameplay.- Soundtrack isn't too bad.- Representation of an Asian American video game character.Cons:- Very glitchy, from overall player control, to physics errors, to scripted events failing to play out correctly.- Enemy AI is very rough around the edges. Sometimes being completely dumb, and other times having the precision of a super computer.- Bland story, with a rather anti-climactic ending.- Dialogue hardly makes sense in some cases, making the characters appear incredibly unintelligent.- Very short singleplayer campaign, though in the case of this game, it's probably a plus.Homefront probably could have been a decent game, had it been given the proper attention and resources during development, as there were some points that showed a bit of potential. However, unfortunately this was nowhere near enough to redeem how glitchy and poorly put together the final product ended up being.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Other reviewers said it would be good graphically and it surely doesn't disappoint.  The quality of the single player campaign is awesome in that it has definite replay value as when you die it makes you want to play that section of the game again and do it with eventually next to no deaths or no deaths next time.  A very intense story with very intense action ...  a quality game.  I paid $6.49 CAN I believe for this all and it is worth much more than that.  As for the MPer I haven't touched that yet but see it as an extra to a game that doesn't need it as the single player campaign stands out on it's own well.  In regards to the single player the objectives set in front of you on the spur of a moment well they are fun and breath taking at times.  The sounds/music in this game are epic and definitely get you pumped to be playing the game.  There are moments where certain things happen to certain characters and you feel emotion for them for what they are going through.  I would have kept playing tonight but I have to feed another gaming addiction too.  Back log for life but I say if you are looking for a pick up and play shooter that is intense and fun play this one.

content:
Posted: January 1
												Im glad i got this game on sale...  Its stupidly short.  3.4 hours going from start to finish.  Its clear that this games focus is on Multiplayer.  That being said, the singleplayer plays well.  Would have loved to have more fun with Golith but meh.  Also, for a game that is almost dependent on cover to survive, why is there no lean option?  There were times when i was being shot around corners by someone i could not see because they had just a slight lean to the right able to look around a corner.  Im also half tempted to call this game "On Rails"  Since it guides you where you need to be at all times and never shuts up untill you get there.  In short i cant recommend this game due to how stupidly short it is and a few issues with the gameplay....and that story... while good on paper, it was told♥♥♥♥♥♥poorly here.

												Easily one of the worst games I have ever played.In the singleplayer campaign there is an incredibly cheap blatant attempt to give some sort of meaning, pull at emotion or whatever it was they intended by having dozens of civilians executed and mowed down by gunfire and wanton violence more vicious than Hitler's SS would dream, and not all too longer after those instances you're introduced to a mass grave.Where in Mass Effect 3 they managed to summarize the global genocide of humanity on Earth by focusing on the death of a single kid being killed in a shuttle shot down as Shepard leaves, this game utterly failed after tossing hundreds of dead civilians at your face. content:
Posted: May 14, 2011
												Come on, what is this ? People who thought the latest Call Of Duties were short, prepare for a new contender. That's right, even with a small pause inbetween, I finished it in 4 hours. It's ridiculous for a full priced game. For the first time I really feel like I've wasted my money. Now, don't get me wrong; it's a good game, but you jump from one scenario to another one way too soon. There should've been more (or longer anyway) missions. And I don't think the multiplayer added something new to the genre. It's dull and from the start there were too many campers sitting around. Say what you want, but Call Of Duty is still king of (over the top) FPS storytelling and, in my opinion, the multiplayer experience just can't be beat. Get this game when it's $10-15.[Rating: 77/100]

												The game desperately wants to invoke some emotions, but it feels clumsy and sometimes cheesy. And if you realize this and you see for example a quite village with playing children, you know it will be destroyed in an instant and the game expects you to weep for the lost souls, for the lost homes. I am not saying there shouldn't be such games. They should. All I am saying is that when developers learn to deal with subtlety and drop the "in-your-face" approach, it may even work.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Terrible, Terrible, Terrible.The trailer was the best part of the game.  I had such high hopes for the storyline and that it was written by the Red Dawn author.Things that sucked in my opinion:*No HP/HUD - Regenerative Health*Endlessly respawning North Koreans*AI was terrible - could hit a guy and not take him out, but then he would lose interest in me if I ducked around a corner*Hit boxes - I could shoot a guy in the shoulder and be given a head shot - hurray for sniping with a shot gun*Rockets that can hit me from around the corner - how did the enemy know where I was to curve his rocket around?*Being yelled at by my allies where to go and whom to shoot - ConstantlyThe gameplay was tedious. I didn't even bother finishing the game. My one regret was spending money and time purchasing and playing this game.  I would rather have punched myself in the nuts for 3 hours while being yelled at in Korean than play this game.Do-not-purchase-this-game!  If you gift this game to someone, you deserve all the bad that can possibly befall you.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Sometimes the best thing about Steam Sales is uncovering the hidden gems. The games that may have been overshadowed on release by other AAA titles. Maybe the quirky indie title that was a bit ahead of its time. The games with solid mechanics that just never caught the public's attention.Homefront is none of these things. Its a short, lazy, generic FPS. Any kind of flow or immersive action is avoided thanks to your NPC teammates. The AI is so dumb its almost interesting. One of the worst games I've ever tried to play from an (ex)AAA publisher.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												- Generic COD clone that brings nothing new to the table.- Frustrating "endless enemy spawn" mechanic used to artificially ramp up the difficulty. It's only on a few levels, but it's noticeable, and it's annoying.- Friendly AI is annoying, constantly vocalizing the same crap order repeatedly. Furthermore, there were times where I would try to reach cover or navigate around an object to gain a tactical advantage in battle, only to be blocked by the AI. Best example? Trying to get through a door so that I didn't get blown up by a grenade, and then getting locked out by my "ally's" buttocks.- Music isn't memorable.- The plot is severely lacking. You're a pilot, but you wind up sniping and gunning the entire game (there's one part where you fly a helicopter, but it's the shortest and easiest level in the game). It's also kind of unsatisfying. The entire first half of the game is dedicated to putting tracker bugs on something. Then you get to the end, fight in a battle that's easier than most of the battles up to that point, don't really do anything too fancy, and then are treated to a fifteen second audio clip about the event that you just played through. Also it's basically just Red Dawn except with grown-ups.- Gunplay is a mess. If you're not ADS, you're not hitting anything. This is fine for most of the game, but there are a couple of times where you just really need to spray and pray because you're that close, and yet you can't, because the bullets are going to miss.+ Graphics are pretty good.+ You get to kill people.+ They did put a lot of time and effort into making the story. There's 61 "pieces of lore" to find that help reveal how the world got to be so cwazy. I still think they could have chosen a better country than North Korea to be the aggressor, though (maybe China by the time the game takes place, but North Korea? ... yeah, right).+ It's short.

Posted: October 4, 2014
												Don't bother. The game looks bad, it plays bad, and it's not even a great port. It looks like Blops 1 graphics, the guns all feel the same and pretty much ARE the same. The story is pretty terrible and cliche, North Korea taking over America + the rest of the world? Really? They could have chosen practically any other nation and it would have been more likely. The enemies have awful AI and the game plays with a mixture of the worst of Battlefield and CoD. It has wave after wave of idiot enemies like CoD, and it has the open maps of Battlefield which would be fine if not for the clown cars of koreans that arrive. Go buy CoD, the story is generally the same junk, but at least most of the guns feel different from eachother and the AI isn't nearly as dumb. Multiplayer is pretty much dead and suffers from the gunplay issue. Unless you have a fascination with Korea or are incredibly desperate for a FPS then pass this.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												This game is short and♥♥♥♥♥♥but I bet any amount of money that stupid people will line up to throw money at the second game in an instant. Edit: Since people are getting angry that my review is so short, let me elaborate why I don't recommend this game. The mechanics are okay at best, they're essentially the same as Call of Duty but there's a few gimmicks that hardly last more than one mission before the devs said "Oh, well that's enough actual fun for this game." Secondly, the story is pretty decent, it's an interesting concept but it's way too short. 3 hours of gameplay is hardly worth it but people still insist about the multiplayer aspect. I really didn't buy this game with the intention of playing it online because I wanted to experience the story, not listen to the 12 year old fanbase complain about everything. Lastly, The characters are flat, they're boring and they don't have any sort of depth to them. In fact, their interaction with each other is laughable. It's rigid and lifeless, and the npcs just look like they're bored with being in such a bad game. Basically the same people are working on the sequel so clearly they're going to be making a mediocre sequel. TL;DR there is no TL;DR, read the whole review

												Fun, interesting, and short.  The premise of the game is nice, and executed well.  I especially like the newspapers that you collect that flesh out the backstory. Posted: September 4, 2012
												Homefront is a straight-forward and very enjoyable FPS, based on the premise of Far Eastern forces attacking and invading the USA. There are some very good set pieces in the game, a large array of weapons to pickup and utilise (only two of which can be carried at anyone time) and laid heavily with some great, convincing voice acting.Although still some distance behind Half-Life 2, Homefront did occasionally dip into that 'righteous campaign' feel that HL2 managed so well. You did get the feeling of David & Goliath - being hopelessly outnumbered, but fighting on for a true cause, regardless.The game itself is only short - it took me a mere 4hrs to complete the SP campaign and I hardly raced through it. But its a clever, rewarding and worthy game of attention.A solid 8.5/10

Experience may vary when playing it only on one monitor, on 3 like I play it, it's absolutely awesome.My only concern is the price. Posted: January 11, 2013
												Unfortunately where Homefront had tremendous potential it completely dropped the ball in virtually every other. I really liked the story, especially since I'm from the San Francisco Bay Area where some of the story takes place, but that's where my positive thoughts for Homefront stops. How companies get away with only providing 4 hours of content now is beyond my understanding. The controls are clunky and you have to repeatedly press buttons to crouch and prone instead of holding them like I am used to. The mechanics are extremely unrefined - you can blast enemies in the head repeatedly and they won't die. You can barely peak out from a corner and an enemy far away can pick you off. The game feels too rushed and unpolished, and if they had taken the time to iron out everything and make the campaign longer, Homefront could have been a really good game.But I do feel like the potential is there especially with it's great concept of a story - perhaps if Homefront 2 ever see's light, it will be refined and polished and provide us with more substance to allow us to really get into the game.

Posted: April 1, 2011
												There was a lot of hype associated with this game. The trailers alone were enough to convince a lot of people, including myself, to buy it. After completing it, I can't help but agree with the common criticism that the game is far too short. It'd be one thing if the ending brought some closure to the story, but it ends just as the action in the game gets really good, and in an obvious [failed] attempt to lure customers into eagerly anticipating the sequel. Given the alarmingly short campaign and the overestimated graphics, this game falls short of being worth its $49.99 price tag. The campaign is fun however, and the multiplayer, despite its relatively gutted graphics, has some potential for addictive and competitive gaming (especially for snipers), but it doesn't compete well with some other multiplayer FPS games available. While I don't feel completely disappointed, I can't in good conscience recommend it at its current price.

Posted: March 15, 2011
												I bought this game 90% for the SP... keep that in mind. I have enjoyed the SP so far, about 85% done. The game runs great, but there are some times that the FPS drops to 25ish, but this is only for around one second or less. The game looks great in SP and the atmosphere is great. The sound is crazy. The weapons sound great, but the voices can be really quite then crazily loud for a little bit. Also, the voice overs can often be out of sync with the facial animations.As for the MP, it is kind of BFBC2 scale, CoD gun handling, and Counter Strike/Crysis Wars currency system. BFBC2 is IMO much better, but there is some fun to be had in Homefront's MP. I have only spent 30-45 minutes in the MP so far and it seems I'll only continue it past the 5 hour mark when I'm with friends.If the game were $60, I would say pass. If you are on the fence, wait till it is $40ish. If you are fairly interested, get it and lets pwn some noobs online.4/5

Posted: May 9, 2011
												The single player portion of this game takes about 4-5 hours to complete the first time through. The story is disturbing because it depicts of what is going on right now in our world. It really opens your eyes to what blessings you have to live in a country were there is freedom to choose. The graphics are very detailed. The sounds in the game sound great. The overall game is really in-depth and very well done. The online portion is really alot of fun and the community isn't that hard to beat if you are used to First Person Shooters. This game is awesome and if you are ready to open your eyes to what the rest of the world is encountering right now then play it. Just don't forget that there are always people worse off then you.

												Homefront is a game which has a alternative new future setting you are a pilot by the name of Robert Jackson freed by the resistance to help against the uprise of the the oppressive Unified Korea .The story is with out a doubt amazing where North Korea occupies South Korea creating the Unified Korea and then goes to conquer the rest of Asia , there is tension between Iran and Saudi Arabia , and over Iraq but is only mensioned not shown in game , now due to Unified Korea occupied America and due to uprising againt your oppressors they kill more innocent people.Now the gameplay is not absolutle new or innovative which makes it extremely generic , the guns have very few recoil which makes gun very easy to use hence nothing is challenging and weapons feel very similar none seem unique , health regenerates really fast making cover rarely usefuly as poping in and out of cover is enough to regenerate your health fully, besides that the campaign is only 4 hours long .But the thing that makes the game very boring is how scripted the events are and how there is only one way to do things and its how the game makes it ,and how the pacing of the game is really off and you'll never feel any type of immersion or emotions off the game , the game's way of present the story is really bad that you don't care about any of the main characters and suprisingly none of them care about you the ending is very bad which makes it very clear they wanted a sequel, another thing is how bad the game makes use of friendly A.I. how you must always walk behind them so they open door , or climb ladder is just a waste of time.The multiplayer has a few innovation in their introduction of battlepoints a currency used to purchase vehicles or equipements is a good concept but poorly executed because when you have a few enemy helicopter on top of your spawn it just fustrating to the people spawning as they will die instantly and have no chance to destroy air support till the round or end game ends and due to the low recoil weapons long ranged combat easy and, how some maps dont have enough cover which make sniper very prevelent.In the end the Homefront is a game which doesn't have enough innovation to diffrentiate it from others from the genre , the story is great but the the way it is presented makes an under-par game.

Posted: December 30, 2015
												This is the type of game where i wish Steam would let me give it a rating. I can recommend it at the current price of about $5, i would never suggest somebody buy it for full price however.The game is very short, which isn't the part that bothered me. The gun play is what bothered me, how enemies act, how bullets act etc. Guns shoot exactly where you point them, There doesn't feel to be any sort of feedback, it just feels lacking. Enemies seem to be able to shoot through walls and anything you're hiding behind, and if you move just a bit they'll tear you apart. Additionally, grenades seem to spawn directly on top of you, enemies will never miss a grenade throw.It's a shame that the mechanics in the game felt so poor compared to other shooters, because the story was quite good. I finished it because of the story, but i found myself frustrated a lot more often than i should have been.

Posted: February 23, 2012
												B rated story that has been combined with numerious AI and graphic bugs. The gameplay is interesting. Quick to die and ammo is always low, so it forces you to take cover and aim. I wouldn't buy this at full price, but if it is on sale for cheap then it wouldn't hurt to check it out.

Posted: March 16, 2011
												Homefront had too much of hype. A dated control scheme and needlessly difficult and infinitely respawning enemies hold the game back from it's full potential. Aside from a few other glaring technical issues with an aging engine, the game is somewhat solid in singleplayer but never really takes off. The compelling storyline never really gets off the ground in terms of the big picture and feels more "a day in the life of crappy, unrelatable player character fighting for the resistance movement." The guns are pretty and make a nice bang, but the Korean soldiers are impossibly better shots than you. Any step out of cover, at all, results in bloody-eye syndrome until you die or take cover. There are some tired mechanics Homefront uses that I've come to expect from most recent games, but I was promised a mold-breaking, heartwrenching experience. What I got was a slow paced, buggy, and altogether mediocre game from a studio that knows how to do so much better.

Posted: November 26, 2011
												Remarkably similar to "Frontlines": Very short (3 hours), continual spawning enemies, odd use of drones. Somewhat less linear, but still plenty of impassable chest-high walls. Product placement is amusing and somehow manages to not be distracting, although I'm pretty sure Montrose, CO, has neither a Hooters nor a White Castle.  Weapon selection and ammo collection is confounding. In the end, it is worth the $15 price of a movie admission, but unless you're here for the multiplayer, I wouldn't put more than that down on it.

												Don't waste your money.  The controls are janky, the graphics feel old and outdated.  The A.I. is terrible.  The plot is non-existant.  I played each one of the multiplayer map types, and they are bad as well.  It would have been a good game back in 2001.The game has no depth and **spoiler alert** the last battle acros the Golden Gate Bridge is horrible, very Serious Sam type feeling.  If you are going to include landmarks in the game, at least build them accurately, including the land around it.Also, the 60's music when you are riding in helicopters is completely played out in video games; to which this one has, with absolutely no reason to be included in the plot line other than a vietnam-era feel when you are flying.1/5

Posted: June 11, 2013
												A game made of cliche elements. Nothing really stand out more than the ultra-linearity and lack of interesting environments. The game is so linear that you´re supposed to obey this other guy all the time and if, by any chance, you want to walk ahead of him, an invisible barrier will block your way. Taking decisions is not allowed either, as if you want to approach an assualt using a different tactic than the one your smart boss proposes, you get an instant kill. You don´t even get the chance to open doors. Everybody can push obstacles and open doors minus you.The only  reason of why getting this game is justified is that you ran out of games to play and it is in a super offer.

												I was really looking forward to Homefront when it was announced back in the day, and I pre-ordered it almost as soon as I could.BUT, when the game was finally released.... Add to that, that the game was way too short, filled with bugs and ended up being a point-and-click-run-in-a-straight-line kinda game, made me feel like it was a waste of money..What people mostly buy this game for nowadays, is for the multiplayer part, but honestly I felt like it was just a copy of all other multiplayer shooters on the marked and it didn't bring anything new, so a disappointment there as well.  I havn't tried it for years, but I doubt that it have been improved much since then..You might disagree with me, but I was way too disappointed to give this game any recommendations and I told everybody I know to stay away from it, and those whom I know had bought it, sadly agrees with me.

Posted: January 9, 2013
												An interesting background, though bundled with an unpolished shooter. Flawed AI and flat sound effects, along with less than desirable voice acting, leaves the title with wasted potential with its settings, unfortunately leaving it as close as "just another generic shooter". However, the narrative inbetween the loading of chapters, and the collectible newspaper articles provide a much more entertaining value than the game itselfHomefront briefly explored the same themes uncovered in Spec Ops (granted, the latter was released a year afterwards, possibly influenced by the former), but it falls short and taken a more traditional approach, leaving the characters under developed, and at times, we just don't really care about what's happening.Additionally, one cannot help themselves but to compare Homefront, and another title from 3 years early named Turning Point: Fall of Liberty (if unfortunate enough to have had played the latter). Of course, Homefront is better than Turning Point, but that's not saying a lot. At the very least, the gameplay is more refined.

Posted: October 5, 2012
												No meio de um mercado dominado por COD e Battlefield, que competem pra ver quem consegue atrair mais pseudo-gamers trouxas o bastante pra pagar 60 dólares por um jogo repetitivo e sem cérebro, além de torrar fortunas em DLCs ridículos, HOMEFRONT merecia um pouco mais de atenção. Seu modo multiplayer está praticamente morto (a developer fechou 3 meses após o lançamento), mas o singleplayer é fácil uma das melhores campanhas de um FPS que eu já joguei, mesmo sendo um pouco curta. Consegue realmente mexer com a cabeça do jogador, exibindo cenas fortes e bem polêmicas, mesmo pra um videogame. Se você não tiver nada melhor pra jogar, vale a pena, sem dúvida.

Posted: February 15, 2012
												Homefront's kind of... well, mediocre. The campaign is only four hours long and the multiplayer is a poor man's Battlefield clone. I did find myself moved at certain points in the campaign, but that seems to have been the idea- the man behind Red Dawn wanted to scare the pants off of people by making them think an invasion by North Korea was not only possible, but a very credible threat, and depict what would happen as a result. It's an engaging story, but it kind of falls apart when you stop and think about it long enough. Plus, heart-wrenching though some scenes were, they feel like cheap attempts to elicit tears in the end. Maybe that's the real horror of it, and this game is just about shock value. I dunno. It was if nothing else a competent single-player FPS with some good wow moments from the helicopter level and the guilty pleasure that is Goliath, autonomous♥♥♥♥♥♥wrecking attack drone.

Posted: January 11, 2013
												Unfortunately where Homefront had tremendous potential it completely dropped the ball in virtually every other. I really liked the story, especially since I'm from the San Francisco Bay Area where some of the story takes place, but that's where my positive thoughts for Homefront stops. How companies get away with only providing 4 hours of content now is beyond my understanding. The controls are clunky and you have to repeatedly press buttons to crouch and prone instead of holding them like I am used to. The mechanics are extremely unrefined - you can blast enemies in the head repeatedly and they won't die. You can barely peak out from a corner and an enemy far away can pick you off. The game feels too rushed and unpolished, and if they had taken the time to iron out everything and make the campaign longer, Homefront could have been a really good game.But I do feel like the potential is there especially with it's great concept of a story - perhaps if Homefront 2 ever see's light, it will be refined and polished and provide us with more substance to allow us to really get into the game.

Posted: March 11, 2013
												Can't decide what to play?  Just start playing Homefront while you think about it.  By the time you decide, the game will be over.  I beat it in 5 hours but I also took some time to look for some of the extras, so yeah, it's that short.This doesn't necessarily mean it's all bad.  It's got a fairly memorable campaign with quick fighting and some challenging moments.  The graphics are great, the shooting is tight.As for the story, I'm a little torn.  On one hand, the concept of an occupied America makes the environment engrossing, so the story pulls you in more than, say, most Call of Duty games.  On the other hand the action in some areas is too ridiculous to be taken seriously, counteracting the attempt at an emotional campaign.  And considering you play a freedom fighter with supposed limited resources, guns are f***ing everywhere!  I don't think I ever had less than half ammo in any gun before I was able to grab another and everywhere I stepped I was picking up more grenades.  With all the sh** the Koreans leave lying around, how is it the Americans haven't wiped them out ages ago?Anyways, I got it for like a 1.25, so I can't complain.  Fun, short little romp.  Recommended?  Meh.  Sure as hell not for 20.00.

Posted: May 10, 2013
												Not the best shooter out there, but if you like atmospheric shooters, it can still be very fun.  Although the missions are set on a pre-determined path, I thought they were pretty well executed (the last two missions were especially great). The campaign was challenging enough and short and sweet (7 missions, I finished in about 6 hours). The story is nothing to write home about but at least it was kind of new and original, and for the most part pretty immersive. There's also a multiplayer I haven't messed with too much, because as you would expect from a game this old, it's not very active. If you can pick it up  for less than $5, I'd suggest doing so.

Posted: June 6, 2015
												A brief review of Homefront's multiplayer:Likes:- Every weapon (besides one) is unlocked by leveling up in multiplayer matches; there isn't really any "pay to win" here.- Ground vehicles and the helicopters are far from "invincible", though they are still quite powerful. But recklessness will be punished by RPGs, among other counters.- Almost every weapon is viable in some way, so choosing one comes down to personal preference.Dislikes:- The Express 870 Shotgun. Can one-shot in close quarters, has a quick refire rate, and has a disturbing effective range.- No active repairs for vehicles, only the "Monkey Wrench" passive perk. And that's the very last unlock.- No 'zoom' feature for your minimap; it's fixed at a relatively close zoom. Your full map can be viewed quickly using a single button, but still.Do I recommend this game? YES.This is Homefront; Home is where the War is.In fact, why aren't you helping to repopulate the multiplayer servers right now??

Posted: May 11, 2015
												Pretty good atmosphericly, a lot going on in the background so you do kind of feel like you're under the boot of the DKRP.  The premise is kind of dumb, as with the re-make movie 'Red Dawn' it is a little daft to think the events as they're portrayed could happen in reality, ignoring that the game does portray a very realistic looking grim dystopian near future.As for the actual gameplay, it's very generic...definitely not open world, very 'Call of Duty-esque'.  You are guided from one  scene to the next with constant hints as to how to get through the stage.  I'm not usually sold on grahpics alone, but if it wasn't for the immersion that the well crafted gamescape provides the game on it's own would be pretty lame, which is a shame.  Still, I enjoyed it.  It would however, have made a better movie than Red Dawn (not the original-that's a classic).

Posted: May 12, 2015
												While I would love to recommend Homefront, I cannot. In my opinion, I have a hard time recommending this game. I am not a huge fan of multiplayer games, so I mostly bought this game for the campaign. As such, I loved the single player gameplay. I really enjoyed the guns and their physics. Each gun behaves differently, fires differently, aims differently and guns make a clicking sounds when they are empty. I wished they had added more guns, I counted only about eight, I could easily be wrong. Also, the fact I could sprint and reload made me very happy. I really enjoyed the storyline. That being said, it was by far too short. In the last scene, I thought "Oh goodness, right in the feels..." Shortly after that, the credits rolled and I silently raged. The ending seems extremely rushed and half done. I found it annoying that I had to use certain animations in the campaign; ladders, crawling through holes in walls, etc. The multiplayer seems to be dead at the moment, could be that I am writing this review at two am.  I found only about six servers, and only one server had players. Five to be exact. Pros:Fun and interesting storylineGuns, guns, guns and C4Sprinting and reloading at the same timeCons:Lack in variations of weaponsExtremely short storylineUnnecessary animationsFew players in multiplayerIf you could buy the game at $5 or less, I would buy it again.

Posted: May 11, 2015
												So .... I know this is a loved game and its a bit dated but i dont want to pull my punches so here goes.Pros:Visually interesting gameVoice acting is decent and cleargameplay is easy and has good continuity (meaning you dont get lost easily)The guns are many and interestingThe plot is current and even in 10 years im sure will still be a ligitimate fearCons:Plot is uninteresting and the writing is also mediocer wich takes you out of caring alotCover system / health system is Call of duty and so many games do it that its incredibly lame to steal identitys from other games.You will be shouted at repeatedly the same exact quotes over and over again (if you are in battle or if you are looking around for ammo they will still shout at you to go through a door or somthing)No sky .... visuals are ground level the sky is a ceiling..... its a nice painting of a ceiling but its unremakableThere is no immersion no matter how bad it is or how many bodys there are i dont care what happens to my characters or to my own character or the people in the city other games do this by enriching the script with storys or giving your own character feelings and emotions but they chose to make it a nobody named jackson with run and gun as your occupationPickups .... newspapers are a way they try and get you immersed but the storys are bland and uninterestingPlot: north koreas leader dies his son takes over and then for no reason takes over japan, south korea and america over after robbing the world of oil from the middle east. Synopsis: This plot sucks .... he did this just because .... here are a list of games and movies that have done this exact thing better: Terminator, Red faction, 1984, Red dawn .... i suppose the worst of this games failings is its a hallway ..... a hallway where i cannot go through any doors even if there open until my AI based teamates go through 1st. An AI that if im in the way will not go through me but will bend space and time to move me. An AI that rarely kills anything and is only there for the story. My enemy is this 1 ruthless korean commando who pops in every once and a while to do somthing to keep me knowing who the enemy is or somthing.I dont ned to beat the game to know this is a boring and unisnteresting game. They stole aspects from other games and took the plot from red dawn and everyone raved for a bit about how good it was .... no this even for the 5 bucks i got it for stinks .... go buy red faction, its open world and choices as well as storyline is more rich and interesting than this will ever be.How it could be better : Homfront 2: Give me a family and friends and make the 1st parts of the game about my role b4 the fighting starts and make me care about my family by beefing up the diologe then kill them and have the commander do it. then have my role in the intro where i was a doctor or a mechanic reflect in my abilitys throughout the game. make it open world and objective based meaning i can at least choose targets and prioritize them. (taking a fuel depo makes other areas not tank heavy or taking a hospital gives me more AI allies) put me in charge by giving me a haven then take it away with real consiquences. Such as the game gets harder and the depots i took get taken back and the secuirity is strengthened at them so it doesnt feel like im replaying areas. Give me allies that i can get to know through a script they get into as we progress through spacific areas. Give me adaptability where my skills can be used to take out tanks by say as a mechanic i know weak points in the hull or as a doctor i can give aid to my allies when there wounded so they can preform spacific battlefeield functions. Sorry i got ranty there but it makes me sad when some games get such great love but are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in a time when games at that exact time where better. Thanks for observing my reviewCheck out fatman and crazygirl gaming for my curator reportsor look through my profile for more interesting reviews or just ask me and wel chat about it.

Posted: February 18, 2015
												For a shooter that has mainly been ignored in the FPD community, I'm surprized on how good it was. The campain was ok, but could be better. I did not like that they pretty much threw you in the world with no backstory on your character or what was going on. Also, the campain itself was short as hell (only 4 hours on normal difficuly, and that includes dying a bunch of times). That being said, the best part about the game in my opinion is the multiplayer which is a mix of both call of duty and battlefield. Its like call of duty in the way that you can go duck around shooting and killing and its very faced paced, and it is like battlefield in the sense that there are multiple game modes, vehicules, big map sizes, and tactic opportunities. I paid 4,99$ for the game, and at that price, it is a MUST buy for shooter fans or casual gamers. Even tough the game is from 2011, it looks beutifull on Ultra settings even with today's standarts. I'd rate it a 9 out of 10. It would have been a 10 if the campain was a little bit better. So what are you waiting for? Get this game now.

Posted: July 5, 2011
												I had very high expectations for Homefront. I followed it through it's development because I loved the idea and storyline they came up with. The game's story is very short, hence my playtime. You can beat it in one sitting if you really wanted to. It ends abruptly and left with, "Yay! We just gained a bridge back!" That's it.There's one thing that makes this game's storyline shine: It's atmosphere. North Korea has taken over the U.S.A. The game makes you feel like that. Your sense of patriotism will peak as you see soldiers, bodies, and the life as you know, gone. The things you do in the story are very memorable. That's what I wanted in the story. Even though it ended abruptly, I enjoyed my time with it.The multiplayer is dead. Servers are gone and not supported since THQ's demise. The multiplayer was great. They had it's own unique system even though there were only two game modes. You unlock vehicles and other items through battleplay, points that you get for doing objectives, killing people, and etc. It had its own polished feel for what it is.The AI in storyline are an issue.They are your key to moving foward and you will find that you are stuck behind them as they clunky move toward a door or something blocking the way that you can't ddo yourself.The story is short but sweet. If you are looking for a short shooter to play. Buy it on sale but not full price.If you are buying from multiplayer, DO NOT BUY! THE SERVERS ARE DEAD.

Posted: July 8, 2013
												Homefront, made by THQ, is a first-person-shooter where you are a resistance fighter in a near-future America, where the North Korean military have occupied your country, and you and the resistance fight for survival.The Good:- Atmosphere: The sense of loss and human suffering is really emphasized, children watching their parents being shot, mass graves, attrocities, done well.- Graphics: while not the most detailed, they are rich and dynamic.The Bad:- Cover: Bullets can not even penertrate a cardboard box, enemies are often only killed when they deliberately show themselves. Not very tactical.- Linear story: Singleplayer is the same, no exploration, and suffers from the "you do as you're told" syndrome, much in the same was as Call of Duty.- Overscripted A.I: Trying to go through a door or down a ladder to early and the game will block you, forcing your teammates to go first. Very annoying and common.- Control: 90% of the time you are being told what to do / following someone- Random deaths: You may kill over 100 enemies in a battle, and then die from instantly from something???- Enemies: 90% cannon fodder infantry, the occasional tank / heli that is killed by an auto targeting ally. - Audio: Weapons sound fake, battle music is bland, this is not the game's strong point.- Sprinting: My grandmother could run faster- Ammo: Hardly any can be carried, ammo is not shared between similar weapons.This title was a dissapointment. THQ suffered from the poor sales and performance of this game. The singleplayer is linear, boring, predictable and frustraiting.After only 2 hours, I had enough. This game played so badly, with repeating objectives, poor copy+paste enemies and audio, I uninstalled the game. I did not play the multiplayer, but it looks like a bland mix of CoD and Frontlines. Hopefully crytek does a better job with the upcoming Homefront 2. Score: 3/10 (Bad)

Posted: August 14, 2011
												N.B. Comments below are based on the single-player campaign.It's short, ranging over 7 missions (it took me 5 1/2 hours), but at least these are action-packed and keep you 'entertained'. The missions offer a diversity of challenges, from sneak& sniper to vehicle missions. The weapons are standard fare, nothing out of the ordinary, but they work well with plenty of choice for everyone. Interesting is the Goliath automated vehicle.The setting is interesting, the story is Ok, the characters are ... shallow and contradict themselves often - which ruins the setting and the story quite a bit.Now to the biggest problem with the game: It is self-righteous, hypocritical and takes itself more seriously than it deserves. Accusing the enemy of dehumanizing the people you fight for (mass graves) within the game, but as a game dehumanizing the enemies by turning them into soul-less and voice-less pop-up targets ... And hence it ruins the moral discussion it tries to create from the onset.

Posted: July 19, 2014
												tl;dr - An amazing story that suffered from a critically short campaign and a crappy tacked-on multiplayer. Worth it for $20.Homefront has an amazingly rich backstory and a wonderful premise based on speculation of current world events.  I was incredibly excited to get this game immediately when it came out and dove straight into the campaign.  The story was good, if a bit linear.  There wasn't a lot of room for exploration and invention, though the non-interactive elements of the environment looked fantastic.  I let myself get drawn into the the story and setting.I noticed a few critical flaws.  First, the controls were not always intuitive.  When new weapons or situations arose later in the game, there was little to no explanation on how to take advantage of this.  (I had to go into the keybinds to figure out how to pilot the helicopter, for example.)  Some weapons were very under-utilized, appearing useful once or twice but otherwise pointless.The end of the campaign was amazing from a story perspective -- and then simply ended.  That was it.  That's the game, thanks for playing.  I had five hours of gameplay and I'd completed the campaign.  It felt like a solid 'Act One' that had absolutely nothing else to it.That's not entirely true ... there was a multiplayer component that was bland and wholly uninteresting, feeling like something they slopped into the game to claim 'Hey, we have multiplayer!' that flopped horribly.At its current price of $20 I would say this is an entertaining single-player game you can enjoy for five or six hours.  Don't bother with the multiplayer aspect and try not to lose your mind over the sometimes awkward controls.

Posted: September 11, 2016
												Okay, yes, this game is a bit of a COD clone to say the least, but it's worth a buy now. As COD is no longer this sort of game with proper boots on ground warfare and a solid shooting engine. I love games where I find it fun just to shoot♥♥♥♥♥♥ I love that in games. COD isn't that anymore, it's all ♥♥♥♥ing space warfare.Campaign-Short, only four hours to play through on normal, which is only 2 hours shorter than the campaigns of the Modern Warfare series.Story-It's alright, not great, just alright.Shooting engine/mechanics-brilliant, very nice to useVariety of weapons-weapons to suit all playstyles...just.There are 2 shotguns on their own that I can think off, and an underslung one.3 different sniper rifles, and also a single fire battle rifle.One choice of pistol.LMGs with choices of optics.Many many choices of assault rifle, with different optics.These Optics include-three different red dots, ACOGs, Iron Sights (so none), and holographic sights. That's all i can think of right now, there might be more.A couple Rocket Launchersand grenades and C4.That's all I can really say, I recomend picking this game up in a sale, it's worth it for a reduced price, but not for full retail price. Or pick it up in a humble bundle like I did. Worth playing definitely, not at full price though, wait for a sale.

Posted: October 29, 2016
TL;DRHomefront is an FPS, with a good/imaginative story-line, good voice acting, good graphics (for the time - 2011) and will keep you hooked until the finished. Not so good: You're stuck on the path the game dictates - can't explore too much...Veridict: Buy it on saleThe long versionHomefront is an FPS, released in 2011 and it's story-line is set in a near future, in America...The North Korea, somehow gets the hold onto a huge nuclear arsenal - then conquers their south counterparts, and forms the Greater Korean Republic (GKR)... It then continues to conquer/embrace other Asian countries to their ranks, enlarging their army and power...After creating an massive satellite - for "peace" - they shoot an EMP through the North America that leave it's people completely on the dark... And an invasion from the GKR then follows...And it's here, two years after this, that we start, in Montrose, Colorado...You will join a resistance movement that will try to fight back the Korean occupation of the USA.Note: I didn't find any glitch or problem in the game - like other users have mention...Pros:- Story - It's an imaginative story - and that's what games are for - to entertain us and open up our mind to other possible realites..- The scenarios and locations;- The graphics (for 2011);- The shooting system;Cons:- The ending of the game;- The length of the game;- Can only carry two guns and four grenades (for other people this can also be a PROS

Posted: July 18, 2014
												I have played this game, both the entire Singleplayer storyline and the Multiplayer. I would have to say it didn't end up being the best of quality at all. But it is something different. It is something to try out besides the usual Call of Duty and Battlefield series. Now, don't buy this game thinking it is going to be epic, because it isn't. But it sure can be fun if you decide to overlook the imperfections of the game.For your info the devs of this game "THQ" Went out of business and sold there title to Crytek. A sequel is currently being made and I sure hope that the quality will be much better in which I do believe it will, as Crytek has a lot more resources to put into it. But if you plan on getting it in 2015, then I for sure suggest that you purchase this installment to get the storyline.You can get immersed into the singleplayer storyline if you want to have a good time. Just don't be too critical of like oh that episode is missing things and such.And Multiplayer is still active that I know of. I played it and it can be quite a bit of fun. Maps are fairly open like Battlefield with a little bit more of a COD gameplay. It is a decent mix and a good change to have. So add the game to your collection and have fun.

Posted: May 16, 2013
												NO, I DON'T RECOMMEND this – This game reeks of XBOX port. Not quite to the level of ‘chest-high-walls’, but it lacks any depth beyond the ‘shoot whatever moves’ concept that would otherwise appeal to console gamers. I’m a PC gamer; chances are: you are too. And, while that doesn’t make us superior by definition, it no doubt helps us realize when we are being pandered to like idiots. I recently bought Metro 2033 and this; and the contrast of excellent storytelling and immersive environments to this all-too-generic console-port-shooter was nauseating. Granted, I didn’t make it beyond the first level, but any game that has me simultaneously pulling off headshots and contemplating weather or not to Alt+F4 instead of pulling the trigger is doing something terribly, terribly wrong. I was expecting a great deal from this game – it’s a fantastic concept that really hasn’t been explored in the industry. Unfortunately, while the concept was novel, it was poorly executed.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												So I bought Homefront for $7.49 as part of the Steam Holiday Sale.  Even with many of the reviews I've always wanted to play the game, and the price was definitely right.  That was earlier today.  I've already downloaded it, played through the entire single player campaign, and had a good go at multiplayer.  Here's what I think.The single player campaign is actually really quite cool.  Too bad it's 4 hours long.  The thing it feels most like is a game that was made to become a movie.  Kinda like a lot of books are written.  Not quite what they should be, in order to pave the way for something else.  From the guy who created Red Dawn, I guess we shouldn't expect more...  So there, single player was a lot of fun, and way too short.Multiplayer is simply♥♥♥♥♥  After several hours of play, that's the only reasonable conclusion.  There are some good ideas here, or rather they've borrowed some good ideas from others.  That said, this multiplayer fails in every way.

Posted: August 12, 2016
												I beat this game pretty quickly. As far as the single player campain goes; it's very tedious and everytime you die it will feel like a cheap and random death. It plays like the older call of duty games pretty much. All in all, I found it easy to beat in spite of many aspects fo the game being very counter intuitive. Some parts of the story are pretty graphic, so kudos to the devs for not holding back and delivering a look at what an occupation might actually be like instead of sugar coating it to be politically correct. I think the 20 dollar price tag is a bit steep for such a short and rough around the edges game. If you can get it on sale and you like shooters, I reccomend it. 6.8/10

Posted: March 31
												Fun game with a great story. At first it seems a bit too similar to Call of Duty with lots of action and twitch shooting. The best parts of this game's story and world are the locations that are peppered with war drama and well executed scenes that show you all the nasty sides of conflict that most modern shooters hide under the rug. While the single player portion of the game is very short it is worth it if you pick this game up at a discounted price. It only took me about 3 hours to finish it but there are lots of collectibles that warrant additional runs.The gunplay is a bit underdeveloped as I feel there is almost no impact to the weapons you're shooting with. Aside from that explosions pack quite a punch and the graphics, for the most part, look good. The character models seem a bit too colorful for the faded world around them and the soundtrack could have been a bit better.

Posted: February 27, 2012
												A fantastic story that still holds up to this day, with graphics that use Unreal Engine 3 quite well, but a campaign that is REALLY short, something like 2 hours or shorter. Gameplay is fun and competitive multiplayer is an absolute blast and completely different from most other competitive FPS out there. This one stands tall.+ Story+ Soundtrack+ Voice-acting+ Easter eggs+ Tons of lore+ Combat+ You really feel like a rebel in an overrun country+ San Francisco setting+ Final battle on Golden Gate Bridge+ Multiplayer is/was incredibly fun- Graphics are dated- Multiplayer is bare- Short campaign

												It just doesn't feel special, it's an ordinary FPS which makes you participate in a guerilla war against North Korean soldiers in the United States. It sounds interesting at first, but it really isn't delivered all that well. The writing for the game was decent, but the gameplay just felt so bland and boring that it nullified the quality work put into the story. Plus the game took me less than four hours to finish, that's pretty quick in my opinion.

Posted: July 21, 2016
												$20? You serious? Still? I got this game near release ages ago. In fact, I got a hard copy! I was a victim of the hype train. I don't know what it is, it's just refreshing to see a game that doesn't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t you with American propaganda. Or, you know, that's what I thought. I didn't care how unrealistic it was. A realistic scenario is the US ♥♥♥♥ed up by making too many enemies and the people it once called friends bailed out. What would be realistic would be a situation where a bunch of countries bully the US and nobody else wants to get involved because of one reason or another. Instead, this game explains nothing of the sort. You are victims to an invasion by North Korea of all people.This wasn't a bad idea. Russia is kinda cliche and, at the time, North Korea was kinda being pissy towards the US. I mean, they still are but that is besides the point. A lot of whiny people will complain about it being North Korea and how unrealistic the game is and stuff. You know what, you're right. However, so is pretty much every other good game out there. They're games, not simulators. Just enjoy it for what it's trying to be, not for what you're looking for. (this is incredibly hypocritical of me to say, but I'll keep it in here to exploit its context).The atmosphere is, again, great at first. You're hyped for how you're gonna survive against the big bad wolf, you're the underdog trying to live in a place you're no longer welcome to be a part of, despite being a citizen of that very place. Just as you're really starting to enjoy it all, it ♥♥♥♥ing ends. It's a VERY short game. Like, it's not even three hours long if I remember. Top it off, it takes a random direction that takes away the satisfaction. Here I am, enjoying the whole "Terminator: Salvation" feel of it all and then, suddenly, it becomes a generic FPS game with American propaganda. I wont spoil it, but everyone here that has played it knows what I mean. I feel it could have been better to expand upon surviving as the victims of suppression rather than being the badass underdogs that don't fear anything.  Some of the story felt pretty dark though, especially for its time. I really appreciated it, because it made me feel things at the time that most games can't make me feel. I sometimes felt a little sad, other times I felt a little disgusted but invested. These feelings, it's all evidence we have a good writer that had a part in this game's creation. However, the game is so ♥♥♥♥ing short that it's also unsatisfying. It's like, I have seen movies that told more story than this damn game. It's like, it had you craving for more and then suddenly the game randomly changes context and direction, changes rythm and momentum. You feel like you're craving so much more afterwards. You want more, but you cannot get it from this game. It's sad how empty you feel after beating this. You really do ask yourself immediately afterwards "is that it?"The gun gameplay is, at least for its time, acceptable. It is not revolutionary, it's pretty generic. It's not bad, it's not even boring, it's just not much to discuss. There is times when it feels like it is slowed down, but ultimately it is fine. Online is interesting, however. The gameplay is pretty enjoyable in fact. The online community is practically dead, but it's around and worth the checkout... or at least it was last time I checked some months ago (lol). You get to customize your loadout, like any FPS from 2011, and you shoot people on the battlefield and complete objectives. Then, you get paid for doing well. Like Counter Strike in a way, you get to spend this "good boy money" on stuff that normally isn't spoon fed to you. This game's take on kill streaks is money and strategic weapon strikes. You can also spawn a tank or helicopter if you save up, making you sometimes very dominate on the battlefield. That is probably the only problem with online, it's easy for good players to snowball. Ultimately, with the current price tag, this game is a HELL NO. This game is worth MAYBE $5-$10. I'd say even less than $10, maybe more like $8. The content in this game, it's there but you just wont get to use it really. You might play online for maybe three hours, and then campaign you might spend three to four hours. So that's seven hours or so, which means you're paying nearly $3 an hour to play this game. That's ridiculous. 6-7/10Pros-Single player has a strong start, interesting atmosphere to offer.Online is pretty addictingCons-nothing is truely special about this gameIt's strongest points are all gimped by all this game's weak points. Online is practically dead, singleplayer is overwhelmingly half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and short. It has a terribly unsatisfying ending.It's price, what the actual ♥♥♥♥. It's a conspiracy, I swear to god. They don't want anyone to buy this.Yah, I'll say I recommend this game, but what I really mean is try to get it second hand so you pay what it's actually worth.

content:
Posted: April 24
												Ah, the great cash-grab that was Homefront. An extremely ambitious (and at times genuinely enjoyable) experience which in the end manages not to live up to its potential.The Good:Voice acting is solid. While it's not the quality people who play COD routinely will be expecting, it's not bad either. Level design is also pretty decent. Yes, the campaign missions become repetitive very quickly, but once you get past the fact the devs are literally recycling the same house roughly 30 times per level, it's easy to ignore.The Bad:Writing. Your character is a silent protagonist, a trope which was proven dead back in 2001 when the original Halo came out, although some developers tried to keep selling the dead horse for some years later and it probably won't ever completely leave the FPS genre. Still it makes it very difficult to immerse yourself in all the WTF things this game throws at you, or care about any of the one-dimensional squad mates you have.Your team consists of Boone, whose dimension is the fact he's your leader, Rianna, who is female, Hooper, who has a very enthusiastic pet robot, and Conner, who is angry. I got four missions into the campaign and this was all I knew of these people, which may not seem surprising until you remember this game only has about 10 missions in it total. The world itself isn't much better. There's a lot of work going into the game's set up itself, very reminscent of the Red Dawn remake released a year later, although that manages to be a far better experience overall. Still, since we don't know anything about any of the characters, it makes it hard to figure out how they fit into the world, and it's therefore very difficult to see what sets this game apart from, say, Modern Warfare 2 or Fallout.Still, I can handle a shallow shooter if at least it's good, but sadly this game fails there as well. A lot of the shooting is just plain janky: my favorite examples of this are the Remingon 870 whose pickup icon indicates a red dot sight, though the sight itself never rendered any time I used it, or the hit boxes for several objects, which are signficantly larger than they should be (i.e., the game treats destroyed cars like completely solid objects, and you can't through the windows or windshields). The firing sounds for a lot of weapons (specifically the Diablo and M16) sound like airsoft rifles, which doesn't help, and most weapons in general feel very bland (particular note goes to the Chinese AK, SCAR-L, M4, and ACR, which I have yet to notice any significant differences between).The game tries to keep a COD-level of weapons and attachment combinations available to you, but they're mostly the same weapons with the same attachments, which most often don't matter anyway (there's no significant difference between the holographic "scope" and "ACOG" attachments, for example). The game also isn't quite sure where it wants its difficulty level to sit. The first mission is surprisingly easy, especially for someone who's sat through other similar shooters, but by mission four (the point I gave up) you're fighting enemies who will gleefully kill you through walls using RPGs with blast-radiuses measured in miles. Fortunately, for the most part your character has a lot of health, but this is good because in place of an actual sprint option you're instead given a "pleasant jog" which isn't significantly faster than your regular running speed. Worse, you're not able to do fairly logical things, like transition from sprinting to being prone; instead the game assumes you want to completely stop and stand up as straight as you can, apparently in an effort to kill yourself quickly.Homefront is probably worth maybe 20%-50% (if I'm feeling charitable) of its current asking price; for as old as it is and as shallow as it is, there's no reason to spend anything more than $10 for it. Honestly, I can't recommend this. There are simply too many other better shooters out there.

Posted: February 19, 2015
												Score -> 6/10Homefront got a lot of mixed hits when it released and for a while afterwords. I picked it up on a Steam sale a couple summers ago. Havent played Multiplayer, I dont know if mp still exists, meaning if people still play it. As for single player, its story is very reminiscent of the Red Dawn movies (even has references in game towards those movies, specifically the original). Story wise was good overall and cliche at times.Combat and Manuverability was mostly good. There were a few instances where I personally thought it was a pain in the rear shooting at enemies while you have artillery canons firing next to you. You get screen shocks and your character aiming bouncing around because of it. Its realistic i guess so its not a huge problem. My big issue I noticed with combat, specifically when shoot at enemies is noticably you tend to shoot blanks from time to time. I know sounds liek a personal problem, it may as well be.The save system or lack there of is kind of annoying a certain points of the game, its a check-point save system. Oh the Single Player Campaign is VERY LINEAR. Not an issue if you like your classic FPS titles.Lastly I played it on Guerilla (Hardest Difficulty) on first play through. It is at most a 5 hour game. I cant imagine how Easy would be. *shank... Shank... SHANK SHANK SHANK*

Posted: January 22, 2015
												A solid start, with poor design choices made early on.First, let me say that I bought into the hype when this was released. I couldn't WAIT to get my hands on it. On deliery day it was the greatest dissapointment ever. Multiplayer just simply lacks the people, mechanics or environments to make this my go-to (or even regularly played) multiplayer game. Enjoy getting stopped in the middle of a driveway stuck on something invisible? Enjoy taking a rocket to the face seconds after you ducked behind cover? Absolutely love getting killed before the 'you've been hit' red marks show on your screen? Then this game is your multiplayer paradise... assuming there are anyone populating the servers.With that aside... single player. Holy Smokes this SP tells you a story. There are scripted tunnels of cinematic moments that are meant to evoke emotion, and they do (almost, more on this later). The gameplay is fairly linier, you go forward in a straight line, no room to wiggle or backtrack to get something. Nope, forward it is. However nice the story is, it is objective based. For instance, one of the opening gun fights you're trapped in a gas station trying to clear out the enemies so you can make an escape. I huddled in the station taking stock of things, and sniped out the enemies out by the pumps, turned around to look at something, and BAM! enemies respawned out front. I took my time in that gas station, and after 45+ enemies, I realized they were respawning... But once you move past their spawn points, they stop spawning there. Cool effect to move you along in the story, annoying as heck if you're looking for the hidden objects.Now, the cinematic lock down sections. I get it, you're trying to tell a story. Thank you for attempting to inject story into a genre that lacks it. However, if you're going to lock me in a bus for the first 3 minutes of the game... make it a cinematic I can skip. Please. For the love of all things sacred. Let me skip watching people being executed on the streets.

Posted: February 3, 2015
												This game was just awful. The controls were awkward and the gameplay, even when it was okay, was stale and unimaginative. If you played the original Call Of Duty in 2003, you aren't going to find anything new here. The storyline is even worse. A lot of companies like to advertise scenarios as being 'chillingly plausibile, but the story in this game is crazier than Tom Clancy and Alex Jones sharing a giant tin foil hat. The characters are as two-dimensional as the developers could have possibly made them. This game's only redeeming quality is the multiplayer, making this the poor man's Battlefield. Overall rating: 3/10 This game gave me herpes.

Posted: January 16, 2012
												Without external influence, I'd like to personally assert that Homefront feels to me like THQ's answer to Activision's Call of Duty. You can bet your dollar that Homefront boasts a very similar action oriented campaign and multiplayer littered with perks and kill streaks.However, Homefront isn't complacent with just lifting the best features from its competitor; it bears intention to improve them. While THQ's efforts are appreciated, these additions are not as polished as one would hope.Starting with its 4-5 hour campaign, the plot here is more emotionally driven. Death is vividly depicted but its repercussions, unfortunately, not fully explored. The characters are multi-dimensional enough to be unique, but play too small a role.The multiplayer is a blend of Call of Duty and Battlefield, mixing fast paced firefights with vehicles. If you've played either of the aforementioned franchises, then you've played Homefront.Homefront isn't bad, but neither is it great.Grade: B-

												An intense but short single player campaign plus an addictive multiplayer mode helped make Homefront the first true alternative to the repetitive Call of Duty and Battlefield franchises.
