Posted: July 8, 2013
												Homefront, made by THQ, is a first-person-shooter where you are a resistance fighter in a near-future America, where the North Korean military have occupied your country, and you and the resistance fight for survival.The Good:- Atmosphere: The sense of loss and human suffering is really emphasized, children watching their parents being shot, mass graves, attrocities, done well.- Graphics: while not the most detailed, they are rich and dynamic.The Bad:- Cover: Bullets can not even penertrate a cardboard box, enemies are often only killed when they deliberately show themselves. Not very tactical.- Linear story: Singleplayer is the same, no exploration, and suffers from the "you do as you're told" syndrome, much in the same was as Call of Duty.- Overscripted A.I: Trying to go through a door or down a ladder to early and the game will block you, forcing your teammates to go first. Very annoying and common.- Control: 90% of the time you are being told what to do / following someone- Random deaths: You may kill over 100 enemies in a battle, and then die from instantly from something???- Enemies: 90% cannon fodder infantry, the occasional tank / heli that is killed by an auto targeting ally. - Audio: Weapons sound fake, battle music is bland, this is not the game's strong point.- Sprinting: My grandmother could run faster- Ammo: Hardly any can be carried, ammo is not shared between similar weapons.This title was a dissapointment. THQ suffered from the poor sales and performance of this game. The singleplayer is linear, boring, predictable and frustraiting.After only 2 hours, I had enough. This game played so badly, with repeating objectives, poor copy+paste enemies and audio, I uninstalled the game. I did not play the multiplayer, but it looks like a bland mix of CoD and Frontlines. Hopefully crytek does a better job with the upcoming Homefront 2. Score: 3/10 (Bad)

Posted: August 31, 2015
												Not a cutting edge shooter, but certainly not the worst game ever.No one is ever too concerned about storylines these days, the pretence to this one was unique, but it just felt like a generic America vs Baddies game.In terms of gameplay, unless your favourite weapon is an LMG, or an enemy weapon, you are out of luck, and will run out of ammo every few minutes and have to switch to a pick up SMG. This is one thing that annoyed me most, not being able to replenish assault rifle ammo with another type of assault rifle!Enemies only seem to target you, they are surprisingly accurate too... hitting you 90% of the time, also, every time you pop your head up you will get splashed, and even when behind cover you will get hit - when crouched even if you can't see enemies over cover, they will often be able to hit you -  probably your forehead up sticks out over cover :(Enemies drop grenades beside you with pin point accuracy too, meaning you have to run out of cover into the hail of bullets aimed directly at youObstacles nearly always come in the form of fridges or wardrobes, everytime you go to the next phase of a mission, it will be the main guy Connor (who orders you about the whole way) that pushes the fridge over, and you can continue your adventure. Clipping is also pretty annoying, before you hook up with the military, you have at least 2 people with you throughout, often 3, they will push you out of the way between firefights when you need to climb a ladder, go through a revolving door, etc, you are always last and it is annoying beyond belief! You don't actually get the option to go up/through until they have all passed.All that aside, I enjoyed playing through the Campaign, although it was pretty short, and ended abruptly, I don't think at the end you have really accomplished anything at all. Steam says my time played was 3 hours, I'm pretty sure the multiplayer is permanently offline too. So definitely not worth paying full price for.Summary: you run out of ammo quickly, seems like you are the only target for enemies, poor ending, multiplayer nonexistant

												Not as bad as critics make it out to be. Atmosphere is well done and while the COD influence is obvious, there are enough unique elements to make this game feel different and refreshing. Posted: June 25, 2011
												A bit graphics-intensive for my 4 years-old machine, however works pretty well once you bring down the motion blur and ambiant occlusion.This said, I was disappointed by the length of the single-player campaign. A mere 4 hours for a crappy player like me is kind of pathetic. I died a few times, sure, but 4 hours of single-player isn't that great, despite the incredible story.Because that's the main appeal; the main storyline is very gritty and harsh, loved it.Multiplayer is a tad on the weak side, too. No co-op that I could find, which is a real shame. Playing this 2 players would be quite awesome. 4 would be even more incredible. It has a huge potential for great co-op gameplay, which is a shame it wasn't included.As for the online multiplayer, it's somewhat of a slightly dumbed-down version of the Battlefield series.  It feels more like a giant free-for-all than an actual team-oriented multiplayer game. However, playing as a team will yield a much better experience overall.

Posted: January 22, 2015
												A solid start, with poor design choices made early on.First, let me say that I bought into the hype when this was released. I couldn't WAIT to get my hands on it. On deliery day it was the greatest dissapointment ever. Multiplayer just simply lacks the people, mechanics or environments to make this my go-to (or even regularly played) multiplayer game. Enjoy getting stopped in the middle of a driveway stuck on something invisible? Enjoy taking a rocket to the face seconds after you ducked behind cover? Absolutely love getting killed before the 'you've been hit' red marks show on your screen? Then this game is your multiplayer paradise... assuming there are anyone populating the servers.With that aside... single player. Holy Smokes this SP tells you a story. There are scripted tunnels of cinematic moments that are meant to evoke emotion, and they do (almost, more on this later). The gameplay is fairly linier, you go forward in a straight line, no room to wiggle or backtrack to get something. Nope, forward it is. However nice the story is, it is objective based. For instance, one of the opening gun fights you're trapped in a gas station trying to clear out the enemies so you can make an escape. I huddled in the station taking stock of things, and sniped out the enemies out by the pumps, turned around to look at something, and BAM! enemies respawned out front. I took my time in that gas station, and after 45+ enemies, I realized they were respawning... But once you move past their spawn points, they stop spawning there. Cool effect to move you along in the story, annoying as heck if you're looking for the hidden objects.Now, the cinematic lock down sections. I get it, you're trying to tell a story. Thank you for attempting to inject story into a genre that lacks it. However, if you're going to lock me in a bus for the first 3 minutes of the game... make it a cinematic I can skip. Please. For the love of all things sacred. Let me skip watching people being executed on the streets.

Posted: November 14, 2014
												I've had this game for some time now and on my first play-through I couldn't understand what the developers were thinking. However, after letting the game sit for a while and going back to play it once more I have decided that this game is an underappreciated, if somewhat rough gem. There are many aspects of the game that I simply adore, the attention to the detail in the collectable news reports is one of them; the absolute immersion into the politics of the time is simply brilliant, not to mention accurate. Along with this, I think that the story, which is the background story of the US being occupied, is fascinating. Usually in games the US is at the zenith of power and you have to save it from complete disaster, however here, in Homefront, the US has indeed fallen and it is the role of the resistance to attempt to rebuild. The preface for this game is wonderful and I simply love it, however there are many problems with the game mechanics, graphics and AI which let the game down. Unfortunately no matter how good the story is, playability is just as important. One of the biggest issues with the game is the AI's seemingly scripted movements, lack of intelligence and spawning locations, making a few play-throughs rather predictable. It is a real pain to re-start at a check point, kill the very same enemies in the very same way, get killed, then do it all over again a few more times. The AI, for a realistic and enjoyable shooter needs to be a little unpredictable. Continuing on from this theme of realism within the game brings me to another issue, the ballistics. I found a few times that I was being pinned down by an enemy but when returning fire it appears that I am out of range, which is strange because the longest distance you fire in the game is no more than 200 meters. For a good shooter the ballistics must be accurate; both the trajectory of the bullets and recoil need to be taken into account. The lack of recoil was not only unrealistic but frustrating  Another, and in a way a very disappointing problem is that I didn’t feel as though I was part of the resistance. The story, the concept and all the potential for a game to truly give you a resistance, grungy, underworld experience felt very much like every other shooter there is. As I said prior, I love the concept and the preface to the game, I think it is fantastic. The execution however was somewhat poorly done. You are dropped in the middle of the action without enough time to become attached to the correctors or the community. In a resistance situation, every single loss would be heartbreaking; I didn’t find that to be the case at all. There are other issues along the same lines, such as a lack of interaction with the Oasis community; it would have been great if you spent some time gathering for supplies, cutting your teeth on a few raids and what not before embarking on the main story. The game was also far too short; I think that there could have been a few more missions that would have made the game more enjoyable. I’ve probably given more criticism than praise, but that is because I wanted so desperately for this game to be good, but what stands out are the failings. This game has the potential to be great. After the release of the sequel I recommend the developers go back and re-do the original, fix it up and re-release it. I really do recommend the game if you’re able to look past the flaws, the concept is great and you’ll see just how good this game could have been. All in all, 5.5/10

Posted: January 16, 2012
												Without external influence, I'd like to personally assert that Homefront feels to me like THQ's answer to Activision's Call of Duty. You can bet your dollar that Homefront boasts a very similar action oriented campaign and multiplayer littered with perks and kill streaks.However, Homefront isn't complacent with just lifting the best features from its competitor; it bears intention to improve them. While THQ's efforts are appreciated, these additions are not as polished as one would hope.Starting with its 4-5 hour campaign, the plot here is more emotionally driven. Death is vividly depicted but its repercussions, unfortunately, not fully explored. The characters are multi-dimensional enough to be unique, but play too small a role.The multiplayer is a blend of Call of Duty and Battlefield, mixing fast paced firefights with vehicles. If you've played either of the aforementioned franchises, then you've played Homefront.Homefront isn't bad, but neither is it great.Grade: B-

												It is the year 2027. You are Robert Jacobs. The so called Greater Korean Republic has taken over the western part of America. Robert Jacobs is a former Marine helicopter pilot. Somehow, a link must be made between saving the world and being a pilot, but no. You use a car which you actually control remotely, like a little boy. Your mission is to bring fuel to a military base in San Francisco, and because of this America gets saved. The irony of this is that only hippies live there who drive electric cars that they are put up with by environmentalism people. You have to do this with a team, consisting of a black person, a woman, a feeble-minded rambo and a technician who is a half Korean, meaning your team is composed of nothing but imbeciles.Note: The only Black Person in the game dies before the halfway point. The single player starts off as a pilot in the year 2027. You are sitting in your room staring at a wall for some strange reason when suddenly a few commies knock on your door. They take you outside after they punched you in the face and throw you in what was used to be a school bus.At this moment the player ought to see all the lulzy things that happen outside, children getting♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ people dying, Korean variants of Razzia's and all other sorts of fun things, which makes them Nazi copyists. Unfortunately, your execution will be postponed because some members of the Resistance Movement blow up your bus to save you, which is dumb as ♥♥♥♥ because they could've killed you too, making them a bunch of sadistic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.Take a ride in this beautiful bus so you can end your miserable life.This is the point where the game gets gradually worse, because they actually manage to save you. You don't want this. You want do die, your life sucks. But they force you to join their Resistance, which makes hem even bigger sadistic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.The game won't last much longer from now on, considering that the single player will take you about five hours. From this point on, you will not notice difference between most levels as every level is the same apathic, miserable and dying mess like in the bus at the beginning. In every level you will kill Koreans, blow stuff up, kill Koreans, use some kind of vehicle that blows stuff up, kill Koreans, save your♥♥♥♥♥and finally kill Koreans. Strikingly enough, you will actually fly a helicopter once. ORLY, you're a pilot!

Posted: July 19, 2014
												tl;dr - An amazing story that suffered from a critically short campaign and a crappy tacked-on multiplayer. Worth it for $20.Homefront has an amazingly rich backstory and a wonderful premise based on speculation of current world events.  I was incredibly excited to get this game immediately when it came out and dove straight into the campaign.  The story was good, if a bit linear.  There wasn't a lot of room for exploration and invention, though the non-interactive elements of the environment looked fantastic.  I let myself get drawn into the the story and setting.I noticed a few critical flaws.  First, the controls were not always intuitive.  When new weapons or situations arose later in the game, there was little to no explanation on how to take advantage of this.  (I had to go into the keybinds to figure out how to pilot the helicopter, for example.)  Some weapons were very under-utilized, appearing useful once or twice but otherwise pointless.The end of the campaign was amazing from a story perspective -- and then simply ended.  That was it.  That's the game, thanks for playing.  I had five hours of gameplay and I'd completed the campaign.  It felt like a solid 'Act One' that had absolutely nothing else to it.That's not entirely true ... there was a multiplayer component that was bland and wholly uninteresting, feeling like something they slopped into the game to claim 'Hey, we have multiplayer!' that flopped horribly.At its current price of $20 I would say this is an entertaining single-player game you can enjoy for five or six hours.  Don't bother with the multiplayer aspect and try not to lose your mind over the sometimes awkward controls.

Posted: July 24, 2016
												Allright, I can recommend the game for it's story (very nice), graphics and sound where well done.. BUt as for the rest, sadly can't say it's worth the few dollars I paid, I can't remember the last time I played a game so stuck on a linear track.. when the game gives you a new objective such as go here , what ir really means is that you can't go there and have anything happen till character X you are following gets there as well.. you can't for example go through a doorway till the character you're following travels the appointed movement track and it will leave you stuck listening to hey we need to go here if the character getts hung up and can't move forward. and the Second biggest gripe is the hitboxes/cover system you cant duck behind something and can be almost assured that the enemy can shoot through it to get you, but you can not do the same, you can duck around the corner even and have nothing obstructing the barrel of your weapon and still have bullets be blocked by the *invisible*corner of the crate,wall, etc. Ammo types as other have mentioned are quite annoying as well.. several weapons take the same size round of ammunition, but you can only pickup ammo if it's from a weapon with the same name,, All in all unless you can pick it up for $5 or so for the story maybe , can't recommend it for the frustration factor

Posted: October 29, 2016
TL;DRHomefront is an FPS, with a good/imaginative story-line, good voice acting, good graphics (for the time - 2011) and will keep you hooked until the finished. Not so good: You're stuck on the path the game dictates - can't explore too much...Veridict: Buy it on saleThe long versionHomefront is an FPS, released in 2011 and it's story-line is set in a near future, in America...The North Korea, somehow gets the hold onto a huge nuclear arsenal - then conquers their south counterparts, and forms the Greater Korean Republic (GKR)... It then continues to conquer/embrace other Asian countries to their ranks, enlarging their army and power...After creating an massive satellite - for "peace" - they shoot an EMP through the North America that leave it's people completely on the dark... And an invasion from the GKR then follows...And it's here, two years after this, that we start, in Montrose, Colorado...You will join a resistance movement that will try to fight back the Korean occupation of the USA.Note: I didn't find any glitch or problem in the game - like other users have mention...Pros:- Story - It's an imaginative story - and that's what games are for - to entertain us and open up our mind to other possible realites..- The scenarios and locations;- The graphics (for 2011);- The shooting system;Cons:- The ending of the game;- The length of the game;- Can only carry two guns and four grenades (for other people this can also be a PROS

Posted: July 21, 2016
												$20? You serious? Still? I got this game near release ages ago. In fact, I got a hard copy! I was a victim of the hype train. I don't know what it is, it's just refreshing to see a game that doesn't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t you with American propaganda. Or, you know, that's what I thought. I didn't care how unrealistic it was. A realistic scenario is the US ♥♥♥♥ed up by making too many enemies and the people it once called friends bailed out. What would be realistic would be a situation where a bunch of countries bully the US and nobody else wants to get involved because of one reason or another. Instead, this game explains nothing of the sort. You are victims to an invasion by North Korea of all people.This wasn't a bad idea. Russia is kinda cliche and, at the time, North Korea was kinda being pissy towards the US. I mean, they still are but that is besides the point. A lot of whiny people will complain about it being North Korea and how unrealistic the game is and stuff. You know what, you're right. However, so is pretty much every other good game out there. They're games, not simulators. Just enjoy it for what it's trying to be, not for what you're looking for. (this is incredibly hypocritical of me to say, but I'll keep it in here to exploit its context).The atmosphere is, again, great at first. You're hyped for how you're gonna survive against the big bad wolf, you're the underdog trying to live in a place you're no longer welcome to be a part of, despite being a citizen of that very place. Just as you're really starting to enjoy it all, it ♥♥♥♥ing ends. It's a VERY short game. Like, it's not even three hours long if I remember. Top it off, it takes a random direction that takes away the satisfaction. Here I am, enjoying the whole "Terminator: Salvation" feel of it all and then, suddenly, it becomes a generic FPS game with American propaganda. I wont spoil it, but everyone here that has played it knows what I mean. I feel it could have been better to expand upon surviving as the victims of suppression rather than being the badass underdogs that don't fear anything.  Some of the story felt pretty dark though, especially for its time. I really appreciated it, because it made me feel things at the time that most games can't make me feel. I sometimes felt a little sad, other times I felt a little disgusted but invested. These feelings, it's all evidence we have a good writer that had a part in this game's creation. However, the game is so ♥♥♥♥ing short that it's also unsatisfying. It's like, I have seen movies that told more story than this damn game. It's like, it had you craving for more and then suddenly the game randomly changes context and direction, changes rythm and momentum. You feel like you're craving so much more afterwards. You want more, but you cannot get it from this game. It's sad how empty you feel after beating this. You really do ask yourself immediately afterwards "is that it?"The gun gameplay is, at least for its time, acceptable. It is not revolutionary, it's pretty generic. It's not bad, it's not even boring, it's just not much to discuss. There is times when it feels like it is slowed down, but ultimately it is fine. Online is interesting, however. The gameplay is pretty enjoyable in fact. The online community is practically dead, but it's around and worth the checkout... or at least it was last time I checked some months ago (lol). You get to customize your loadout, like any FPS from 2011, and you shoot people on the battlefield and complete objectives. Then, you get paid for doing well. Like Counter Strike in a way, you get to spend this "good boy money" on stuff that normally isn't spoon fed to you. This game's take on kill streaks is money and strategic weapon strikes. You can also spawn a tank or helicopter if you save up, making you sometimes very dominate on the battlefield. That is probably the only problem with online, it's easy for good players to snowball. Ultimately, with the current price tag, this game is a HELL NO. This game is worth MAYBE $5-$10. I'd say even less than $10, maybe more like $8. The content in this game, it's there but you just wont get to use it really. You might play online for maybe three hours, and then campaign you might spend three to four hours. So that's seven hours or so, which means you're paying nearly $3 an hour to play this game. That's ridiculous. 6-7/10Pros-Single player has a strong start, interesting atmosphere to offer.Online is pretty addictingCons-nothing is truely special about this gameIt's strongest points are all gimped by all this game's weak points. Online is practically dead, singleplayer is overwhelmingly half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and short. It has a terribly unsatisfying ending.It's price, what the actual ♥♥♥♥. It's a conspiracy, I swear to god. They don't want anyone to buy this.Yah, I'll say I recommend this game, but what I really mean is try to get it second hand so you pay what it's actually worth.

												I bought this for the campaign, which while decently interesting, was far too short. Decent dialogue and characters, cool setpieces showing the brutality and horror of militarized occupation. 												That was fast. If I had three words to sum up this game, it would be those three words. Homefront is a game about fighting a guerrilla war against the North Korean Army, which has "liberated" the United States. Now, to this end, the mission was accomplished. North Korean soldiers were killed, and it was in a guerrilla fashion. However, that's not to say I didn't have a few issues with the game. First off, I beat this game in one afternoon. One afternoon. It's more like a DLC, and nowhere near the full-length size most games are nowadays. On that note, if you're bored one afternoon, and want to give a a whirl, hey, go ahead; you'll be done before dinner's on the table. Also, I enjoyed the variety of guns, but combat was not exactly varied. I was more going through the motions, and how I engaged my target depended largely on what weapon I was using at the time. Also, I enjoyed the moments when I got to use the Resistance's robot thingy that launched many rockets (kind of like Black Ops 2's CLAW unit). Overall, like I said, if you have an afternoon to kill, I would say why not? It doesn't bring anything really new to the table, but sometimes, you just need to shoot some bad guys. And Homefront has no shortage of bad guys, let me tell you.Overall Score: 7.8/10

Posted: May 9, 2015
												Just for frame of reference, I paid $5 on sale for this game and I only played the single player. I did not complete the single player because I got fed up with it.Pros:-Lots of little details in the graphics, characters, environment, etc.-LOTS of guns and LOTS of customization options.-The game doesn't let you carry a lot of ammo so you're forced to swap out weapons often. This allows you to get comfortable with all of the weapons available.-Lots of options and settings to customize your graphics settings and gameplay.-One word. Goliath.Cons:-This game tries way too hard to be serious, and it falls flat on its face. I watched the first couple of cinematics, then immediately started skipping them.-Collectible newspapers in your on-the-rails shooter? No thanks.-EXTREMELY scripted. You find yourself stopping at every door just to wait for your buddies to open it for you.-Clunky PC controls for swapping weapons, but you can customize it. Should have been more thought out.-Very strange hit detection. I found myself spamming sniper rifle shots trying to hit people sometimes. -Cover makes the hit detection even worse. It's acceptable in a large open world like Skyrim or Fallout, but not in a shooter like this.-Simple ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ enemy AI.-'Mericuh.-Rianna's big fat♥♥♥♥♥ While you're waiting for your buddies to open doors and progress the plot you will find yourself being helplessly jostled around like a stripper during fleet week because your allies have MASSIVE character boxes! Rianna even got me stuck in a doorway once because she wouldn't drink a slimfast once in a while. My advice? Stay far away from your friends.-Why is everyone such a♥♥♥♥♥♥to Hopper?Summary:Is this a good game? No. But I'd say it's worth $5 if shooters are your thing. I can't speak to the multiplayer--I just picked it up to give it a try. This game was definitely overhyped when it first came out, but now that no one remembers it the game can actually stand on its own and be worthy of $5. I'd say I at least got $5 worth of gameplay out of it.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												Game is damn good. The beginning is quite like COD4, which gives an insight about the brutal behavior of intruders thus you have the right season to fight back. Game play is brilliant. Story goes very intense and absorbing. Have a good shooting feeling, and a balanced difficulty of enemies. You don't have lots guns to choice but pick up the right one you should be fine.Again this game built up an awesome atmosphere, some scenes unforgettable: You actually hide inside a body-drop ditch to avoid enemies; the anger the time you saw the hide heaven been destroyed and manslaughters; One mission that requires sniper rifle with stealth; Also you fly a helicopter and in gun position of military vehicles; The final mission on Golden Gate Bridge...This game is a blast. If you like FPS games, be sure don't miss this one.However still some downsides, like the introduction of each new chapter is barely a few pages with sound but no CG; some collections are hard to find but not so interesting. Repeat scenes and unlimited enemies, if you don't get to the point the mission asks you. But overall the game experience is quite well.8/10 recommend. Kudos to developers.

Posted: May 23, 2013
												Homefront is a game which has a alternative new future setting you are a pilot by the name of Robert Jackson freed by the resistance to help against the uprise of the the oppressive Unified Korea .The story is with out a doubt amazing where North Korea occupies South Korea creating the Unified Korea and then goes to conquer the rest of Asia , there is tension between Iran and Saudi Arabia , and over Iraq but is only mensioned not shown in game , now due to Unified Korea occupied America and due to uprising againt your oppressors they kill more innocent people.Now the gameplay is not absolutle new or innovative which makes it extremely generic , the guns have very few recoil which makes gun very easy to use hence nothing is challenging and weapons feel very similar none seem unique , health regenerates really fast making cover rarely usefuly as poping in and out of cover is enough to regenerate your health fully, besides that the campaign is only 4 hours long .But the thing that makes the game very boring is how scripted the events are and how there is only one way to do things and its how the game makes it ,and how the pacing of the game is really off and you'll never feel any type of immersion or emotions off the game , the game's way of present the story is really bad that you don't care about any of the main characters and suprisingly none of them care about you the ending is very bad which makes it very clear they wanted a sequel, another thing is how bad the game makes use of friendly A.I. how you must always walk behind them so they open door , or climb ladder is just a waste of time.The multiplayer has a few innovation in their introduction of battlepoints a currency used to purchase vehicles or equipements is a good concept but poorly executed because when you have a few enemy helicopter on top of your spawn it just fustrating to the people spawning as they will die instantly and have no chance to destroy air support till the round or end game ends and due to the low recoil weapons long ranged combat easy and, how some maps dont have enough cover which make sniper very prevelent.In the end the Homefront is a game which doesn't have enough innovation to diffrentiate it from others from the genre , the story is great but the the way it is presented makes an under-par game.

Posted: January 9, 2013
												An interesting background, though bundled with an unpolished shooter. Flawed AI and flat sound effects, along with less than desirable voice acting, leaves the title with wasted potential with its settings, unfortunately leaving it as close as "just another generic shooter". However, the narrative inbetween the loading of chapters, and the collectible newspaper articles provide a much more entertaining value than the game itselfHomefront briefly explored the same themes uncovered in Spec Ops (granted, the latter was released a year afterwards, possibly influenced by the former), but it falls short and taken a more traditional approach, leaving the characters under developed, and at times, we just don't really care about what's happening.Additionally, one cannot help themselves but to compare Homefront, and another title from 3 years early named Turning Point: Fall of Liberty (if unfortunate enough to have had played the latter). Of course, Homefront is better than Turning Point, but that's not saying a lot. At the very least, the gameplay is more refined.

Posted: February 9, 2015
												I am split about this game.  I enjoyed many of the missions, but as beautiful as the world they place you in is, it is very linear.  You are forced down very narrow paths with at most the ability to walk around the left side of a vehicle/box/house versus the right side.  Throughout the game you have the challenge of discovering little bits of news papers as background story but I found that while looking for them, almost always after a firefight, you miss out in the NPC dialog as they continue on with the mission ahead of you.  Speaking of which, the running mechanic is to me far too slow.  Walking crouching feel correct, but running feels like I have a 200 Lbs pack on my back.  There is a prown / crawling position, but that got used twice, once in the opening mission as a demo, and once later.  The mission types are wonderfully varied, from heli pilot / gunner, hummer gunner, sniper, rpg gunner, grenade launcher missions, in addition to the standard fps mode but they only appear forthe most part once each (minus the fps missions).  Which brings me to my biggest problem with the game, it's very short.  It took me only 7 hours to finish and it could have been faster if I wasn't overly aggressive running and gunning and dying in many of the FPS missions as I was, in addition, if I avoid the side news paper hunting element of the game I could have easily taken another hour off the total time.  Over all a good game, but only at a discount.  Side note, I did not play the multiplayer part of the game.

Posted: January 11, 2013
												Unfortunately where Homefront had tremendous potential it completely dropped the ball in virtually every other. I really liked the story, especially since I'm from the San Francisco Bay Area where some of the story takes place, but that's where my positive thoughts for Homefront stops. How companies get away with only providing 4 hours of content now is beyond my understanding. The controls are clunky and you have to repeatedly press buttons to crouch and prone instead of holding them like I am used to. The mechanics are extremely unrefined - you can blast enemies in the head repeatedly and they won't die. You can barely peak out from a corner and an enemy far away can pick you off. The game feels too rushed and unpolished, and if they had taken the time to iron out everything and make the campaign longer, Homefront could have been a really good game.But I do feel like the potential is there especially with it's great concept of a story - perhaps if Homefront 2 ever see's light, it will be refined and polished and provide us with more substance to allow us to really get into the game.

Posted: April 1, 2011
												There was a lot of hype associated with this game. The trailers alone were enough to convince a lot of people, including myself, to buy it. After completing it, I can't help but agree with the common criticism that the game is far too short. It'd be one thing if the ending brought some closure to the story, but it ends just as the action in the game gets really good, and in an obvious [failed] attempt to lure customers into eagerly anticipating the sequel. Given the alarmingly short campaign and the overestimated graphics, this game falls short of being worth its $49.99 price tag. The campaign is fun however, and the multiplayer, despite its relatively gutted graphics, has some potential for addictive and competitive gaming (especially for snipers), but it doesn't compete well with some other multiplayer FPS games available. While I don't feel completely disappointed, I can't in good conscience recommend it at its current price.

												Could be worse, could be better.The campaign is pretty cool, and the feeling while shooting is nice and charging.The multi player alas, is pretty unbalanced, with a points-to-buy sort of killstreaks and powerups for your soldier with no team restriction. Prepare to have a sky full of bombers, machine gun drones and UAV guided missiles. Poor footsoldiers and sharpshooters can't live too long. Posted: March 16, 2011
												Homefront had too much of hype. A dated control scheme and needlessly difficult and infinitely respawning enemies hold the game back from it's full potential. Aside from a few other glaring technical issues with an aging engine, the game is somewhat solid in singleplayer but never really takes off. The compelling storyline never really gets off the ground in terms of the big picture and feels more "a day in the life of crappy, unrelatable player character fighting for the resistance movement." The guns are pretty and make a nice bang, but the Korean soldiers are impossibly better shots than you. Any step out of cover, at all, results in bloody-eye syndrome until you die or take cover. There are some tired mechanics Homefront uses that I've come to expect from most recent games, but I was promised a mold-breaking, heartwrenching experience. What I got was a slow paced, buggy, and altogether mediocre game from a studio that knows how to do so much better.

Posted: July 24, 2016
												Allright, I can recommend the game for it's story (very nice), graphics and sound where well done.. BUt as for the rest, sadly can't say it's worth the few dollars I paid, I can't remember the last time I played a game so stuck on a linear track.. when the game gives you a new objective such as go here , what ir really means is that you can't go there and have anything happen till character X you are following gets there as well.. you can't for example go through a doorway till the character you're following travels the appointed movement track and it will leave you stuck listening to hey we need to go here if the character getts hung up and can't move forward. and the Second biggest gripe is the hitboxes/cover system you cant duck behind something and can be almost assured that the enemy can shoot through it to get you, but you can not do the same, you can duck around the corner even and have nothing obstructing the barrel of your weapon and still have bullets be blocked by the *invisible*corner of the crate,wall, etc. Ammo types as other have mentioned are quite annoying as well.. several weapons take the same size round of ammunition, but you can only pickup ammo if it's from a weapon with the same name,, All in all unless you can pick it up for $5 or so for the story maybe , can't recommend it for the frustration factor

Posted: March 31
												Fun game with a great story. At first it seems a bit too similar to Call of Duty with lots of action and twitch shooting. The best parts of this game's story and world are the locations that are peppered with war drama and well executed scenes that show you all the nasty sides of conflict that most modern shooters hide under the rug. While the single player portion of the game is very short it is worth it if you pick this game up at a discounted price. It only took me about 3 hours to finish it but there are lots of collectibles that warrant additional runs.The gunplay is a bit underdeveloped as I feel there is almost no impact to the weapons you're shooting with. Aside from that explosions pack quite a punch and the graphics, for the most part, look good. The character models seem a bit too colorful for the faded world around them and the soundtrack could have been a bit better.

												While I enjoyed the style of this FPS set in a compelling near-future vision of the US, I found it to be seriously lacking in substance. The single player campaign is painfully short with very little replay value and although the engine is servicible I never realy felt drawn in to the action and as a result it doesnt really jump out as a title to play multiplayer. I was also annoyed by the fact that it doesnt display the correct buttons to push for an x box controller, so I spent a lot of time mashing keys trying to work out what was button 8 to drop my flares or whatever.It's not a terrible game and I really liked the back story, but I really can't recommend it as there just isn't enough meat on the bone.

Posted: February 23, 2015
												There are issues with the single player storyline although it is fun. Your teammates can keep you alive, but they also make your job harder, especially Connor.  If you could kill him this game would be way shorter and way easier.Spoiler:In the bell-tower with all the enemies below and your teammates come back right below you and Connor decides to barrel across the way and then they tell you to come out as enemeies autospawn. Why? Why not just wait for you at the truck and let you get in and then drive to the next assignment? The makers wanted you to wade through autospawn attackers?  The level was too easy or too short otherwise? I don't know.Second Spoiler:In the helicopter, you are supposed to destroy tankers.  They are invincible so you have to hijack them instead. Your team gets in tankers and suddenly you are responsible to keep them safe.  They were just invincible 10 seconds before for crying out loud! Call me a whiner, but hopefully the game designers put themselves in the game as enemies so I could shoot them for it.Teammates seem to exist mostly to keep you alive and annoy you at the same time. They offer endless distractions with their cries for help. Did I mention they are invincible? Yes, the unkillable annoyances, sort of like coworkers and siblings.Why would I recommend the game?  Multiplayer.  Singleplayer is fun, but has annoyances.

Posted: February 24, 2015
												I enjoyed this game much more then Call of Duty and it looked beautiful, despite running it on low graphics. The weapons weren't exactly varied, and I didn't notice a huge difference between different rifles and SMGs, but that, I suppose, comes with playing mutliplayer and more intensively. The stealth portions were few, but very well done, and the combat was only "constant spawning" in two or three places, and did not require you to "move up" only kill all the enemies to advance, which is more realistic. You also cannot rush down enemies with a knife, as the rifles are powerful enough to kill you in three or four well placed shots. I only used the knife twice in the entire game where it wasn't necessary to advance the story. The story was a bit confused and rushed at some points, but hey, it was plenty realistic! 8/10

Posted: May 27, 2016
												Well then.Homefront is a first-person shooter developed by the now closed Kaos Studios, with a incredible multiplayer mode developed by Digital Extremes and was published by Deep Silver in 14/03/2011. I'll seperate this into two reviews, one of the Single-Player and another one of the Multiplayer, and then a final verdict and score with both combined.-Single Player-Homefront has a pretty cool idea in its single-player mode, but sadly it's terribly written and it has terrible voice-acting, but a good amount of weaponry and it's sometimes fun, but generally it's just dull. The game has pretty bad optimization, and lots of bugs. There isn't much to talk about here, specially in the 3 hours of gameplay that the campaign offers. It's pretty boring, but it's still competent. I can still give credit for the single player as it's brutal and shows what kind of face war has. War is hell. I liked the weaponry like i said, but it doesn't matter much since the game isn't really that fun. The graphics look extremely outdated but the graphics aren't bad. The game runs in the Unreal Engine 3, and i have seen more games that run in this engine that both run better and look better, in which case i'm talking about Batman Arkham Knight, which i did not have optimization problems like the ones i did with Homefront. the sudden ending is very ♥♥♥♥♥♥, and utterly disappointing, as of how much you'll suffer by how many enemies the game puts you into, and you'll die many times. This game will obviously show you America on its knees and it's slowly building a downfall. The ending and story itself doesn't resolve anything at all. The game tries to make characters which you should care about, but you just won't. This is clearly, Spec-Ops: The Line, but done wrong. Very wrong. The soundtrack is very good, but nothing too good. The concept is ♥♥♥♥ing incredible, but i'm sad that the story isn't. This could be a beggining for a great franchise or trillogy. Homefront: The Revolution released, but even if it's not as good as many expected, we still have hope. But one thing this game shows us that even Spec-Ops: The Line did show: War is Hell.Pros:+Weaponry+Concept+Soundtrack+War is hell+Brutality+Sometimes funCons:-Voice-acting-The game looks dull and outdated-Optimization-Storyline is terribly written-Extremely Boring-Too easy, but sometimes too unfairOverall, the campaign for Homefront is really bad, but still has hope.Score for Campaign:3/10 -War is hell, so is this campaign.+Multiplayer+Here we are, talking about a multiplayer mode that is very good. Homefront has a really fun multiplayer, even with the small amount of content it offers. There isn't much i know, all i know pretty much is how fun it is, and how it remains being fun and never stops being fun. Weaponry remains good, and there isn't much to talk about here, it's simply fun, but of course, i don't think you would buy this game just for the multiplayer. It makes up for the ♥♥♥♥♥torm that was the Campaign, but doesn't make up too much. I don't know how to explain the problems of the Multiplayer, just that really, it's not much content or things to keep you busy playing it, but it's fun enough to make you play it a lot.Not enough content for me to qualify Pros and Cons.Score for Multiplayer:8.5/10Final Verdict for Homefront:Homefront is a game that has a great concept in its hands, along with pretty cool weaponry and stuff, but the general problems it has are just so many that i don't think you'd buy this game if it was at time of release. But at this point, the multiplayer is still good and the price is lower, so it's a game worth checking out for the Multiplayer, which doesn't make up entirely for the badly optimized, terribly written, terribly voice-acted campaign it has, but still has a good soundtrack and it truly shows us what War is like, but the thing is, War isn't the only hell you're gonna go through in Homefront. Because the other type of hell is the campaign itself, and i mean it as of how bad the campaign is. If you're gonna check this game out, do it for the Multiplayer.Final Score for Homefront:7.2/10 ~America is on its knees.

Posted: July 21, 2016
												$20? You serious? Still? I got this game near release ages ago. In fact, I got a hard copy! I was a victim of the hype train. I don't know what it is, it's just refreshing to see a game that doesn't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t you with American propaganda. Or, you know, that's what I thought. I didn't care how unrealistic it was. A realistic scenario is the US ♥♥♥♥ed up by making too many enemies and the people it once called friends bailed out. What would be realistic would be a situation where a bunch of countries bully the US and nobody else wants to get involved because of one reason or another. Instead, this game explains nothing of the sort. You are victims to an invasion by North Korea of all people.This wasn't a bad idea. Russia is kinda cliche and, at the time, North Korea was kinda being pissy towards the US. I mean, they still are but that is besides the point. A lot of whiny people will complain about it being North Korea and how unrealistic the game is and stuff. You know what, you're right. However, so is pretty much every other good game out there. They're games, not simulators. Just enjoy it for what it's trying to be, not for what you're looking for. (this is incredibly hypocritical of me to say, but I'll keep it in here to exploit its context).The atmosphere is, again, great at first. You're hyped for how you're gonna survive against the big bad wolf, you're the underdog trying to live in a place you're no longer welcome to be a part of, despite being a citizen of that very place. Just as you're really starting to enjoy it all, it ♥♥♥♥ing ends. It's a VERY short game. Like, it's not even three hours long if I remember. Top it off, it takes a random direction that takes away the satisfaction. Here I am, enjoying the whole "Terminator: Salvation" feel of it all and then, suddenly, it becomes a generic FPS game with American propaganda. I wont spoil it, but everyone here that has played it knows what I mean. I feel it could have been better to expand upon surviving as the victims of suppression rather than being the badass underdogs that don't fear anything.  Some of the story felt pretty dark though, especially for its time. I really appreciated it, because it made me feel things at the time that most games can't make me feel. I sometimes felt a little sad, other times I felt a little disgusted but invested. These feelings, it's all evidence we have a good writer that had a part in this game's creation. However, the game is so ♥♥♥♥ing short that it's also unsatisfying. It's like, I have seen movies that told more story than this damn game. It's like, it had you craving for more and then suddenly the game randomly changes context and direction, changes rythm and momentum. You feel like you're craving so much more afterwards. You want more, but you cannot get it from this game. It's sad how empty you feel after beating this. You really do ask yourself immediately afterwards "is that it?"The gun gameplay is, at least for its time, acceptable. It is not revolutionary, it's pretty generic. It's not bad, it's not even boring, it's just not much to discuss. There is times when it feels like it is slowed down, but ultimately it is fine. Online is interesting, however. The gameplay is pretty enjoyable in fact. The online community is practically dead, but it's around and worth the checkout... or at least it was last time I checked some months ago (lol). You get to customize your loadout, like any FPS from 2011, and you shoot people on the battlefield and complete objectives. Then, you get paid for doing well. Like Counter Strike in a way, you get to spend this "good boy money" on stuff that normally isn't spoon fed to you. This game's take on kill streaks is money and strategic weapon strikes. You can also spawn a tank or helicopter if you save up, making you sometimes very dominate on the battlefield. That is probably the only problem with online, it's easy for good players to snowball. Ultimately, with the current price tag, this game is a HELL NO. This game is worth MAYBE $5-$10. I'd say even less than $10, maybe more like $8. The content in this game, it's there but you just wont get to use it really. You might play online for maybe three hours, and then campaign you might spend three to four hours. So that's seven hours or so, which means you're paying nearly $3 an hour to play this game. That's ridiculous. 6-7/10Pros-Single player has a strong start, interesting atmosphere to offer.Online is pretty addictingCons-nothing is truely special about this gameIt's strongest points are all gimped by all this game's weak points. Online is practically dead, singleplayer is overwhelmingly half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and short. It has a terribly unsatisfying ending.It's price, what the actual ♥♥♥♥. It's a conspiracy, I swear to god. They don't want anyone to buy this.Yah, I'll say I recommend this game, but what I really mean is try to get it second hand so you pay what it's actually worth.
